{"code":1,"isDone":false,"toInsertArticleList":[{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"8 Resources to Use to Ensure You're Using Inclusive Language","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/tools-inclusive-language","description":"<p>We've talked about it before, but <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/workplace-diversity-stats\">diversity, inclusion, and belonging</a> shouldn't be about filling a quota. Instead, the goal should be to foster a true sense of belonging among your team, which is likely filled with people from <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/cultural-competence\">all backgrounds</a>.</p>  \n<p>One way to do this is by using inclusive language.</p> \n<p>Whether it's intentional or not, we all carry implicit biases in our everyday language. However, it's important to make a conscious effort to avoid this.</p> \n<p>This isn't <em>just</em> the right thing to do. It also makes good business sense.</p> \n<p>In fact, <a href=\"https://learn.joinhandshake.com/employers/70-inclusive-language-principles-that-will-make-you-a-more-successful-recruiter/\">over 70% of students said they prefer a company that is diverse, inclusive and makes them feel included regardless of race, geographic location, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, disability, socioeconomic status, and appearance.</a></p> \n<p>Additionally, creating a sense of belonging can <a href=\"https://www.inc.com/adam-vaccaro/why-letting-employees-express-themselves-is-good-for-business.html\">lead to greater retention rates and even result in higher customer satisfaction</a>.</p> \n<p>So, how can you use more inclusive language?</p> \n<p>Below, we'll review the top tools that can automate this process for you and resources that can help you use more inclusive language.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://betterallies.com/language/\">Better Allies</a></h3> \n<p>During an allyship meeting at HubSpot, we discussed tools that help people use more inclusive language.</p> \n<p>A colleague brought up a Slackbot, Better Allies. This Slackbot can help you shift your language to be more inclusive.</p> \n<p>The tool was inspired by the book Better Allies by Karen Catlin. This book can help you spot situations where you can create more inclusive culture.</p> \n<p>The Slackbot will automatically flag non-inclusive language and make alternate suggestions. You can even customize the tool by adding your own words to avoid and alternate suggestions.</p> \n<p>For example, I want to remove the words \"guys\" and \"crazy\" from my vocabulary. With this tool, I can put those words in the Slackbot and then include suggestions for myself to use instead.</p> \n<h3>2. Inclusive Language Guides</h3> \n<p>An <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/inclusive-language\">inclusive language</a> guide is a document that will advise you on terms to avoid and alternative terms to use. The goal is to use more inclusive language that doesn't have biases, slang, or discriminatory terms.</p> \n<p>While an inclusive language guide won't help you automate this process, you can use this resource to inform your automation process. For example, you can add terms from an inclusive language guide to your Better Allies Slackbot.</p> \n<p>If your team doesn't have an inclusive language guide, we suggest you create one. Our inclusive language guides at HubSpot have sections on Gender, LGBTQIA+, Race, Ethnicity, Culture, and Accessibility.</p> \n<p>Here are some great examples to get you started:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://buffer.com/resources/inclusive-language-tech/\">Buffer's Inclusive Language Guide for Startups and Tech</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/offensive-phrases-that-people-still-use-2013-11\">Business Insider's Race and Ethnicity Inclusive Language Guide</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://everydayfeminism.com/2015/08/alternatives-to-oppressive-language/\">Everyday Feminism's Inclusive Language Guide on Ableism and Homophobia</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://nasaa-arts.org/nasaa_research/inclusive-language-guide/\">NASAA Inclusive Language Guide</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/gender-neutral-pronouns\">HubSpot's Guide on Gender Neutral Pronouns</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://apastyle.apa.org/style-grammar-guidelines/bias-free-language/socioeconomic-status\">How to Talk About Socioeconomic Status</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"http://religionstylebook.com/categories\">Religion Stylebook</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.self.com/story/self-weight-health-style-guide\">Self's Weight and Health Style Guide</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://developers.google.com/style/inclusive-documentation\">Google's Guide for Developers in Writing Inclusive Documentation</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://consciousstyleguide.com/sensitive-style-for-covering-sexual-violence/\">Writing About Sexual Violence</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.knowyourix.org/press-room/guide-for-journalists/\">Gender-Based Violence Language Guide</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.glaad.org/reference\">GLAAD Media Guide</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h3>3. Company Bots</h3> \n<p>To automate your inclusive language, you can create a bot that will alert you when you use exclusionary terms.</p> \n<p>As you saw above, Better Allies created one to help you on Slack. However, you might want a bot when you're using Google docs or other platforms.</p> \n<p>In that case, you can create your own. At HubSpot, we have a bot that HubSpotters can download on Chrome that will review content for HubSpot's style guide.</p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://textio.com/\">Textio</a></h3> \n<p>As a company, you produce a lot of content. Your employees have to write a lot. To automate your process, you can use Textio.</p> \n<p>Textio is an augmented writing platform that can give your team a score on the content they write. Plus, it provides suggestions on how to improve.</p> \n<p>This includes bias interruption, expanded language insights, and team analytics. The whole point is to help you write more insightful, inclusive content.</p> \n<p>You can use this for recruiting purposes or just to review your company blogs.</p> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"http://gender-decoder.katmatfield.com/\">Gender Decoder</a></h3> \n<p>A quick way to check your language for gender bias is to use this gender decoder. You can just copy and paste your content in it and get quick results.</p> \n<p>While this was created to analyze job ads to ensure you use inclusive language, you can put any content in there.</p> \n<p>I even put this blog content in to see the results. The tool told me, \"This uses more words that are subtly coded as feminine than words that are subtly coded as masculine (according to the research). Fortunately, the research suggests this will have only a slight effect on how appealing this is to men, and will encourage women.\"</p> \n<h3>6. <a href=\"https://www.ted.com/talks/kimberle_crenshaw_the_urgency_of_intersectionality\">TEDTalk with Kimberlé Crenshaw</a></h3> \n<p>While using tools to help automate your inclusive language process is important, it's also necessary to focus efforts on continued learning.</p> \n<p>That's why we recommend watching this short (only 18 minutes) TEDTalk on the urgency of intersectionality. This talk discusses the reality of race and gender bias so we can understand how the two combine and create more harm.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, the goal is to broaden your understanding of intersectionality and implicit bias so you can recognize it when it occurs and speak up for victims of prejudice.</p> \n<h3>7. <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QhENGl3XviM\">MTV Decoded</a></h3> \n<p>For an even shorter way to continue your education (5 minutes), you can watch this great video from MTV on phrases that have a racist origin.</p> \n<p>Again, this is an easy and quick way to continue learning about implicit bias so you can adjust your language to be more inclusive.</p> \n<p>You can consider sending these types of short videos to your employees to encourage them to use more inclusive language and continue learning.</p> \n<h3>8. <a href=\"https://www.tolerance.org/professional-development/test-yourself-for-hidden-bias\">Implicit Bias Test</a></h3> \n<p>A great way to see if you're using inclusive language is to test yourself on implicit biases. This test will measure unconscious bias.</p> \n<p>This is an excellent step to take so you can examine, understand, and recognize your own biases and when you're using exclusionary language.</p> \n<p>We recommend sending this to people on your team as well. This will help your whole team begin to understand and use more inclusive language as a whole.</p> \n<p>Taking active steps to use inclusive language is an important part of allyship. Additionally, it's important for your employees and customers to see that you participate in and encourage others to continue learning about other people's experiences.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ftools-inclusive-language&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 24 Sep 2020 08:30:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"530bb725ffca2ef968f037a071020440","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Rebecca Riserbato","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ftools-inclusive-language&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn37@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-51-864_d766d35befeb17b9.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389707},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"How to Implement & Succeed With Marketing Automation","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/marketing-automation","description":"<p>Emails. Social media posts. PPC campaigns. <em>Wait</em> — another email. Don’t miss that new lead that just downloaded your online course!</p>  \n<p>The life of a marketer or business owner is <em>busy</em>. Your brain is constantly swirling with ideas, which doesn’t help you get to the bottom of your never-ending task list. Believe me — as both a marketer and business owner, I know how this feels.</p> \n<p>In the past 20 or so years, new tools and technology have helped simplify some of these tasks … but this increase has also served to heighten customers’ expectations: <em>Oh, our audience is expecting abandoned cart emails now? Okay, let me add that to the list…</em></p> \n<p><em></em></p> \n<p>One technology improvement has made marketers’ lives abundantly easier, however — marketing automation. This guide will walk you through the ins and outs of marketing automation, including:</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Let’s dive in.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p></p> \n<p>If you’ve ever done some midnight shopping (ahem, like me) and <em>immediately</em> received a confirmation email, you’ve been met with <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/insiders/what-is-marketing-automation-a-beginners-guide\">marketing automation</a>. You didn’t think there was a poor guy sitting behind his computer at 1:00 AM waiting for new purchases to come through, did you?</p> \n<p>No, that online store likely has some pre-written and scheduled email automations ready to go out when their customers complete certain tasks on their website. We’ll talk more about email marketing automation below.</p> \n<p>Other marketing automations include social media, advertising, and SMS marketing automation, as well as internal automations that help you manage and triage marketing tasks.</p> \n<p><em><a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/lead-management?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase\">Marketing automation can help you capture and nurture more (and more qualified) leads. Learn more about how to do this in our free HubSpot Academy course.</a></em></p> \n<p>Nearly <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/marketing-statistics\">70% of marketing leaders</a> are currently using a marketing platform. Of those who are automating marketing, <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/marketing-statistics\">23%</a> are automating their content delivery.</p> \n<p>Marketing automations can certainly make life easier, but it shouldn’t replace human touch. As I said in the introduction, a recent increase in technology has been met with increased or changed consumer expectations. Marketing automation is no exception — consumers appreciate the timeliness and thoughtfulness of automation, but they also can also read between the lines of bot-written copy or stale imagery.</p> \n<p>Marketing automation should complement your current marketing efforts, not replace them.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>What is marketing automation primarily used for?</h2> \n<p>Marketing automation is primarily used to mechanize and automate otherwise manual marketing tasks like sending emails, posting social media messages, collecting information, and managing internal tasks.</p> \n<h3>Benefits of Marketing Automation</h3> \n<p>There are countless <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/marketing-automation-benefits\">benefits of marketing automation</a>. A few I’d like to highlight include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Efficiency</strong>: Wasted time is a marketer’s nightmare. Marketing automation can help you complete repeatable tasks in an efficient <em>and</em> effective manner.</li> \n <li><strong>Nurtured leads</strong>: It takes a lot of time and energy to effectively nurture every individual lead; however, it’s too important <em>not</em> to. Marketing automation allows you to nurture your leads on a mass scale while still personalizing each lead’s experience with your brand. <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/marketing-statistics\">70% of the companies</a> report that the most important benefit of automation technology is better-targeted customer communication.</li> \n <li><strong>Increased revenue</strong>: The more you nurture your leads, the more leads that’ll likely convert to users. Marketing automation can result in increased revenue as more leads become paying customers.</li> \n <li><strong>Better reporting</strong>: Marketing automation streamlines important marketing tasks and allows you to review and analyze your activity and its results.</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Types of Marketing Automation</h2> \n<p>Marketing automation can take many forms. Let’s unpack the different types of automation and how you can use them in your marketing.</p> \n<h3>Email Marketing Automation</h3> \n<p>Email marketing automation is perhaps the most common use case for automation. From welcome emails to post-purchase emails and re-engagement emails, there’s a lot that goes into email marketing. Without <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/email-marketing-automation-examples\">email marketing automations and workflows</a>, email would be an otherwise <em>very</em> manual process.</p> \n<p>Email automation is typically <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/triggered-emails-marketing-automation\">triggered</a> by <strong>time</strong> or <strong>action</strong>. Time-based emails are sent on certain occasions, such as a customer’s birthday (don’t you love those free birthday drinks from Starbucks?) or a holiday (Black Friday discounts, anyone?).</p> \n<p>Action-based emails are a bit more involved. These automated emails are triggered by actions taken by a website visitor, lead, or customer who then receives an email or series of emails related to that particular action.</p> \n<p>Let’s return to my midnight shopping example. Instead of completing my purchase and receiving the subsequent confirmation email, let’s say I exit the site with items still in my cart—and within 30 minutes, I receive an email reminding me about the forgotten items. This is called an <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/ecommerce/shopping-cart-abandonment-reasons-solutions\">“abandoned cart” email</a>, and many online stores deploy them in hopes that shoppers return and complete their purchases. This is an example of an <em>action-based</em> email marketing automation.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image1-Sep-28-2020-08-09-25-32-PM.png?width=188&amp;name=image1-Sep-28-2020-08-09-25-32-PM.png\" alt=\"marketing automation abandoned cart email\" width=\"188\" style=\"width: 188px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\"></span></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\"><em><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/abandoned-cart-email\">Source</a></em></span></p> \n<p>Email automation campaigns are among the <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/marketing-statistics\">top three tactics</a> used by email marketers to improve performance, and email marketing automation has many benefits. The best one (in my opinion) is how it saves precious time and energy by otherwise <em>priceless</em> tasks. Automated emails can help you generate leads and increase revenue, but that doesn’t mean your marketing team has to spend all their time sending and monitoring them. That’s what marketing automation is for.</p> \n<p><em><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/beginner-guide-retargeting-campaigns?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase\">Learn everything you need to know about email marketing in our free HubSpot Academy course.</a></em></p> \n<h3>Digital Marketing Automation</h3> \n<p>Although email marketing is a common use case for marketing automation, it’s not the only one. Let’s talk about other forms of digital marketing automation (both external and internal).</p> \n<h4>Social Media Marketing Automation</h4> \n<p>Anyone who works in marketing knows how time-intensive <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/29340/how-to-automate-your-social-media-marketing-like-the-pros.aspx\">social media marketing</a> can be. If you’re going to do it right, you’ve got to do, well, nonstop. Thankfully, marketing automation can help. Tools like <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/social-inbox\">HubSpot</a> and <a href=\"https://hootsuite.com/\">Hootsuite</a> allow you to schedule content, set social media monitoring filters, and even automate the response process — although this should never replace genuine, human interaction with your followers and customers.</p> \n<h4>Advertising Automation</h4> \n<p>You’ve heard of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/beginner-guide-retargeting-campaigns\">retargeting</a>, yes? Now … could you imagine having to go into every advertising platform and change the copy, graphics, and timing based on each customer’s individual actions or behavior? Whew, that’d be a lot. Retargeting is an example of advertising automation, as it automatically shifts and smartens its strategy in response to consumer behavior. If a customer visits your website, your retargeting automation will respond by displaying relevant ads on the sites they browse next.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image3-Sep-28-2020-08-09-25-35-PM.png?width=340&amp;name=image3-Sep-28-2020-08-09-25-35-PM.png\" width=\"340\" style=\"width: 340px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"marketing automation retargeting\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><em><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/crm-automation\">Source</a></em></p> \n<h4>Mobile Marketing Automation</h4> \n<p>As SMS marketing becomes more popular and effective, companies are adding <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/28776/the-ultimate-cheat-sheet-for-mastering-mobile-marketing.aspx\">mobile marketing</a> to their marketing automation tool belts. Like emails, text messages can also be automated and triggered based on time or actions, and they tend to have a higher (and faster) open rate than emails.</p> \n<h4>CRM with Marketing Automation</h4> \n<p>Ah, the <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/crm\">CRM</a>—a marketer’s best friend. Thankfully, your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/crm-automation\">CRM and marketing automation</a> can go hand-in-hand. A simple update in your database can trigger a whole host of internal tasks, including lead scoring and alerting your sales team to new prospects. You can also use your CRM to trigger email workflows, either based on user data or user actions.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image2-Sep-28-2020-08-09-25-82-PM.png?width=600&amp;name=image2-Sep-28-2020-08-09-25-82-PM.png\" alt=\"marketing automation crm \" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><em><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/marketing-automation-software-tools\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\">Source</span></a></em></p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Marketing Automation Software</h2> \n<p>As a marketer, your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-build-a-marketing-stack\">marketing technology stack</a> may or may not be your best friend … I know mine sure is.</p> \n<p>Do you have a favorite tool or two? Let me guess — a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/marketing-automation-software-tools\">marketing automation software</a> (if you’re currently using one) just crossed your mind.</p> \n<p>I don’t blame you. These tools sure make our lives easier and our customers happier. If you’re looking for new tools to add to your list, or you’re wanting to check out marketing automation for the first time, take a look at the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/marketing-automation-software-tools\">marketing automation software tools we’ve compiled in this article</a>. Here are a handful of of my favorites:</p> \n<h3>HubSpot</h3> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/crm\">HubSpot CRM</a>, as mentioned above, provides many marketing automation features. As a standalone tool, HubSpot’s marketing automation allows you to automate a variety of tasks, from setting up simple email workflows to building a complex network of rules to target users with tailored emails, live chats, and more.</p> \n<h3>Drip</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.drip.com/\">Drip</a> specializes in e-commerce marketing automation. It’s mostly used for email marketing and provides email automation workflows, multi-channel marketing, full campaigns, and more.</p> \n<h3>ManyChat</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://manychat.com/\">ManyChat</a> allows you to extend your marketing automation strategy beyond email. Use this tool to build a smart bot to engage with prospects and customers on Facebook Messenger and over SMS. While your marketing automation shouldn’t replace a human touch, ManyChat can help you get the conversation started with prospects — it also captures information from prospects and adds it to your CRM.</p> \n<h3>Sprout Social</h3> \n<p>I had to include at least one social media marketing automation tool on this shortlist. <a href=\"https://sproutsocial.com/\">Sprout Social</a> can help lighten the load of manual social media tasks — responding to messages, tracking engagement, and measuring audience sentiment. Moreover, Sprout Social provides easy onboarding documentation and resources so you can hit the ground running.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Marketing Automation Strategy</h2> \n<p>Your marketing automation strategy should vary depending on what tools you use and what goals you set. For example, if you choose to use HubSpot to nurture leads that download a free ebook, your strategy would focus on converting those leads using information relevant to why they perhaps downloaded the ebook—and how your product or service could help meet those needs.</p> \n<p>Regardless of your marketing automation strategy, however, make note of these few marketing automation best practices:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Know your audience. </strong>You can’t create personalized marketing — whether automated or not — without knowing what your audience’s pain points are and how you can meet them. <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/make-my-persona\">Build your buyer personas</a> to get to know your audience before building your marketing automation workflows.</li> \n <li><strong>Know your customer journey.</strong> A key determinant of successful marketing automation is meeting your lead wherever they are. You can’t do this unless you know their journey to become your customer. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/customer-journey-map\">Map out your customer journey</a> and match your marketing automation to those lead stages.</li> \n <li><strong>Review on a regular basis. </strong>Although marketing automation is pretty hands-off, it is not a one-and-one strategy. Review your marketing automation workflows on a monthly, quarterly, and yearly basis. Your automation should change as your business, products, and customers do.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Check out this blog post for more <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/tips-marketing-automation-less-robotic\">marketing automation tips</a>.</p> \n<h2>Automate Your Marketing to Grow Better</h2> \n<p>Marketing automation may seem like a lot to learn upfront … but imagine what it’ll feel like to kick back and relax once you’ve got everything in place. OK, maybe not <em>relax</em>, but marketing automation will certainly help you shorten that to-do list.</p> \n<p>From email marketing to advertising and retargeting to internal tasks, marketing automation can help you save time, energy, and money — and make your customers’ lives easier and happier. It truly is a marketer’s best friend.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmarketing-automation&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 01 Oct 2020 11:30:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"4d108d0ab030c57c181abc7b938b5c67","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"adecker@hubspot.com (Allie Decker)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image1-Sep-28-2020-08-09-25-32-PM.png?width=188&name=image1-Sep-28-2020-08-09-25-32-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn82@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-47-434_d0d177e407a31876.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image3-Sep-28-2020-08-09-25-35-PM.png?width=340&name=image3-Sep-28-2020-08-09-25-35-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn24@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-45-786_d68e78ce7af4e615.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/image2-Sep-28-2020-08-09-25-82-PM.png?width=600&name=image2-Sep-28-2020-08-09-25-82-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn27@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-50-564_55bbde4c976e4092.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmarketing-automation&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn70@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-48-181_e53766453099329a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389702},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"What is Real-Time Marketing? (In 300 Words or Less)","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33696/7-inspiring-examples-of-real-time-marketing-in-action.aspx","description":"<p>While it might seem like people use delayed media (like streaming services or podcasts) more often, real-time media hasn't come to a halt.</p> \n<p>Real-time marketing is still a great way to get in front of and convert your audience.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>In fact, <a href=\"https://oursocialtimes.com/real-time-marketing-increases-conversion-rates-by-26/\">a new report from Monetate and Econsultancy concludes that UK marketers report a 26% increase in conversion rates from real-time marketing</a>.</p> \n<p>Additionally, <a href=\"https://www.slideshare.net/lieblink/outlook-2013-marketing-advertising-social-media-trends\">a study found real-time marketing not only positively impacts standard marketing goals -- word-of-mouth, attention, preference, likelihood to try or buy -- but it also turbocharges other marketing initiatives, including paid and owned media effectiveness</a>.</p> \n<p>As marketers, those stats are impossible to ignore.</p> \n<p>Below, let's learn more about real-time marketing, and then we'll see what it looks like in action.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>This type of marketing occurs when your company reacts, instead of planning or strategizing a marketing plan for months. That's not to say that you won't have a real-time marketing plan, but it'll be a quicker turnaround.</p> \n<p>The objective? To connect with your audience and communicate your brand position.</p> \n<p>You might be able to plan real-time marketing if there's an event or ongoing trend. For example, if you strategize an ad around a current fad, your company might become more appealing to your audience because you understand them.</p> \n<p>Real-time marketing helps you provide relevant messaging that is tailored to your audience's wants, interests, and needs.</p> \n<p>One way for marketers to implement a real-time marketing strategy is to have an active social media presence.</p> \n<p>Your social media team will often be the first people to know about a current fad or trend if they're implementing <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/social-listening\">social listening</a> (which they should be).</p> \n<p>Additionally, you can learn more about your audience and their current interests by looking at your own data.</p> \n<p>For instance, you can look at your website or social media analytics to discover the most popular topics of conversation. You can also learn what questions your audience is asking through <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/social-listening-tools\">social listening tools</a>.</p> \n<p>Having a team actively look at this information every day can be helpful in planning and strategizing a real-time marketing plan.</p> \n<p>When you want to implement a paid real-time marketing ad, you can use social media and search engine targeting tools to ensure you reach the right audience. That type of personalization in marketing has elevated real-time marketing efforts.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, to effectively implement a real-time marketing plan, you should always listen to your audience, monitor industry trends, and know where the conversation is taking place.</p> \n<p>Then, you need to react. Respond to your audience on social media and create assets to discuss what's going on.</p> \n<p>Before you implement a real-time marketing campaign, think about your audience and what you want to achieve with your reaction. Once you know the goal, you can create your message, whether it's a social media comment, an email, or an ad.</p> \n<p>Now that we know more about real-time marketing, let's review some examples.</p> \n<h2>Real-Time Marketing Examples</h2> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">1. <a href=\"https://www.responsiveinboundmarketing.com/blog/ice-bucket-challenge-a-lesson-in-real-time-marketing\" style=\"font-size: 14pt;\">ALS Ice Bucket Challenge</a></h3> \n<p>One of the greatest lessons in real-time marketing is the ice bucket challenge from 2014. This phenomenon went around the globe and every company or celebrity who took part in the challenge was participating in real-time marketing.</p> \n<p>Taking part in the challenge was a way to raise awareness and money for ALS. But since it was a current event and trend, companies were able to increase brand sentiment and awareness by participating.</p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://www.inbound.com/\" style=\"font-size: 14pt;\">INBOUND</a></h3> \n<p>Every year, INBOUND attracts thousands of business professionals from almost every industry to learn more about marketing, sales, and customer service.</p> \n<p>During this three-day event, businesses and professionals are active on social media and commenting on the live events, such as HubSpot product updates and the keynote speech.</p> \n<p>All of these social media posts and comments about the live breakout sessions or speeches are real-time marketing in action.</p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://twitter.com/tacobell\" style=\"font-size: 14pt;\">Taco Bell</a></h3> \n<p>Taco Bell has built a reputation as a great company to follow on social media through their <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/brand-communication-strategy\">crafted brand messaging</a>.</p> \n<p>The reason? On social media, Taco Bell's strategy is to take part in enthusiastic real-time marketing. They respond to messages on Twitter almost twice an hour every day.</p> \n<p>The company has made it a priority to listen to their customers online and to interact and connect with them, no matter what is happening that day.</p> \n<p>Real-time marketing is a great strategy to connect with your customers right now. However, to implement this type of marketing, it's important to measure conversations and sentiment to determine how real-time programs will develop. To get started, you can use free monitoring tools, or invest in one of the many paid social media monitoring technologies.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fblog%2Ftabid%2F6307%2Fbid%2F33696%2F7-inspiring-examples-of-real-time-marketing-in-action.aspx&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 08 Oct 2020 21:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"138df802f7746516f686d21dd17d856d","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Rebecca Riserbato","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fblog%2Ftabid%2F6307%2Fbid%2F33696%2F7-inspiring-examples-of-real-time-marketing-in-action.aspx&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn52@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-48-929_cf3b8d24fba0718e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389713},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"The Ultimate Guide to Successfully Livestreaming From Home","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/livestream-from-home","description":"<p><em>This post is written by Kerry Shearer, \"The Livestream Expert\". Kerry is a conference speaker, workshop presenter, online course creator and smartphone video trainer based in Sacramento, California.&nbsp;</em></p> \n<p>In 2020, the way we work, shop and entertain ourselves has been completely up-ended.</p> \n<p>Work and school transitioned online, placing many people in unfamiliar situations with frustrating technical challenges as they livestream from home.</p> \n<p>The results have sometimes been cringe-worthy.</p> \n<p>On live webinar meetings, for example, we've been treated to up-the-nose camera angles, inadvertently-shared bathroom breaks, echo-y audio and dark, grainy webcam video.</p> \n<p>Not the best way to make an impression!</p> \n<p>The good news is that it's actually pretty easy to give your viewers an outstanding experience, whether you're participating in an online meeting on Zoom or <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-live-stream-checklist\"><span>livestreaming on popular platforms</span></a> like Facebook Live, Twitter Live, Periscope or Instagram Live.</p> \n<p>When you have the right mindset, the right approach, and the right accessories, you can absolutely look and sound like a pro.</p> \n<p>Here, I'll share my best practices when it comes to live streaming, including the platform(s) you should consider when livestreaming, and all the equipment you need to get started.</p> \n<p>But first — let's dive into the benefits of livestreaming for businesses.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Benefits of Livestreaming</h2> \n<p>I've spoken with many entrepreneur and communications colleagues, and months of lockdown have definitely taken an emotional toll.</p> \n<p>Staying motivated when your lifestyle and habits have been disrupted means it's more important than ever to get exercise, eat well, and practice self-care so you can be your best self in these trying circumstances.</p> \n<p>And it also means you need to put yourself in the place of your customer or client.</p> \n<p>When livestreaming, it's critical to remember that it's not about you — it's about the difference you're going to make in the life of the person you're impacting with the information you're delivering!</p> \n<p>Many of us are doing two types of livestreaming these days: online meetings or webinars with colleagues, and livestreams related to promoting our products or services.</p> \n<p>For our purposes we'll focus on the second type of livestreaming: promoting a product or service.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Livestreaming is a powerful tool to help entrepreneurs and small businesses differentiate themselves and connect with customers (or potential ones).</p> \n<p>And doing it well can make a huge difference in your impact — and your earnings.</p> \n<p>Vancouver therapist <a href=\"http://www.juliakristina.com/\"><span>Julia Kristina</span></a>, who holds a Master's degree in Psychology, used live video as a springboard to create a thriving online business to compliment her existing in-person clinical practice.</p> \n<p>She told me, \"I began showing up live on Periscope and Facebook, nearly every day at first, doing short talks about different mental wellness topics.\"</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>\"Doing all those unscripted livestreams, either from home or from my office downtown, made me an even better public speaker. At the same time, it grew a loyal audience whose lives were being impacted by what I was teaching.\"</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>Kristina eventually began creating and selling live online group coaching and recorded video courses on topics such as having healthy boundaries, overcoming anxiety, and building confidence.</p> \n<p>Last fall, Kristina launched her membership program, \"<a href=\"https://courses.juliakristina.com/ss-cv-waitlist-sign-up\"><span>The Shift Society</span></a>,\" which features both live video coaching and recorded video content for members.</p> \n<div class=\"hs-embed-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; width: 100%; height: auto; padding: 0; max-width: 560px; max-height: 315px; min-width: 256px; display: block; margin: auto;\">\n <div class=\"hs-embed-content-wrapper\">\n  <div style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.25%; margin: 0px;\">\n   <iframe style=\"position: absolute; top: 0px; left: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"https://www.facebook.com/plugins/video.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2FJuliaCounsellor%2Fvideos%2F1093071547544970%2F&amp;show_text=0&amp;width=560\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n  </div>\n </div>\n</div> \n<p>\"Livestreams don't need to be perfect,\" Kristina says. \"You just need to show up, be yourself, and let your passion for the topic be the magnet that draws your ideal audience in.\"</p> \n<p>Particularly in 2020 when many brick-and-mortar shops needed to shift largely online, livestreaming can provide opportunities for small businesses to connect with their customers and prospects in real-time.</p> \n<p>Miranda Pinto, owner of <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/la.piccolina.ca/\"><span>La Piccolina Baby Boutique</span></a> in Lincoln, CA, turned to Facebook Live in an effort to keep sales afloat after having to close her doors to walk-in customers.</p> \n<p>Initial livestream attempts were hampered by poor internet upload speeds at her store, so she and an assistant grabbed piles of clothing and headed to Pinto's house to do their first big online sale.</p> \n<p>\"I felt totally out of my element as a video host, but I know my product, so I just kept talking and describing each item.\"</p> \n<div class=\"hs-embed-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; width: 100%; height: auto; padding: 0; max-width: 267px; max-height: 476px; min-width: 256px; display: block; margin: auto;\">\n <div class=\"hs-embed-content-wrapper\">\n  <div style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 178.28%; margin: 0px;\">\n   <iframe src=\"https://www.facebook.com/plugins/video.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fla.piccolina.ca%2Fvideos%2F1733482893467152%2F&amp;show_text=0&amp;width=267\" width=\"267\" height=\"476\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0px; left: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"true\"></iframe>\n  </div>\n </div>\n</div> \n<p>Pinto says the sales just kept coming in. \"We use a subscription-based tool called 'Comment Sold' to track sales and send invoices.\"&nbsp;</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>\"I credit livestreaming with saving my business and giving homebound moms an easy and fun way to shop locally for baby clothing.\"</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>Pinto says each sale she conducts on Facebook Live lasts 1-2 hours, and creates the income normally earned in 2-4 days of walk-in sales when the store is open.</p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Live Streaming Platforms&nbsp;</h2> \n<p>So if these stories have inspired you, it's time to choose a livestreaming platform to focus on. That involves figuring out where your potential audience is (or, upon which platform you want to build a presence). There are more choices than ever, but it's better to get started with one.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Next, let's go over a brief overview of each popular livestreaming platform.</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">1. Facebook Live</h3> \n<p>Facebook is undeniably the most popular social platform worldwide, with more than <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/264810/number-of-monthly-active-facebook-users-worldwide/\"><span>2.7 billion monthly active users</span></a>.</p> \n<p>Facebook Live allows you to broadcast to the world in real-time, and live video is more often prioritized by the algorithm and shown in your news feed.</p> \n<p>Facebook Live is an effective way of providing training and information in Facebook Groups, and many <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/pages\"><span>Business Pages</span></a> use it to reach out to followers with how-to demonstrations, product unboxings, trainings, and sales events.</p> \n<p>It's easy to go live via the <a href=\"https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.facebook.katana&amp;hl=en_US\"><span>Facebook app</span></a> on your phone, or through <a href=\"https://business.facebook.com/creatorstudio/\"><span>Facebook Studio</span></a> on a desktop or laptop.</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">2. Twitter and Periscope</h3> \n<p>Periscope is Twitter's live broadcasting app, which <a href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2015/03/13/how-periscope-works/?guccounter=1&amp;guce_referrer=aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZ29vZ2xlLmNvbS8&amp;guce_referrer_sig=AQAAAEcr6kSqJ9unugxhxWxWLh3NTf5Q5wHsWMGO_eLqobQ975KDJ1iAgdsfGDH4hxtvzqyi8TmQJNlxrZhvPUPSOQunWnb0wszmhsFjs_oV9fSHOBDF6oMMbN6jI7DsOizofydY9-heqKNCAs12hXObOPznteYgQ2QsXuf-uLro6UAI\"><span>launched in March 2015.</span></a> When you go live, you broadcast to the app and your followers get a push notification that you're live.</p> \n<p>Your livestream is also shown in user's Twitter feeds if your accounts are linked with the same username.</p> \n<p>For this reason, use of hashtags in the broadcast title can result in a bigger audience.</p> \n<p>You can also broadcast directly from the Twitter app using the \"Live\" button. Twitter is known as the place to go for \"what's happening now\", so livestreams involving timely events are popular.</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">3. Instagram Live</h3> \n<p>2020 marks Instagram's 10<sup>th</sup> year of operation, and the service has about <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/253577/number-of-monthly-active-instagram-users/\"><span>1 billion active users</span></a>.</p> \n<p>That userbase could grow even more with Instagram's <a href=\"https://about.instagram.com/blog/announcements/introducing-instagram-reels-announcement\"><span>recent release of Reels</span></a>, its answer to Tik Tok for creating short videos that can go viral.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-go-instagram-live\"><span>Instagram Live also offers a feature</span></a> that lets you bring one guest at a time into the broadcast.</p> \n<p>Instead of expiring after 24 hours, any Instagram Live broadcasts that you want to save can now be shared to your Instagram TV channel.</p> \n<h2 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Best Livestreaming Equipment</h2> \n<p>Once you've chosen the right platform for your needs, you'll need to ensure you have the equipment necessary to create high-quality live videos.</p> \n<p>Livestreams don't have to be perfect, but it <em>is</em> critical to have good lighting, great audio, and a steady shot. Here are some of the options I recommend regularly to clients who want to put on a great broadcast.</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">1. Lighting</h3> \n<p>Natural light on your face always looks great, so if your computer desk faces a window that lets in ambient outdoor light (rather than direct, harsh sunlight), it will provide a natural look.</p> \n<p>If natural light isn't available, you can add LED lighting. Dimmable LED ring lights are popular, and the better ones are bi-color.</p> \n<p>That means they have control knobs to let you \"warm\" the color of the light to match the tone of the room, or \"cool\" the color to mimick the look of outdoor light.</p> \n<p>Ring lights, such as the <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3279ZJM\"><span>Dracast Halo 180</span></a>, come in a popular 18\" size, which generally requires mounting on an aluminum light stand.</p> \n<p>A smartphone or video camera can be mounted inside the ring and set at eye-level, giving your face a nice, even glow.</p> \n<p>There are also smaller desktop ring lights available, such as the <a href=\"https://amzn.to/34ea5SS\"><span>Neewer 10\" ring light</span></a>, or <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2E3od6w\"><span>GVM rectangular ring light</span></a>, which can hold your smartphone or serve as a webcam light by peeking over the top of your computer monitor.</p> \n<p>The Lume Cube company <a href=\"https://lumecube.com/collections/best-sellers/products/video-conference-lighting-kit-for-remote-workers\"><span>has created LED lighting</span></a> specifically for video conferencing, including a rectangular light with a suction mount that sticks to the back of your computer monitor.</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">2. Audio</h3> \n<p>Viewers will often put up with less-than-perfect video quality, but if the audio is poor, don't expect them to hang around your livestream for long.</p> \n<p>Poor audio is an issue for either smartphone broadcasting — where the built-in microphone picks up lots of annoying background noise — or for streaming from a laptop computer, where the cheap internal mic often produces thin-sounding audio that's hard to listen to for long periods of time.</p> \n<p>One solution for smartphones is a simple wired lavaliere smartphone mic, such as the <a href=\"https://amzn.to/322wRKF\"><span>YouMic</span></a>.</p> \n<p>The mic clips onto your shirt, blouse or blazer, and the cord connects to the audio jack on your smartphone.</p> \n<p>If you have an iPhone 7 or newer, you'll also need the Lightning-to-3.5mm headphone adapter that came with your phone.</p> \n<p>Connect your mic to the adapter, and the adapter to the Lightning port.</p> \n<p>If you'd prefer to go wireless, a dependable lightweight system like the <a href=\"https://www.bhphotovideo.com/c/product/1471382-REG/rode_wireless_go_compact_wireless.html\"><span>Rode Wireless Go</span></a> is a great solution. The receiver and transmitter are very small and operate for seven hours on built-in rechargeable batteries.</p> \n<p>Additionally, the transmitter has a built-in mic, so you can just clip it to your jacket.</p> \n<p>Or, to be more discreet, Rode's plug-in Lavaliere Go mic can be purchased separately so you can ditch the transmitter in a pocket and use the small clip-on microphone.</p> \n<p>Another option is the similar <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3aFYTQa\"><span>Pixel</span></a> wireless lavaliere microphone.</p> \n<p>If you've had experiences sitting on a Zoom call for hours, you know how hard it can be on the brain to listen to tinny audio from participants speaking from echo-y home offices.</p> \n<p>A solution for this is to use a plug-in USB microphone with your laptop or desktop computer so you can get your voice closer to a microphone.</p> \n<p>One option is the <a href=\"https://amzn.to/348Kivf\"><span>Fifine wired clip-on lavaliere</span></a> USB microphone. Simply plug the connector into any available USB port on your computer, and then change the audio selection in your webinar software or livestreaming app to the new audio source.</p> \n<p>Another high-quality option would be a USB microphone typically used for recording podcasts.</p> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3276K55\"><span>Audio-Technica ATR-2100X</span></a>, the <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2DXjeEJ\"><span>Fifine PC Microphone</span></a>, and the <a href=\"https://www.bhphotovideo.com/c/product/1057722-REG/rode_rodntusb_versatile_usb_condenser_microphone.html\"><span>Rode NT USB</span></a> microphones are all examples of podcasting-style mics that connect quickly to your computer and will skyrocket the quality of your audio.</p> \n<p>Note that although these microphones all come with small desktop stands, the best approach is to mount them to an articulating <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2YfwEmb\"><span>boom arm</span></a> that clamps to the edge of your desk. That will prevent the mic stand from transmitting any thumps and bumps created by your hands or elbows tapping your desk surface.</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">3. Tripods</h3> \n<p>Shaky video can be incredibly distracting and frustrating when someone is watching a livestream.</p> \n<p>Fortunately, there are lots of options to help you have a steady shot. If you already have a video or camera tripod and will be livestreaming from a smartphone, you can simply attach a smartphone mount.</p> \n<p>My favorites are the <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3gawUJs\"><span>Square Jellyfish</span></a> metal smartphone mount, or the <a href=\"https://www.arkon.com/product/RVRM1420-phone-tripod-mount.html\"><span>Arkon Road-Vise</span></a> heavy duty smartphone mount.If you don't have a tripod, one place to begin is with a mini-tripod that sits on a desk and has an extendable middle column.</p> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2EcPK5i\"><span>Benro BK-15</span></a>, when placed on a desk, will extend to the equivalent of full standing height for standup presentations or interviews.</p> \n<p>The advantage to a small tripod like this is that you can easily move it from room to room, walk with it while you talk, or throw it in your messenger bag so you're always prepared to livestream.</p> \n<p>For other uses, you might need a floorstanding tripod. The least expensive option is to buy a basic tripod like this <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2Q1Gio0\"><span>Endurax</span></a> aluminum tripod. It extends to 66 inches.</p> \n<p>Tripods in this price range often have a plastic pan/tilt assembly, which is fine if your camera will be locked down and not moved, but often doesn't allow for smooth camera movement.</p> \n<p>If you'll be panning and tilting and following the action during your livestream, go for a more expensive tripod that has a fluid head.</p> \n<p>A fluid head mechanism gives very smooth camera movements which look professional. One of my personal favorites is the <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3kVSO6B\"><span>Manfrotto Be Free</span></a> aluminum Lever Lock video tripod. It is only 16\" long when folded for transport.</p> \n<p>And for livestreaming on the go, there's nothing like a 3-axis electric smartphone gimbal. A gimbal holds your smartphone level and steady while you walk, giving you silky-smooth Steadicam-like results.</p> \n<p>I use the <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3h9moU3\"><span>Benro 3XS</span></a> gimbal, and one of the main reasons I love it is because it does not block the Lightning port on a smartphone like many gimbals do — that's important if you want to connect a microphone to the port do to a walk-and-talk narration during your livestream.</p> \n<p>A single push of a button rotates the phone from horizontal to vertical, and the mounting arm also folds for compact storage.</p> \n<p>New equipment is constantly coming out for smartphone video shooting and livestreaming, allowing you to ensure that your video will be wonderfully watchable.</p> \n<h3 style=\"font-weight: normal;\">On-Camera Confidence</h3> \n<p>Assuming you have selected your platform, have a smartphone mic, LED light and tripod, it's time to curate your confidence so you come across well on video. Keep in mind the following tips:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>No, you don't look weird or sound weird on video, so stop judging yourself!</li> \n <li>We usually need to ramp up our energy a bit for video. If it helps, before you go live play a favorite song from your playlist that gets you pumped up. Dance around like a crazy person for a couple of minutes. Anything to get the blood moving and get a dose of energy!</li> \n <li>Remember, like I told you earlier, it's not about you. Focus on the people you're helping.</li> \n <li>If you're livestreaming from a laptop, do whatever you need to do to get the webcam lens at eye level. That may require propping your laptop up on a box or a stack of books if you're using the unit's internal webcam.</li> \n <li>Be sure to smile (as appropriate). You want to appear open, approachable, and authentic.</li> \n <li>If you normally gesture wildly as you talk, reel it in so your movements are appropriate for a tighter webcam image.</li> \n <li>If you're in charge of the livestream and are primarily the one presenting information, do whatever you can to keep people engaged. Ask questions and tell viewers to put their answers in the chat. You can also \"flag\" important points, by saying things like: \"If you're multi-tasking right now, come back to me because I'm about to give you some really important information.\"</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Remember, livestreaming is a mix of using your best presentation skills and some smart tech to make sure that you're communicating clearly and effectively.</p> \n<p>It is also a skill that you can develop over time. If you're looking for more tips related to livestreaming, take a look at our <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-live-stream-checklist\">checklist for getting started with your first livestream</a>.&nbsp;</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Flivestream-from-home&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 23 Sep 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"a1c1c5df6e14d556cb1506a98b79c197","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Kerry Shearer","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Flivestream-from-home&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn86@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-51-411_942411e7f5ffabc5.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389709},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"How to Write a Blog Post Outline: A Simple Formula to Follow","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-write-blog-post-outline","description":"<p>What makes a blog post bad?</p> \n<p>There are lots of reasons a blog post could be less-than-perfect. Poor formatting. Poor grammar. Poor word choice. Poor shareability.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>The most pervasive problem? <strong>Poor flow.&nbsp;</strong>The post jumps from one idea to the next to the next and then circles around again for a split second to the first idea, then back to the fourth, and so on. Or the post reads like a stream of consciousness -- but it wasn't a stylistic choice.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Luckily, you have a simple solution.&nbsp;Before diving headfirst into writing your post, you can create an outline.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>I'm not talking about jotting down a few quick bullet points -- even experienced writers can go astray with just a few talking points. I'm talking a fully fleshed-out outline with enough details that make it virtually impossible for your writing to go off the deep end. And it's pretty easy to do.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Below is my method for outlining posts and organizing my thoughts. You may prefer to switch up some of the steps depending on your writing style, but your end goal should always be to get an outline detailed enough that its result is a cohesive, logical piece. Here's one way you can do that.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>1. Nail your working title.</h3> \n<p>This is the most important step of this entire process. You want to have a clear understanding of what you're going to write before you start outlining.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>My colleague Corey wrote an awesome post about how to pick a great working title. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-choose-solid-topic-next-blog-post-ht\">Go read it</a>, now. I won't go too much into the weeds here (that's why you should read her post), but a great working title is specific. It's \"How to Use Images to Generate Leads on Twitter,\" not \" Twitter lead generation.\"</p> \n<p>Spend time getting your working title to something specific and easy to tackle in a blog post format -- but don't waste time getting nitpicky. You can refine your title later. The goal here is to have a title that gives you a very clear idea of what the whole piece is about. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/a-simple-formula-for-writing-kick-ass-titles-ht\">You can make it sound catchy later</a>. &nbsp;</p> \n<h3>2. Write down as many distinct takeaways from the article as you can.</h3> \n<p>Next, you get to brain dump. Write down all the things you want your readers to get out of the article. These won't always be the main sections of your article -- it's just all the things you want your readers to know by the end of reading your post.</p> \n<p>This is the only time in the whole process you're not worried about organization -- just let your ideas flow naturally. You need to get out all of your wild and crazy ideas now so they won't muck up your post later in the process.</p> \n<p>Let's use the previous example to show you what I mean. If my working title was \"How to Use Images to Generate Leads on Twitter,\" I'd probably want readers to know:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>What sets a good image apart from a bad one on Twitter</li> \n <li>Where they can find images to use legally&nbsp;</li> \n <li>How they can create images on their own</li> \n <li>What sizes they need to make images</li> \n <li>How often they should tweet images</li> \n <li>How to actually upload an image to Twitter</li> \n <li>How they can generate a lead on Twitter</li> \n <li>How long their tweet should be with the image in it</li> \n <li>What results they should expect to get&nbsp;</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Notice how these are really unfiltered and all over the place. That's okay. We'll wrangle it all in in the next step.</p> \n<h3>3. Break up those takeaways into larger sections.</h3> \n<p>Now, we'll take that jumble of ideas and place them into overarching sections. Think of it like sorting laundry -- each thought belongs to a different pile. From your brainstorm, you should come up with a few big themes.&nbsp;Sometimes, one of your brainstorming bullets will be a theme in itself, but usually several bullets will fall under one overarching theme. You may also realize that there's a theme that you may not have any bullets for, but the post definitely calls for it.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Lots of people recommend sticking to 3-4 larger sections, but it really depends on what type of post you're writing. If you're writing something that's long and comprehensive, you might need more. If it's a quick post, fewer sections would be ideal. But if you need a benchmark, 3-4 sections are fine.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>So if we're writing that post about generating leads on Twitter using images, we'd bucket my ideas into the following buckets:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Intro</li> \n <li>Crafting a Twitter Image Lead Gen Strategy \n  <ul> \n   <li>How they can generate a lead on Twitter</li> \n   <li>How often they should tweet images</li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li>How to Create the Perfect Lead Gen Tweet \n  <ul> \n   <li>How long their tweet should be with the image in it</li> \n   <li>How to actually upload an image to Twitter</li> \n   <li>What sizes they need to make images</li> \n   <li>How they can create images on their own</li> \n   <li>Where they can find images to use legally&nbsp;</li> \n   <li>What sets a good image apart from a bad one on Twitter</li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li>Measuring Your Strategy's Success \n  <ul> \n   <li>What results they should expect to get</li> \n  </ul> </li> \n</ol> \n<h3><strong>4. Add more takeaways to some sections.&nbsp;</strong></h3> \n<p>At this point, you should have a pretty weird looking outline. Mine is. Some sections have lots of little bullet points, others have only a few, and others have nothing.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Now's the time to fill in the holes. <strong>What did you miss in your initial brainstorm?</strong> Thinking about what's missing is always hard, but it will help improve your final post significantly.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Don't forget to beef up your intro here, too. Have a great point you think would set the stage for the article? Add a little reminder below that section so you don't forget it.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Below shows how my outline's evolved. I italicized all the things I added, and the outline is becoming closer and closer to being a post:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Intro \n  <ul> \n   <li><em>Images work really well on Twitter (find study)</em></li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li>Crafting a Twitter Image Lead Gen Strategy \n  <ul> \n   <li>How they can generate a lead on Twitter</li> \n   <li>How often they should tweet images</li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li>How to Create the Perfect Lead Gen Tweet \n  <ul> \n   <li>How long their tweet should be with the image in it</li> \n   <li>How to actually upload an image to Twitter</li> \n   <li>What sizes they need to make images</li> \n   <li>How they can create images on their own</li> \n   <li>Where they can find images to use legally&nbsp;</li> \n   <li>What sets a good image apart from a bad one on Twitter</li> \n   <li><em>Should you tag people in images</em></li> \n   <li><em>Should you use photo collages</em></li> \n   <li><em>What colors you should use to stand out</em></li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li>Measuring Your Strategy's Success \n  <ul> \n   <li>What results they should expect to get</li> \n   <li><em>Which metrics to look at</em></li> \n   <li><em>How to find them in your analytics</em></li> \n   <li><em>How to adjust the above to get better results</em></li> \n  </ul> </li> \n</ol> \n<p>Essentially, you're re-doing the second step, but in a more controlled, organized manner.</p> \n<h3>5. Revise, remove, and reorganize details in each section.</h3> \n<p>Now comes the fun part: editing your outline. You've already done the hard part of actually thinking of your ideas. Now, you're tightening up your outline to include only the most relevant information, revising the sub-bullets to actually make sense, and reorganizing the sub-bullets to tell the most logical story.</p> \n<p>First, let me show you what I'd cut -- shown in bold.&nbsp;</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Intro \n  <ul> \n   <li>Images work really well on Twitter (find study)</li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li>Crafting a Twitter Image Lead Gen Strategy \n  <ul> \n   <li>How to generate a lead on Twitter</li> \n   <li>How often they should tweet images</li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li>How to Create the Perfect Lead Gen Tweet \n  <ul> \n   <li>How long their tweet should be with the image in it</li> \n   <li><strong>How to actually upload an image to Twitter (This is a pretty basic step that someone would already know if they're reading this post.)</strong></li> \n   <li>What sizes they need to make images</li> \n   <li>How they can create images on their own</li> \n   <li>Where they can find images to use legally&nbsp;</li> \n   <li>What sets a good image apart from a bad one on Twitter</li> \n   <li>Should you tag people in images</li> \n   <li>Should you use photo collages</li> \n   <li><strong>What colors you should use to stand out (Don't believe there's hard data on this, just speculation. Let's cut it.)</strong></li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li>Measuring Your Strategy's Success \n  <ul> \n   <li><strong>What results they should expect to get (The study in the first part should cover this bullet point.)</strong></li> \n   <li>Which metrics to look at</li> \n   <li>How to find them in your analytics</li> \n   <li>How to adjust the above to get better results</li> \n  </ul> </li> \n</ol> \n<p>I cut things usually because the sub-bullet didn't add value to the post or the reader would already know it. That's a pretty good benchmark to remember if you're not sure whether to cut something.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Next, we'll reorganize the remainder of the sub-bullets and rework them to sound like actual takeaways. We'll also turn some of the sub-bullets into sub-sub-bullets. Here's what this outline looks like now:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Intro \n  <ul> \n   <li>Images tend to work really well on Twitter (find study)</li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li>Crafting a Twitter Image Lead Gen Strategy \n  <ul> \n   <li>How to generate a lead on Twitter</li> \n   <li>How lead generation fits in with the rest of your Twitter strategy</li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li>How to Create the Perfect Lead Gen Tweet \n  <ul> \n   <li>How to choose the right image \n    <ul> \n     <li>Creating it on your own&nbsp;</li> \n     <li>Finding images to use legally</li> \n    </ul> </li> \n   <li>Optimizing the image for Twitter \n    <ul> \n     <li>Sizing images for Twitter</li> \n     <li>Tagging people in images</li> \n     <li>Using Photo Collages</li> \n    </ul> </li> \n   <li>Optimizing the rest of your tweet \n    <ul> \n     <li>How long the tweet should be with the image in</li> \n    </ul> </li> \n  </ul> </li> \n <li>Measuring Your Strategy's Success<strong><br></strong> \n  <ul> \n   <li>Which metrics to look at</li> \n   <li>How to find them in your analytics</li> \n   <li>How to adjust your strategy to get better results</li> \n  </ul> </li> \n</ol> \n<p>Ta-da! A much more comprehensive outline that makes your post easy to write.</p> \n<h3>6. Include links to your examples and/or data.</h3> \n<p>This is purely a time-saving trick. After you've fully fleshed out and then trimmed your outline, you should look for examples and data to support these claims. Once you find a source to support your arguments, just add them as a note underneath the section -- that way, when you go to write it, it's all organized for you. &nbsp;</p> \n<h3>7. If any details come to you that you don't want to forget, add them in.&nbsp;</h3> \n<p>Last, but certainly not least, spruce up the outline with anything you don't want to forget while writing. Maybe you're writing the post right away -- or maybe you won't have time to actually start for a few more days. Regardless, having these details in your outline will make sure you're not missing a thing. I do this often if I think of a terrible pun or pop culture reference while outlining ... and trust me, that's something I definitely wouldn't want to forget. ;)</p> \n<p>Here's my final outline:&nbsp;</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>Blog Post Outline Example</h2> \n <ol> \n  <li>Intro \n   <ul> \n    <li>Images tend to work really well on Twitter</li> \n   </ul> </li> \n  <li>Crafting a Twitter Image Lead Gen Strategy \n   <ul> \n    <li>How to generate a lead on Twitter</li> \n    <li>How lead generation fits in with the rest of your Twitter strategy \n     <ul> \n      <li>Reference Anchorman line: \"Come and see how good I look.\"</li> \n     </ul> </li> \n   </ul> </li> \n  <li>How to Create the Perfect Lead Gen Tweet \n   <ul> \n    <li>How to choose the right image \n     <ul> \n      <li>Creating it on your own&nbsp;</li> \n      <li>Finding images to use legally</li> \n     </ul> </li> \n    <li>Optimizing the image for Twitter \n     <ul> \n      <li>Sizing images for Twitter</li> \n      <li>Tagging people in images</li> \n      <li>Using Photo Collages</li> \n     </ul> </li> \n    <li>Optimizing the rest of your tweet \n     <ul> \n      <li>How long the tweet should be with the image in</li> \n     </ul> </li> \n   </ul> </li> \n  <li>Measuring Your Strategy's Success \n   <ul> \n    <li>Which metrics to look at</li> \n    <li>How to find them in your analytics</li> \n    <li>How to adjust your strategy to get better results</li> \n   </ul> </li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<p>And that's it! Feel free to take that methodology and apply it to other types of posts. Once you have a solid outline, writing the actual post should be a breeze. It's even easier if you work from a template.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><em></em></p> \n<p><em></em></p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in May 2014 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-write-blog-post-outline&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 05 Oct 2020 12:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"cb949ab0af385c26fc42e252bec278a1","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"gsoskey@hubspot.com (Ginny Mineo)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-write-blog-post-outline&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn7@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-50-760_be6df9fe271f6c9a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389709},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"The 11 Best ClickFunnels Alternatives & Competitors in 2020","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/clickfunnels-alternatives","description":"<p>The marketing technology landscape is <a href=\"https://chiefmartec.com/2020/04/marketing-technology-landscape-2020-martech-5000/\">expanding rapidly</a>, and it's becoming cheaper and easier for marketers to run powerful campaigns on their website or other channels.</p>  \n<p>So, if you want to build a powerful inbound marketing engine, what do you need?</p> \n<p>Well, first off, you <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-make-a-website\">need a website</a>.</p> \n<p>It also helps to have dedicated landing pages, sales pages, splash pages, and lead capture forms. Additionally, you'll want messaging tools like email, push, or SMS to communicate with your leads and prospects.</p> \n<p>All of these tools are invaluable in helping you build powerful inbound marketing systems and predictable revenue.</p> \n<p>To help consolidate all of these marketing elements in one place and test new campaigns, there are powerful suites like ClickFunnels that you might try out — but ClickFunnels isn't for everyone.</p> \n<p>Here, we'll explore 11 alternatives to ClickFunnels that will help you create high-quality campaigns and drive more revenue in 2020 and beyond.</p> \n<p>But first — what is ClickFunnels?</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2><strong>What is ClickFunnels?</strong></h2> \n<p>At its core, <a href=\"https://www.clickfunnels.com/\">ClickFunnels</a> is a company that tries to help you with all of the above. It's a full suite sales and website funnel building tool, primarily predicated on landing pages and basic marketing automation functionality. The magic is that you can set up pretty clever workflows and funnels without the help of developers.</p> \n<p>This means you can move faster, test new campaigns rapidly, and therefore, drive more revenue.</p> \n<p>Some of ClickFunnels features include:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Landing pages</li> \n <ul> \n  <li>Sales pages</li> \n  <li>Squeeze pages</li> \n  <li>Webinar pages (you need to integrate with a 3rd party tool)</li> \n  <li>A/B testing functionality</li> \n </ul> \n <li>Email and SMS</li> \n <ul> \n  <li>Pre-designed templates</li> \n  <li>Automation and sequences</li> \n  <li>A/B testing</li> \n </ul> \n <li>Shopping cart</li> \n <ul> \n  <li>Full integrated shopping cart platform to sell your products.</li> \n </ul> \n <li>Lead capture forms</li> \n <li>Analytics</li> \n <ul> \n  <li>Easily see your revenue, conversions, etc.</li> \n </ul> \n <li>Contacts database</li> \n <ul> \n  <li>Lists and segmentation</li> \n  <li>Personalization</li> \n </ul> \n</ul> \n<p>ClickFunnels also has a raving fan community that loves the company. This makes it easy to find help when you need it.</p> \n<p>However, not everyone is a fan and the tool isn't for everyone.</p> \n<p>While it has many features, sometimes you don't want or need every one of them, or you'd like to use a more powerful tool to accomplish something specific (such as email or landing pages). Additionally, there are often stronger point solutions for a given functionality.</p> \n<p>Whatever your reason for seeking an alternative to this popular funnel and landing page building tool, this list should help you with your shopping.</p> \n<h3>1. HubSpot Marketing Hub</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/free\">HubSpot's Marketing Hub</a> includes a myriad of free tools that help marketers do everything from managing your paid ads to collecting leads, building landing pages, and setting up email marketing campaigns.</p> \n<p>The coolest part is all of your contacts data is stored in the <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/crm\">free CRM</a>, so you can easily access insights and use CRM data to improve and personalize your campaigns.</p> \n<p>As an alternative to ClickFunnels, the all-in-one aspect of HubSpot is a big selling point.</p> \n<p>Specifically with regards to the landing pages functionality, you're able to build out beautiful pages — sales pages, squeeze pages, downsell pages, upsells, webinar funnels, etc. — using the simple drag-and-drop editor. There are several landing page templates available to get you started, as well.</p> \n<p><strong>Pros</strong></p> \n<ul> \n <li>Easy drag-and-drop builder</li> \n <li>All-in-one platform that plugs into a free CRM</li> \n <li>Get started for free</li> \n <li>A/B testing functionality embedded in most features</li> \n <li>Excellent customer support and documentation</li> \n <li>Embed a calendar to book meetings on your landing page for free</li> \n</ul> \n<p><strong>Cons</strong></p> \n<ul> \n <li>Usage limits on free plan</li> \n <li>No custom modules for free</li> \n <li>Not as large a library of templates as other alternatives</li> \n</ul> \n<p><strong>Pricing</strong>: Starts free and then Starter Tier pricing begins at $50/month.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%2011%20Best%20ClickFunnels%20Alternatives%20%26%20Competitors%20in%202020.gif\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<h3>2. Leadpages</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.leadpages.com/\">Leadpages</a> is a strong contender in the marketing technology world, and it's an especially popular <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-landing-page-builder\">landing page builder</a>.</p> \n<p>Essentially, it allows you to build no code (or low code) websites and landing pages. It also includes handy tools for lead capture and funnel building, such as popup forms, alert bars, and an <a href=\"https://www.leadpages.com/integrations\">impressive list of native integrations</a>.</p> \n<p>Previously, Leadpages had also owned a marketing automation platform, Drip, though they have since <a href=\"https://www.bizjournals.com/twincities/news/2020/03/02/leadpages-is-bought-by-canadian-tech-company.html\">diverged in Leadpages' recent acquisition</a>. Still, you can easily integrate Drip with Leadpages (or basically whatever <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/marketing-automation-software-tools\">marketing automation tool</a> you use).</p> \n<p><strong>Pros</strong></p> \n<ul> \n <li>Beautiful drag-and-drop page editors</li> \n <li>Ability to build a full website or landing pages</li> \n <li>Great lead capture tools</li> \n <li>Affordable pricing</li> \n</ul> \n<p><strong>Cons</strong></p> \n<ul> \n <li>No email or campaigns functionality</li> \n <li>Lack of robust native analytics reports</li> \n <li>Not the most customizable/complex feature set</li> \n</ul> \n<p><strong>Pricing</strong>: Starts at $25/month</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/The%2011%20Best%20ClickFunnels%20Alternatives%20%26%20Competitors%20in%202020-3.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<h3>3. Unbounce</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://unbounce.com/\">Unbounce</a> is one of my favorite landing page builders.</p> \n<p>Their landing page editor is easy to use, but the product is also one of the most powerful and flexible I've tried out. You'll be just as satisfied with the tool whether you're a marketer who can't code, a marketer who can code, a designer, or a developer. It's a great product for landing pages at scale.</p> \n<p>While landing pages are their bread and butter, they also have some truly great lead capture tools, as well.
