.gif?width=200&name=Everything%20You%20Need%20to%20Know%20about%20Instagram%20Reels,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Academys%20Social%20Media%20Professor-1.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn40@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-48-956_f07474bfccd9c87e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Everything%20You%20Need%20to%20Know%20about%20Instagram%20Reels,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Academys%20Social%20Media%20Professor-3.png?width=200&name=Everything%20You%20Need%20to%20Know%20about%20Instagram%20Reels,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Academys%20Social%20Media%20Professor-3.png":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Everything%20You%20Need%20to%20Know%20about%20Instagram%20Reels,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Academys%20Social%20Media%20Professor-1.png?width=200&name=Everything%20You%20Need%20to%20Know%20about%20Instagram%20Reels,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Academys%20Social%20Media%20Professor-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn99@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-49-296_ad0137934f00ff96.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Everything%20You%20Need%20to%20Know%20about%20Instagram%20Reels,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Academys%20Social%20Media%20Professor-Sep-16-2020-05-57-05-93-PM.png?width=200&name=Everything%20You%20Need%20to%20Know%20about%20Instagram%20Reels,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Academys%20Social%20Media%20Professor-Sep-16-2020-05-57-05-93-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn92@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-50-090_7564e493b7a239d9.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Finstagram-reels&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn91@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-49-233_5f07eedcdb0916ea.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389713},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"The Beginner's Guide to Reminder Advertising","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/reminder-advertising","description":"<p>When I go to bed every night, I have to set about five alarms for the morning.</p> \n<p>I'm just the type of person that needs a lot of reminders to wake up on time.</p> \n<p>In a similar vein, marketers use reminder advertising to stay top-of-mind with potential customers.</p>  \n<p>And it makes sense.</p> \n<p>In the world of sales, <a href=\"https://spotio.com/blog/sales-statistics/\">80% of sales require 5 follow-up calls after a meeting.</a> For marketers, it's no different.</p> \n<p>Essentially, you have to nurture and continuously remind your audience who you are to convert leads.</p> \n<p>In fact, <a href=\"https://spotio.com/blog/sales-statistics/\">companies excelling at lead nurturing generate 50% more sales-ready leads at 33% lower cost</a>.</p> \n<p>Below, let's learn more about reminder advertising and see what it looks like in action.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Reminder advertising is a paid method of marketing that targets people in your audience who are in the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/what-is-the-buyers-journey\">consideration stage of the buying process</a>.</p> \n<p>During this stage, users are reviewing their options. They're aware of their problem and the companies that might be able to help them. Now, they're trying to figure out which solution is the right way to go.</p> \n<p>In this stage, it's important to stay at the forefront of your audience's mind. That's where reminder advertising comes in.</p> \n<p>Another way to use reminder advertising is if you own a retail or ecommerce store. With a reminder ad, you can inspire customers to buy more products from you.</p> \n<p>In this case, reminder advertising can help customers remember that they like your store and products.</p> \n<p>Additionally, you can use reminder advertising when you're at the end of the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/product-life-cycle\">product life cycle</a>. For example, if a product has launched and you're done with the growth phase, then you can use reminder advertising to keep people interested.</p> \n<p>At this point, you might've noticed that this type of advertising doesn't introduce a new product. Instead, these ads are targeted at customers who are already aware of your brand and the products you offer.</p> \n<p>Also, these types of ads won't contain a lot of information. Rather, they'll just reinforce key messages and brand awareness. For instance, while you might include brief testimonials, usually just the name of the brand and product with a visual is enough.</p> \n<p>The objective is to hopefully serve as a reminder for potential customers and increase demand for your product or service.</p> \n<p>So, what tactics can you use for reminder advertising? Let's take a look at a quick list below.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Retargeting:</strong> <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/retargeting-campaigns-beginner-guide\">Retargeting</a> is when users who were on your website or social media page start seeing ads for your company on other pages they visit online. The whole point of retargeting ads is to remind customers of a product or service they were looking at and didn't buy. Retargeting is essentially a targeted reminder ad.</li> \n <li><strong>Abandoned cart emails:</strong> If a potential customer is on your website, adds a product to their cart, but doesn't complete the purchase, you don't want to lose that sale. To get them to complete their purchase, you can send them an <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/ecommerce/shopping-cart-abandonment-reasons-solutions\">abandoned cart email</a> and remind them that they have items in their cart they may want to buy.</li> \n <li><strong>Email newsletters: </strong>An email newsletter is a great way to stay top-of-mind with your customers. If you're regularly sending them valuable information and perhaps including special offers, they'll be more likely to purchase from you.</li> \n <li><strong>Display ads: </strong>Display ads on <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-adwords-ppc\">Google</a> or <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/facebook-paid-ad-checklist\">Facebook</a> are another excellent option for reminder advertising. You can create a reminder ad that can help reinforce brand awareness.</li> \n <li><strong>Content:</strong> One of the best ways to keep your brand in your audience's mind is to produce content on your website and social media. If someone sees your posts on social media or on your blog, they'll have you in their mind when it's time to purchase.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Now that we know more about reminder advertising, let's look at some examples.</p> \n<h2>Reminder Advertising Examples</h2> \n<h3>1. Coca-Cola</h3> \n<p>Since Coca-Cola is an established brand, any ad that isn't aimed at a new product launch serves as a reminder ad.</p> \n<p>Take the ad below, for instance.</p> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; max-width: 560px; max-height: 315px; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.25%; margin: 0;\">\n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/8mKFF5K4aUI\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n </div> \n</div> \n<p>In this ad, Coca-Cola isn't introducing any new product. All they're doing is trying to remind you that their brand exists and you might be thirsty.</p> \n<p>This is a great reminder ad because you're probably not thinking about Coke all day. By seeing these types of messages, you're more likely to purchase a Coke the next time you can.</p> \n<h3>2. Zillow</h3> \n<p>Zillow is another brand that benefits from reminder advertising. With Zillow, you can look to buy or rent a new apartment, condo, or house. However, people don't make these big purchases all the time. Instead, Zillow needs to rely on reminder ads so their audience chooses Zillow when it's time to buy a new house.</p> \n<p>In the ad below, even the tagline reads, \"When you're ready for a change, we're ready to help.\"</p> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; max-width: 560px; max-height: 315px; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.25%; margin: 0;\">\n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/_-GI13YihME\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n </div> \n</div> \n<p>This is a great example of a reminder ad. This shows that Zillow isn't trying to show you anything new, but rather remind you that they'll be there when you're ready to buy a house.</p> \n<h3>3. McDonald's</h3> \n<p>Again, McDonald's is a globally recognized brand. If they aren't launching a new product, almost any ad you see from them is a reminder ad.</p> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; max-width: 560px; max-height: 315px; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.25%; margin: 0;\">\n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/Yz2Gi8nHdgo\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n </div> \n</div> \n<p>In this McDonald's ad, the company isn't trying to launch any new menu items or tell you about something new.</p> \n<p>Instead, they're just reminding you that the company exists. And hopefully, they made you hungry enough to go buy some French fries.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, reminder ads are a great way to stay top-of-mind with your audience. Since most people need to come in contact with your brand several times before they purchase, reminder ads are an excellent way to convert leads.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Freminder-advertising&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 06 Oct 2020 08:30:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"a461a7e5c20a4f2467053179d3c1aebc","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Rebecca Riserbato","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Freminder-advertising&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389708},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"How to Create Facebook Video Ads, According to HubSpot Advertisers","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-create-facebook-video-ads","description":"<p>During the last few years, Facebook has emerged as a real contender for the online video platform throne. In wake of several new video features being introduced and a <a href=\"http://www.entrepreneur.com/article/245818\">heavy video focus</a> from Mark Zuckerberg, the social media giant has <a href=\"https://www.wordstream.com/blog/ws/2017/03/08/video-marketing-statistics#:~:text=Over%20500%20million%20(half%20a,every%20day%20(via%20Forbes).\">over 500 million people watching Facebook videos every day</a>.</p> \n<p>Facebook's increased focus on video isn't only because users like to watch it (although they clearly do) -- it's also because more <a href=\"http://fortune.com/2015/06/03/facebook-video-traffic/\">marketers are shifting their budgets</a> from TV to mobile video. The allure for advertisers lies in Facebook's hyper-surgical targeting possibilities and <a href=\"http://insights.fb.com/2015/04/02/measuring-facebook-video/\">the results Facebook videos can deliver</a>.</p> \n<p>If you're one of those marketers who wants to dive into advertising with Facebook videos -- but isn't sure where to start -- keep on reading.</p> \n<p>Below we'll review the types of Facebook video ads and how to create an effective ad with tips from HubSpot advertisers. Then, we'll look at some examples to put it all into practice.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>1. Slideshow</h3> \n<p>You might think that recording and creating a video for a Facebook ad is a daunting task. However, with slideshow ads, all you need to do is create a video using only photos and text.</p> \n<p>Whether you use your own photos or stock images, slideshow ads are easier to put together and don't take too much time.</p> \n<p>This is a great way to engage audiences without spending time and money on creating a video.</p> \n<h3>2. Stories</h3> \n<p>If you've created a video for your Facebook feed, you can repurpose the same content as an ad that will play in Facebook stories.</p> \n<p>Story ads are a great way to reach your audience where they're at.</p> \n<h3>3. In-stream</h3> \n<p>In-stream ads are the closest way to replicate traditional TV advertising on social media.</p> \n<p>For this type of ad, you'll create a video that will play when people are watching Facebook videos. If you've ever watched native content that was interrupted by an ad, that was an in-stream ad.</p> \n<p>Now that you know the type of ads, let's discuss how you'll create and launch an effective Facebook video.</p> \n<h3>1. Set your objectives.</h3> \n<p>The first step of any marketing effort is to decide what you want to accomplish. In your Facebook video ad campaign, are you trying to increase brand awareness or drive conversions? Choosing what you're going to prioritize should affect what kind of video you should create and how you should distribute it.</p> \n<p>So choose your KPIs and plan accordingly. Below I've organized some common KPIs around three categories: engagement, audience reach, and brand lift.</p> \n<h4>Conversion KPIs</h4> \n<ul> \n <li>Clicks</li> \n <li>CTR</li> \n <li>Revenue Generated</li> \n</ul> \n<h4>Engagement KPIs</h4> \n<ul> \n <li>Engagement (Share, likes, comments)</li> \n <li>Audience Retention (How much of your video the viewer watch)</li> \n <li>Relevance Score (How relevant your video is to your audience)</li> \n</ul> \n<h4>Audience Reach KPIs</h4> \n<ul> \n <li>Impressions (How many people viewed your video)</li> \n <li>Percent of In-Target Audience (What percent of your target audience you reached)</li> \n <li>Brand awareness</li> \n</ul> \n<p>By choosing which metrics you want to track and what goals you're trying to reach before you actually start creating your video, you're more likely to be successful.</p> \n<h3>2. Choose your target audience.</h3> \n<p>Who are you targeting with your video ad campaign? Yankee fans between 30-40? Newlyweds who shop at Costco? Millennials who play Minecraft? Or the people who already like your Facebook page?</p> \n<p>The true power of video advertising on Facebook is the targeting capabilities. Forget spray and pray -- you need a hyper-targeted group of people for your ad's audience. Narrowing your target group will give you less overall views, but because you're reaching only the people who are relevant, your CTR is likely to be higher.</p> \n<p>Leticia De Bortoli, a principal video editor at HubSpot, says, \"Think like a user. People don't go on Facebook to watch ads, and most people actually want to avoid ads at all cost. With that in mind you have to invest in your ad. Take the time to create something very compelling that can act as a thumbstopper, otherwise people will scroll right by your ad.\"</p> \n<p>She adds, \"Take the time to learn about your target audience. You might find specific interests and behaviors that can inform your creative and help you develop more compelling ads.\"</p> \n<p>Which targeting options you should have is dependent on what target audience you have, but here are some key targeting options for an effective Facebook video ad campaign:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Gender</li> \n <li>Age</li> \n <li>Location</li> \n <li>Interests</li> \n <li>Behavior</li> \n <li>Relationship status</li> \n <li>Work (Job title, Office type)</li> \n <li>Financial income</li> \n <li>Home (Type, Value, Ownership)</li> \n <li>Market segment (Ethnicity, Generation, Household composition)</li> \n <li>Parents (Age of children)</li> \n <li>Life events</li> \n <li>Device owner</li> \n</ul> \n<p>If you go to the \"Audience Insights\" page in the Facebook Ads Manager, you can play around with the different options to define your target audience. Hopefully you have a pretty good idea about who your target market is based on <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33491/everything-marketers-need-to-research-create-detailed-buyer-personas-template.aspx\">your buyer persona research</a>, but finding the best audience for your video ads might require a few attempts.</p> \n<p>This is a prime opportunity to really confirm your optimal target audience. What target audience has the highest CTR? What target audience has the highest LTV? Use the data you get from your campaigns to evaluate both your Facebook campaigns <em>and</em> your larger marketing strategy.</p> \n<h3>3. Plan the video creative.</h3> \n<p>With your KPIs and target audience decided, you know what you want to accomplish and the people you want to reach. Now it's time to plan your video creation. A good, solid plan for your video will increase the chances of it coming out looking good. Here are the things you should decide before you even touch a camera.</p> \n<ul> \n <li>What is your topic? For example, if you're in the boat paint business, you might choose a topic like \"How to buy the right environmentally friendly boat paint.\"</li> \n <li>What will your key takeaway be? What message do you want to convey to your audience? For example, \"Our metal-free bottom paint lasts longer than normal paints and is more environmentally friendly.\"</li> \n <li>What is your CTA? For example, \"Use this code to buy our metal-free bottom paint for 20% before August 1st!\"</li> \n</ul> \n<p>De Bortoli says to keep in mind that less is more.</p> \n<p>\"In social media advertising, one second is a lot of time. Have one clear message and one clear story that will center all the other elements of your ad,\" she says. \"Focus on delivering that central message in a very interesting way, instead of having multiple messages fighting to coexist in a few seconds.\"</p> \n<p>Megan McCall, a motion designer at HubSpot, agrees.</p> \n<p>\"Make the first 5 seconds the most compelling part of the ad. It's tempting to leave the pay-off of the ad until the end, but it's likely a user will catch your ad while scrolling, so you want to appeal to them early and make it clear what your company is about,\" McCall adds. \"That's why we often try to put the UI early, along with a mention of our brand and a clear value prop.\"</p> \n<p>Keeping all this in mind, it's time to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-write-a-video-script-ht\">write the script</a>. Write up what you want to say, how you're going to say it (if you're doing a voice-over), and what graphics and text you need. Make sure that your message is on point and not too long. It should sound natural when read aloud. And try to keep what you say to a minimum -- when it comes to online video ads, \"less is more\" is a better approach.</p> \n<h3>4. Create the video.</h3> \n<p>This is where things can get a little bit complicated. What kind of gear you need all depends on your experience level and how often you're planning to do videos in the future.</p> \n<p>For most beginners, a good smartphone and a microphone could be enough to get some decent photos or videos. But if you are devoting more resources to video, you might consider trading up to some higher quality gear and thinking about lighting and studio set up.</p> \n<p>McCall says, \"When you create a video, include your logo or a mention of your brand in the first 5 seconds. Monday.com does a great job at this <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8ELpzmNeS4M&amp;list=PLutcJfNEwNkTrn8024aA5-g8sx894xUTW&amp;index=6\">here.</a>\"</p> \n<p>Additionally, she says to consider adding burned in captions for viewers who don't use sound.</p> \n<p>Rex Gelb, the director of acquisition analytics and paid advertising at HubSpot, says, \"The best video ads on Facebook tend to grab people's attention in the first couple of seconds. People are busy and scrolling through their feeds fast -- you have about 2 seconds and 2 inches of real estate to engage them before they fly by. Make it count!\"</p> \n<p>If you are looking to easily create videos from the product photos you've already got, check out <a href=\"http://blog.shakr.com/how-to-take-product-photos-that-rock/\">this guide</a>. And if you're looking to up your video game, check out Wistia's <a href=\"http://wistia.com/library/diy-office-video-studio\">DIY office studio guide</a>.</p> \n<h3>5. Set up your Facebook campaign.</h3> \n<p>Once you've created your video, it's time to set up your Facebook video ad campaign. Setting up a video ad on Facebook is relatively straight-forward process, especially if you're used to setting up normal Facebook ads. Facebook does a good job of walking you through the process of setting up the campaign through either the Ad Manager or the Power Editor. Here are the basic steps you need to go through:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Start creating an ad and choose \"Video Views\" as your objective. You could choose to \"Boost Post\" as well, but choosing \"Video Views\" will give you a lower cost per view.</li> \n <li>Choose your audience. Like I mentioned before, you have a wealth of targeting options at your disposal. You can also <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/retargeting-campaigns-beginner-guide\">retarget previous website visitors</a> or use any of the Custom Audiences you might already have, like your email list or app users. You can also target the fans of your Facebook page.</li> \n <li>Set budget and pricing. Choose how much you want to spend, over what time, and what you want to optimize your ad for.</li> \n <li>Upload your video. Be sure to choose your video thumbnail carefully -- it could affect your views.</li> \n <li>Edit your ad copy. Add the text copy and your CTA. Choose where you want your ad to be served, on web or mobile or both.</li> \n</ol> \n<h3>6. Track your campaign.</h3> \n<p>Here are a few ways to track the different metrics I mentioned earlier in the post.</p> \n<h4>Conversion KPIs</h4> \n<p>Use a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-are-utm-tracking-codes-ht\">URL with UTM codes</a> to track the traffic from the ad to your website. Your marketing software should make it easy for you to track incoming traffic and subsequent conversions, and compare your video campaign to other campaigns you've run.</p> \n<p>You can also use Facebook Conversion Pixels to see the long-tail effect of your video campaign. For example, if someone visits your site after watching an ad, leaves, and then comes back, that information would be shown in the conversions column of your Facebook ad analytics.</p> \n<h4>Engagement KPIs</h4> \n<p>Tracking your engagement KPIs is a relatively straightforward process. Just go into the Ads Manager, choose \"Campaigns,\" and click on your ad to see how it performed.</p> \n<h4>Audience Reach KPIs</h4> \n<p>Similar to engagement, audience reach is simple to track on Facebook. On the \"Campaign Report\" page, see how many people viewed your ad and what your Relevance Score is. The Relevance Score will help you evaluate if your target audience actually liked your video. If your Relevance Score is poor compared to scores for other ads shown to your audience, Facebook will limit the reach of your video. The better the video and the better the targeting, the better your Relevance Score will be.</p> \n<h3>7. Evaluate your campaign.</h3> \n<p>After your video campaign is over, it is time to take a step back and evaluate how successful your campaign was. Go back and check your KPIs and see if you hit your goals.</p> \n<h4>Conversion KPIs</h4> \n<p>How many conversions did you get from your video campaign? Did people who clicked through to your website bounce quickly, or did they convert on your content? Did retargeted visitors convert at a later stage?</p> \n<h4>Engagement KPIs</h4> \n<p>Did people who saw your video engage with it? How many shares, likes, and comments did you get? How many of those were from organic sharing?</p> \n<h4>Audience Reach KPIs</h4> \n<p>Did you plan on reaching 10,000 people with your video/budget, but only reached 7,000 people because your Relevance Score was too low? You might want to think about how good your video is and how well it is aligned with your audience's wants. A good idea is to keep track of your videos' performance in a spreadsheet -- <a href=\"http://www.socialmediaexaminer.com/analyze-social-media-with-excel/\">Social Media Examiner has a great template you can use.</a> That way, you can compare and evaluate your different campaigns, and figure out what kind of videos actually resonates with your audience.</p> \n<h3>8. Iterate.</h3> \n<p>After you've evaluated your video campaign's performance, it is time to do it again! Think about what went well and what you could improve. Is the video content you're putting out good enough? Is your targeting on point? When you have enough data from previous campaigns, you can easily compare them to see what works and what doesn't -- and then make changes on future ads.</p> \n<p>To really dive in deep, you might consider taking some lessons or classes on Facebook video ads, like the one <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/facebook-advertising-training\">HubSpot</a> has.</p> \n<h2>Examples of Compelling Facebook Video Ads</h2> \n<h3>1. Monday.com</h3> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; max-width: 560px; max-height: 315px; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.25%; margin: 0;\">\n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/8ELpzmNeS4M\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n </div> \n</div> \n<p>This is a great Facebook ad because it mentions the brand/logo in the first few seconds. As a user, you immediately know what you're getting.</p> \n<p>Additionally, the script is easy-to-understand. There are plenty of quick cuts, which makes it more interesting to watch.</p> \n<h3>2. Colgate</h3> \n<iframe style=\"border: none; overflow: hidden; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\" src=\"https://www.facebook.com/plugins/video.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2FColgate%2Fvideos%2F1109763475785392%2F&amp;show_text=0&amp;width=476\" width=\"476\" height=\"476\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe> \n<p>This is one of the best ads I've seen on Facebook. Colgate chose a very compelling topic, <em>\"What would you do with your Tooth Fairy money?\"</em> In the first few seconds, you're introduced to an engaging question and you can see that kids are going to be the ones answering the question.</p> \n<p>Besides puppies, showcasing wholesome content is a great way to get people to stop and watch your video.</p> \n<h3>3. Squarespace</h3> \n<iframe style=\"border: none; overflow: hidden; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\" src=\"https://www.facebook.com/plugins/video.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fsquarespace%2Fvideos%2F10156083341074731%2F&amp;show_text=0&amp;width=560\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe> \n<p>This Squarespace ad is compelling because the company showcased a celebrity partner. When you're fighting in the first 2 seconds to get people to stop scrolling, showcasing their favorite celebrities is a great tactic.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, creating Facebook ads is an important marketing tactic to consider. You can reach a lot of people in your audience, because most people watch videos on the social media site every day.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in July 2015 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<div></div> \n<div></div>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-create-facebook-video-ads&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 22 Sep 2020 21:45:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"485fd1de197f80109dddeac9528cb3e4","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Rebecca Riserbato","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-create-facebook-video-ads&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389709},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"5 Brand Partnership Fails [+Co-Marketing Mistakes to Avoid]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/brand-partnership-fails","description":"<p>When you were in school, did you ever work on a group project?</p> \n<p>If so, you probably remember that some went well, and others weren't as synergistic.</p> \n<p>The same thing is true with brand partnerships.</p> \n<p>Sometimes co-marketing works because each brand pulls in a new audience and the two are able to learn from one another.</p>  \n<p>However, this isn't the case with all partnerships.</p> \n<p>Below, let's review some brand partnerships that have failed and discuss <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/co-marketing-campaign\">co-marketing</a> mistakes to avoid.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2>5 Brand Partnership Fails</h2> \n<h3>1. Kendall Jenner and Pepsi</h3> \n<p>A few years ago, a major brand partnership that failed was between Kendall Jenner and Pepsi. Pepsi featured Jenner in a commercial where she offers a soda to a policeman at a protest.</p> \n<p>Here's the commercial:</p> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; max-width: 560px; max-height: 315px; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.25%; margin: 0;\">\n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/uwvAgDCOdU4\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n </div> \n</div> \n<p>The reason this partnership failed was because audiences thought the two brands were <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/05/business/kendall-jenner-pepsi-ad.html\">making light of serious social and civil rights issues</a>.</p> \n<p>Essentially, this commercial was perceived as being done in poor taste and didn't showcase social consciousness.</p> \n<h3>2. Target and Neiman Marcus</h3> \n<p>In 2013, Target and Neiman Marcus partnered on a new clothing line.</p> \n<p>However, Target's customers search for cost-efficient, mass trend clothing options, while Neiman Marcus is a luxury brand that offers expensive, edgy clothes.</p> \n<p>Unfortunately, this collection didn't take Target's target audience into account. The clothing line ended up being <a href=\"https://business.time.com/2013/01/02/epic-retail-fail-where-did-the-target-neiman-marcus-collection-go-wrong/\">too expensive and edgy for Target's audience.</a></p> \n<p>Usually, if a high-end brand is partnering with Target, the prices would be lower, so customers can get trend-setting designs at an affordable price.</p> \n<p>This partnership failed because the brands couldn't make both target audiences' happy with their collection.</p> \n<h3>3. Kraft and Starbucks</h3> \n<p>A partnership that had lasted for years ended in a major court battle.</p> \n<p>When this partnership was successful, Kraft was able to help Starbucks grow by offering distribution services and helping the coffee brand build a presence in grocery stores.</p> \n<p>According to William Neuman of \"<a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/07/business/07coffee.html\">The New York Times</a>,\" \"Kraft claims that Starbucks unilaterally decided to end their agreement, and Starbucks says that Kraft failed to aggressively promote its brands, which include Seattle's Best Coffee, in stores.\"</p> \n<p>Ultimately, this brand partnership failed because of poor communication, and possibly poor execution as well.</p> \n<h3>4. Forever 21 and Atkins</h3> \n<p>Last year, Forever 21 decided to partner with Atkins by sending out Atkins snack bars to customers who had ordered online.</p> \n<p>However, Forever 21's target market didn't appreciate the brand sending them weight loss bars. In fact, customers complained that the brand was body-shaming them.</p> \n<p>Additionally, since the partnership wasn't explained to customers, some people assumed the bars were being sent to plus-size customers who ordered online.</p> \n<p>This <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2019/07/24/business/forever-21-atkins-bars/index.html\">partnership failed</a> because it didn't make sense for the audiences and the brands' missions didn't align.</p> \n<h3>5. Shell and LEGO</h3> \n<p>Another example of brands that had worked together for years (about 50 years to be exact), Shell and LEGO had a falling out.</p> \n<p>At first, it made sense that LEGO would partner with an oil company because they could use the credibility of Shell with their race cars and gas station sets.</p> \n<p>However, LEGO eventually became a global children's entertainment brand, and the partnership didn't make sense anymore because of the oil company's reputation of poor environmental practices and oil drilling.</p> \n<p>Eventually, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2014/oct/09/lego-ends-shell-partnership-following-greenpeace-campaign\">this partnership failed</a> because of the public outcry from LEGO's audience and the impact on the brand's reputation.</p> \n<p>Now that we've reviewed some brand partnerships that have failed, let's discuss why they didn't do well and look at some common co-marketing mistakes to avoid.</p> \n<h3>1. Poor communication.</h3> \n<p>When you're working with another brand, it's important to communicate effectively and efficiently with each other.</p> \n<p>You need to be honest about what you're both going to give and get from the partnership since it has to make sense for your brands.</p> \n<p>Margot Mazur, a senior marketing manager in charge of co-marketing for HubSpot, says, \"Co-marketing is all about negotiation — you give some, and you get some from your partner. Make sure to come into the negotiation from a place of positivity, and instead of focusing on what you're going to get — whether it's promotional materials, ad spend, or placement — focus on what you can give the partner to make sure that they're finding value from the relationship.\"</p> \n<p>She added, \"On the other side of that email, there's a human being trying to do their best work, just like you. Focus on strengthening that relationship, being honest and clear about expectations and needs, and your co-marketing offer is sure to succeed.\"</p> \n<h3>2. The brand stories don't align.</h3> \n<p>Before you partner with another brand, think about your brand messaging and your story. Personify your brand and think of it as a person -- who is your brand?</p> \n<p>Now, when you choose a partner, your brands should have the same values and similar brand messaging.</p> \n<p>For example, if you're an eco-friendly brand working with an oil company, those stories don't make sense together.</p> \n<p>Your brand stories need to align, otherwise your customers will notice and call you out.</p> \n<h3>3. The partnership doesn't consider the customers.</h3> \n<p>As we saw with some of our examples, it's important that a brand partnership makes sense for both target audiences.</p> \n<p>In fact, three out of the five examples failed because the brand partnership didn't make sense for the audience.</p> \n<p>Before you begin a co-marketing relationship with another brand, consider your audience. Will this partnership make sense to them? What would they think of your partnership?</p> \n<p>It's important to answer these questions before moving forward with a co-marketing campaign.</p> \n<h3>4. Badly written agreements.</h3> \n<p>Unfortunately, for a couple of our examples above, there were issues over contracts and agreements.</p> \n<p>If you don't have a detailed, well-written agreement, then you could end up in court for not upholding your end of the deal.</p> \n<p>Each partner should agree to every part of the partnership so no one is left disappointed.</p> \n<h3>5. Executed poorly.</h3> \n<p>Another reason that a partnership might fail is because it's executed poorly. If the implementation is misguided, then you could do serious damage to your reputations.</p> \n<p>If you're going to partner with another brand, make sure that both parties are committed to it and will execute the agreement with 100% effort.</p> \n<p>So, now that we've discussed why brand partnerships might fail, how can you avoid these mistakes?</p> \n<h2>Avoiding Co-Marketing Mistakes</h2> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/co-marketing-partner-tips\">Co-marketing can be greatly beneficial</a> for both brands if it makes sense and provides value for your audience.</p> \n<p>To <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-cobranding-partnerships\">avoid these mistakes</a>, make sure that you communicate with your partner and consider your customers.</p> \n<p>To learn more about co-marketing, check out our <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/34188/what-in-the-heck-is-co-marketing.aspx\">ultimate guide</a>.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbrand-partnership-fails&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 21 Sep 2020 08:30:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"a3cd9f74495dbc18cf95e64856803229","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Rebecca Riserbato","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbrand-partnership-fails&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn22@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-49-415_b2d01c19d25a4896.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389710},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"How To Do a Poll on Instagram: A Beginner's Guide","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-poll-instagram","description":"<p>I'm a little embarrassed to admit this, but checking Instagram is one of the first things I do in the morning.</p> \n<p>But, I know I'm not alone.</p> \n<p>Did you know that <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-use-instagram\">Instagram went from one million users in December 2010 to over one billion in 2020</a>?</p>  \n<p>In fact, it's one of the most popular social media platforms in the world. So, you might be wondering, <em>\"How can I use this platform?\"</em></p> \n<p>Well, a great way to engage with your audience is through an Instagram poll.</p> \n<p>According to HubSpot research, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/instagram-story-formats\">quiz or poll stickers are one of the most popular Instagram Story formats</a>.</p> \n<p>Polls are a great way to keep in touch with your audience and even conduct market research.</p> \n<p>In this post, let's learn how to set up a poll on Instagram and discuss how you can use this feature.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>1. Open Instagram and swipe left.</h3> \n<p>To get started with Instagram polls, the first thing you need to do is open the app. Then, you'll swipe left. This will take you to the screen where you can post on your Stories.</p> \n<h3>2. Make sure you're posting to Story (underneath the record button).</h3> \n<p>Once you're here, make sure that you're posting to your Story. Underneath the record button, you'll see whether you're posting a Story, a Reel, or going Live.</p> \n<p>To post a poll, make sure you're posting to your Story.</p> \n<h3>3. Take the video or picture you want to post.</h3> \n<p>Now, just take the video or picture you want to post.</p> \n<p>If you have it saved, you can just select the content from this screen by clicking on the picture icon on the bottom left. This will take you to your camera roll where you can select a video or image.</p> \n<h3>4. Click the sticker icon on the top right.</h3> \n<p>To add the poll, click on the sticker icon on the top right. It's the third icon from the left.</p> \n<h3>5. Scroll down and choose poll or look for the sliding poll.</h3> \n<p>Now you should see different sticker options including location, time, questions, and more. Scroll down and choose the poll icon.</p> \n<p>You can either do a question and answer poll, or a sliding poll. To choose a sliding poll, you'll want to scroll until you find the slide bar option.</p> \n<h3>6. Type in the question and responses.</h3> \n<p>If you chose the question and answer poll, it's time to type in your question and the possible responses.</p> \n<p>If you chose the slide bar, you'll want to type in your question and then add an emoji to the sliding bar.</p> \n<h3>7. Click \"Send To\" and then share your poll to your Story.</h3> \n<p>Now all that's left to do is post. To do this, just click \"Send To\" and then share the post on your Story.</p> \n<h3>8. Track results.</h3> \n<p>Once you've posted a poll, it's time to wait for the responses. To view the results, you'll want to watch your Stories.</p> \n<p>Then, click the \"Seen by\" icon in the bottom left corner. This will show you who voted and the results.</p> \n<p>Here, you'll also see a button to \"Share Results.\" You can click that and post the results to your Story to let your viewers know the outcome of the poll.</p> \n<p>When you're creating a poll, remember to place it strategically.</p> \n<p>You don't want people to have problems voting because of the placement. Make sure your poll is placed near the center, and not too high or low that the other Story icons block it.</p> \n<p>As you can see, posting a poll on Instagram is a simple process. But, how do you use this feature?</p> \n<p>Here are some of the top ways you can use Instagram polls:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Learn about your audience. </strong>Polls are a great way to talk to your followers. You can learn about their interests and opinions using a simple poll.</li> \n <li><strong>Market research. </strong>Instagram polls can also help you discover what your audience wants to see from your brand. For example, I've seen a powder protein company ask questions on what flavors customers want to see and then deliver on those flavors. This makes your audience feel like they're a part of a community and like you value their opinion.</li> \n <li><strong>Gather feedback.</strong> If you want to know what your customers think, why not just ask them? You can use polls to gather feedback and information from your followers.</li> \n <li><strong>Share your content.</strong> Instagram polls are a great way to get your audience interested in the content on your site. Hopefully, the poll will strike enough interest that your followers go to your site to see a blog.</li> \n <li><strong>Enter a giveaway. </strong>I've seen plenty of influencers use the sliding bar to gather giveaway entries. After posting a few Story slides on the giveaway, the last slide usually says, \"Slide this bar so I know you entered.\"</li> \n <li><strong>Increase engagement.</strong> Polls are very helpful for the Instagram algorithm. The more engaged your audience is with you, the more likely they are to actually see your content in their feed.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Ultimately, the point of using Instagram polls is to engage with your followers and capture their attention. To learn more about Instagram marketing, you can take <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/instagram-marketing\">HubSpot's Instagram Training course</a>.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-poll-instagram&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 30 Sep 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"755ca010433b58b5b7b665f4073213dd","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Rebecca Riserbato","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-poll-instagram&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn82@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-51-341_424c37f21b59dfdb.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389711},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"The Ultimate Guide to Email Design and 13 Best Practices","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/email-design","description":"<p>By 2022, the number of email users around the world is expected to hit <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/255080/number-of-e-mail-users-worldwide/\">4.3 billion</a>.</p> \n<p>Among all of those users are members of your target audience, a.k.a. quality leads and prospects you can work to reach and convert via email.</p> \n<p>To ensure your emails stand out and grab the attention of these audience members, your email design needs to be on point.</p> \n<p>In this guide, we'll talk about what email design is, cover 13 best practices, examples of successful email design, and offer some tools you may be interested in experimenting with. Let's get started. <br /></p> \n<p></p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Email Design</h2> \n<p>Email recipients often scan information and abandon emails that don't offer them value or simply appear to be too dense. That’s why having great email design is so important — it'll help you capture the attention of, and engage, your email recipients.&nbsp;</p> \n<a></a> \n<p>Your email design should be attention-grabbing, aesthetically-pleasing, and on-brand, among other things — let's dive into those things next with these 13 best practices for email deign.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>1. Craft a strong subject line.</h3> \n<p>Your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/improve-your-email-subject-line?_ga=2.76553621.1076171011.1568210823-1493293515.1553017609\">email subject line</a> is the first thing anyone sees when you send them an email. It’s the brief statement that’s supposed to pique the interest of your recipients. It should capture their attention so they <span style=\"font-style: italic;\">want</span> to open your email and continue reading.</p> \n<p><strong>Here’s what a subject line looks like in your email inbox:</strong></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/email%20subject%20line%20example-1.png?width=1500&amp;name=email%20subject%20line%20example-1.png\" alt=\"email subject line example from email on desktop\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p><strong>Here’s what a subject line looks like in your mobile device’s email inbox:</strong></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Email%20subject%20line%20on%20mobile.jpeg?width=1500&amp;name=Email%20subject%20line%20on%20mobile.jpeg\" alt=\"Email subject line example  from email on mobile\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\" /></p> \n<p>A <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-email-subject-lines-list\">great subject line</a> will have these characteristics:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Grab the attention of your readers in as few words as possible (remember: <em>less is more</em>).</li> \n <li>Provide value for the recipient that makes them want to open the email.</li> \n <li>Summarize what recipients are going to read and/ or see once they open the email.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>2. Write an attention-grabbing pre-header.</h3> \n<p>Your email pre-header is a preview of what the email is about, similar to the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/meta-descriptions\">meta description</a> of a web page. It’s the second thing recipients see.</p> \n<p>Rather than rewriting the first sentence of your email, you can customize the pre-header to provide an inside look into what your recipients are about to read in your message.</p> \n<p><strong>Here’s what a pre-header looks like in your email inbox:</strong></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/email%20preheader%20example.png?width=1500&amp;name=email%20preheader%20example.png\" alt=\"email preheader example in desktop email inbox\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<p><strong>Here’s what a pre-header looks like in your mobile device’s email inbox:</strong></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/email%20preheader%20example.jpeg?width=1500&amp;name=email%20preheader%20example.jpeg\" alt=\"email preheader example from a mobile device\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> \n<h3>3. Be concise.</h3> \n<p>How many times throughout the day do you find yourself opening an email thinking, <em>I can’t wait to sit down and take the next 5-10 minutes to really dive into this email from Business X!</em></p> \n<p>If you're anything like me, your answer is likely rarely or never.</p> \n<p>Give email recipients the information they want and need from you without getting into the weeds. This will show them you value their time which has the potential to help you improve email subscriber retainment.</p> \n<h3>4. Keep your email on-brand.</h3> \n<p>When your email recipients open your message, they should know the email was sent from your company. Meaning your email should be branded.</p> \n<p>To <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/branding?_ga=2.76553621.1076171011.1568210823-1493293515.1553017609\">keep your email on-brand</a>, consider using the following tactics:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Use a tone in your emails that complements your other content and marketing materials (like your website and social media).</li> \n <li>Incorporate the same colors and fonts that you use in your other branding and marketing materials.</li> \n <li>Include your logo, a link to your website, links to your social media accounts, and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/email-design#calls-to-action\">calls-to-action (CTAs)</a> that are relevant to your products or services. This is a great way to increase brand awareness while also boost conversions.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>5. Use the layout to enhance your email’s user experience.</h3> \n<p>Nobody wants to read a cluttered and unorganized email — this makes recipients feel overwhelmed and can lead to increased abandonment.</p> \n<p>Instead, organize your layout with <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ux-user-experience?_ga=2.76553621.1076171011.1568210823-1493293515.1553017609\">user experience (UX)</a> in mind — meaning, leave empty/ white space and strategically place your written and visual content so it’s organized and easy to consume and navigate.</p> \n<h3>6. Personalize every email.</h3> \n<p>When you <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/customers/personalize-emails-with-smart-content\">customize an email</a> and tailor it to your recipient, it'll feel more thoughtful, professional, and personal. Email personalization also helps you humanize your brand. This touch helps you foster a relationship between your business and email recipients and boost retention rates.</p> \n<h3>7. Incorporate unique visual content.</h3> \n<p>If recipients open an email and only see paragraphs of information, it’s likely going to be difficult to hold their attention and keep them interested in your message. Rather, incorporate on-brand and engaging images, videos, GIFs, animations, etc. to break up the written content and create a memorable experience.</p> \n<p>And speaking of incorporating creative and unique visual content in your emails, let’s talk emojis.</p> \n<h3>8. Don’t be afraid to use emojis. 🧡</h3> \n<p>At first, emojis may seem like an unnecessary or unprofessional addition to an email. While this may be a fair assumption, it’s actually untrue in a number of scenarios.</p> \n<p>In fact, when you <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/articles/kcs_article/email/can-i-use-emojis-in-the-subject-line-of-my-emails?_ga=2.76553621.1076171011.1568210823-1493293515.1553017609\">add emojis to your email subject line</a> and/ or email copy, you can <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-emojis?_ga=2.142563762.1076171011.1568210823-1493293515.1553017609\">increase your open and click-through rates</a>. But remember: When using <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/emojis?_ga=2.142563762.1076171011.1568210823-1493293515.1553017609\">emojis for marketing</a> purposes, make sure you know the meaning and connotation of the specific one(s) you incorporate. 😃</p> \n<h3>9. Use a responsive design.</h3> \n<p>A <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/responsive-web-design?_ga=2.142563762.1076171011.1568210823-1493293515.1553017609\">responsive design</a> means your email changes format to fit the screen it’s being viewed on, whether it's on a desktop, laptop, or mobile device. Recipients will be able to read your emails with ease no matter where or how they’re viewing them. By incorporating a responsive design, you'll be able to enhance UX and improve email retention across all devices.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h3>10. Optimize your email with CTAs.</h3> \n<p>Calls-to-action (CTAs) are used to convert your email recipients. For instance, you can use a CTA to get recipients to follow you on social media, visit your website, chat with a sales rep, or become paying customers.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/call-to-action-examples?_ga=2.142563762.1076171011.1568210823-1493293515.1553017609\">CTAs</a> should be visible, enticing, and clearly show why they’re valuable to click. Additionally, you might choose to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/personalized-calls-to-action-convert-better-data?_ga=2.142563762.1076171011.1568210823-1493293515.1553017609\">personalize your CTAs</a> to tailor them towards specific recipients — this tactic has been proven to increase conversions.</p> \n<h3>11. Add an \"unsubscribe\" button.</h3> \n<p>Email marketing is highly effective as long as you’re providing relevant content to your recipients. The unfortunate but true reality of email marketing is that your recipients and customers change over time — especially as your business grows and evolves. Therefore, your content may not always be relevant to certain audience members.</p> \n<p>For this reason, allow your recipients to leave (or unsubscribe from your emails) on a good note so they can remember your business in a positive light — who knows, they may need your email content, products, or services again in the future. To do this, simplify their lives with an easy-to-use and visible \"unsubscribe” button.</p> \n<p>In addition to offering a better experience for users, you're actually required by law to add that unsubscribe button.</p> \n<p>According to the <a href=\"https://www.ftc.gov/tips-advice/business-center/guidance/can-spam-act-compliance-guide-business\">Federal Trade Commission and CAN-SPAM Act</a>, you’re <i>legally</i> required to include a “clear and conspicuous explanation of how the recipient can opt-out of getting emails from you in the future”. Meaning, that unsubscribe button <em>isn’t</em> an option.</p> \n<p>(If you need some inspiration, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/email-unsubscribe-pages?_ga=2.142563762.1076171011.1568210823-1493293515.1553017609\">check out these effective unsubscribe pages.)</a></p> \n<h3>12. A/B test your design.</h3> \n<p>Similar to most marketing efforts, email design is an iterative process. You might determine you need to make changes and updates to get the most out of your email design.</p> \n<p>Whether it’s modifying your CTA, colors, images, layout, or tone, don’t be afraid to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-do-a-b-testing\">A/B test </a>designs to determine which one works best in terms of ability to reach, resonate with, and convert the greatest number of recipients.</p> \n<h3>13. Design an email signature.</h3> \n<p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/professional-email-signatures\">Great email signature design</a> is another way you can establish a professional and personal feel over email. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/sales-email-signature\">Email signatures</a> shouldn't just include your name — they should contain other defining and memorable characteristics about you, your role, contact information, and company.</p> \n<p>Here are some specifics you can include in your email signature:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>First and last name</li> \n <li>Contact information (and secondary contact information)</li> \n <li>Job Title / Role</li> \n <li>Company Name</li> \n <li>Link to your meeting calendar</li> \n <li>Social media links (e.g. LinkedIn profile)</li> \n <li>Pronouns</li> \n <li>Photo</li> \n <li>Industry disclaimer or legal requirements</li> \n</ul> And \n<a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/email-signature-generator\">here's a free email signature generator tool</a> to help you design your signature. \n<br> <p>A great way to streamline the process of working on and incorporate all 13 of the above best practices is to use <strong>email design tools and software</strong>.</p> <p>In fact, many of the best practices we reviewed will come up naturally while you’re designing, writing, and planning your messages with email design software.</p> <a></a> <h2>Email Design Tools</h2> <p>There are a number of email design tools with a wide range of capabilities (some completely unrelated to email design!) — here are some popular examples.</p> <h3>1. HubSpot</h3> <p><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/email\">HubSpot’s Email Marketing software</a> allows you to create, design, personalize, and optimize all of your emails. You don’t need any IT or coding knowledge, and you can easily customize mobile-friendly emails. The software allows you to A/B test emails to determine which designs work best.</p> <h3>2. BEEPro</h3> <p>As a <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/email/beepro?_ga=2.174937762.1076171011.1568210823-1493293515.1553017609\">BEEPro</a> user, you can design responsive emails in just minutes. Smart design tools provide you with a quick way to format your emails and ensure your layout complements your content. You can also customize and save various email design templates so your messaging and branding is consistent.</p> <h3>3. MailChimp</h3> <p>With over 100 templates offered, <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/integrations/mailchimp?_ga=2.174937762.1076171011.1568210823-1493293515.1553017609\">MailChimp</a> allows you to customize your email design for your target audience. If you’re someone who <em>does</em> have coding experience, and you want to take your design a step further, MailChimp offers you the ability to code your template as well.</p> <h3>4. Stripo</h3> <p><a href=\"https://stripo.email/\">Stripo</a>&nbsp;requires no HTML knowledge to create and design professional email templates. All of their pre-made templates are responsive so readers can easily view them via any device. You can also sync your current email service provider (ESP) with the software to access all of your email and contact information from a central location.</p> <h3>5. Chamaileon</h3> <p>As a collaborative email builder, <a href=\"https://chamaileon.io/\">Chamaileon</a> gives you the ability to invite members of your team to collaborate on your designs. The software ensures your emails will have a responsive design and automatically comes with over 100 pre-made templates to customize for specific recipients.</p> <a></a> <h2>Email Design Examples</h2> <p>Let’s take a look at some successful email designs to inspire your work.</p> <h3>HubSpot Marketing Blog</h3> <p>HubSpot sends subscribers <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing\">Marketing Blog</a> emails every day. These include a few blog marketing-related articles to read and learn from. If recipients choose, they may also subscribe to HubSpot’s <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales?_ga=2.174937762.1076171011.1568210823-1493293515.1553017609\">Sales Blog</a> and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service?_ga=2.170155680.1076171011.1568210823-1493293515.1553017609\">Service Blog</a> emails.</p> <p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-09-07%20at%201.30.17%20PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-09-07%20at%201.30.17%20PM.png\" alt=\"hubspot marketing email email design examples\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> <p>The emails are branded so readers immediately know who the email is from and what it will include. To make the daily emails engaging and unique, they include previews of the articles and an occasional quiz.</p> <h3>Starbucks Rewards</h3> <p><a href=\"https://www.starbucks.com/\">Starbucks</a> customers and members may have seen this email, or something similar, in their inbox before:</p> <p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-09-06%20at%201.04.21%20PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-09-06%20at%201.04.21%20PM.png\" alt=\"starbucks email design example\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> <p>The email complements Starbucks’ marketing and branding, and there’s plenty of white space separating the written information from the engaging imagery. And the CTA that recipients can click on to activate the offer is clearly placed.</p> <h3>Vital Proteins Email Design</h3> <p>Although <a href=\"https://www.vitalproteins.com/\">Vital Proteins'</a> email design contains many images and a lot of information, it’s neatly organized so it doesn’t feel overwhelming to recipients. The email’s colors, font, and visuals are on-brand and feature the company’s products.</p> <p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-09-06%20at%201.06.22%20PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-09-06%20at%201.06.22%20PM.png\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"vital proteins example of email design\" /></p> <p>There's an obvious CTA that redirects recipients to their Instagram page — in turn, this type of CTA helps the company increase their follower count and brand awareness on the social platform.</p> <p><em><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/email-templates-for-marketing-and-sales?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase\">Get inspired with 15 free and downloadable email templates designed for marketing and sales with previously written copy to save you time. </a></em></p> <h2>Grow Better With Really Good Email Design</h2> <p>With great email design, you’ll reach and resonate with your audience members more effectively, allowing you to grow better. Eye-catching and impactful emails will help you build long-lasting relationships and convert more people into paying customers and brand advocates. So, begin designing your emails while keeping the best practices and examples we reviewed in mind.</p> <p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in August, 2017 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> <p></p> <p></p> <img
