atedDate":1602214389707},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"20 Stats That Make the Case for Co-Marketing in 2020","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/co-marketing-stats","description":"<p>As a billionaire inventor and CEO, the fictional <a href=\"https://ironman.fandom.com/wiki/Avengers_Team_(film)\">Tony Stark</a>, also known as <a href=\"https://ironman.fandom.com/wiki/Avengers_Team_(film)\">Marvel's</a><a href=\"https://ironman.fandom.com/wiki/Avengers_Team_(film)\"> Iron Man</a>, worked his way to the top of the corporate ladder while repeatedly saving the world on the side.</p>  \n<p>Despite Stark's impressive achievements, his career success and robotic super-suit weren't what made him a legend.</p> \n<p>In fact, Stark’s best <em>Marvel Comics</em> storylines began when he <a href=\"https://ironman.fandom.com/wiki/Avengers_Team_(film)\">joined The Avengers</a> to save the entire universe.</p> \n<p>Although Stark was fully capable of saving Earth alone in his super-suit, he knew teaming up with other superheroes would allow him to save multiple planets.</p> \n<p>Marketers can learn a lot from Tony Stark.</p> \n<p>While our brands might be capable of reaching basic targets all on their own, pooling marketing resources, combining skill sets, and jointly creating campaigns with other <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/co-marketing-partner-tips\">non-competing companies</a> could help us reach much broader audiences. This tactic is known as <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-cobranding-partnerships?_ga=2.134688818.211809938.1593996156-896985742.1590628977\">co-marketing</a>.</p> \n<p>Although co-marketing can be incredibly beneficial to you and your partner's brands, it will still take time, planning, and coordination when it comes to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/co-marketing-partner-tips\">finding a co-marketing partner</a> and launching mutually beneficial campaigns.</p> \n<p>Like any good marketer considering a new tactic, you’ll want to know that co-marketing can be effective before devoting resources to it. And yes, you'll likely want to research more than just the superhero analogy I've made above.</p> \n<p>To help you make the case for co-marketing, here’s a list of 20 statistics that prove why you should consider this strategy in 2020.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2>20 Co-Marketing Stats to Know in 2020</h2> \n<h3>The State of Co-Marketing in 2020</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>After seeing co-marketed campaigns, 68% of consumers are able to make buying decisions before even speaking to sales representatives. (<a href=\"https://www.partner-path.com/partner-program-benchmark-data\">PartnerPath, 2019</a>)</li> \n <li>Virtually all companies surveyed in 2018 were already active in internet marketing partnerships and affiliate programs. The few that weren't were active planning to be in the next 12 months. (<a href=\"https://blog.partnerize.com/partner-affiliate-marketing-research-the-state-and-future-of-partnerships-survey-1-4/\">Partnerize, 2018</a>)</li> \n <li>54% of companies say partnerships drive more than 20% of total company revenue. (<a href=\"https://blog.partnerize.com/partner-affiliate-marketing-research-the-state-and-future-of-partnerships-survey-1-4/\">Partnerize, 2018</a>)</li> \n <li>34% of marketers say that co-marketing or brand partnerships are the most effective ways to increase an email subscriber list. (<a href=\"http://research.ascend2.com/2017-email-list-growth-trends/\">Ascend2, 2017</a>)</li> \n <li>74% of companies say partnerships and affiliate marketing campaigns are a high or very high priority for their businesses. (<a href=\"https://blog.partnerize.com/partner-affiliate-marketing-research-the-state-and-future-of-partnerships-survey-1-4/\">Partnerize, 2018</a>)</li> \n <li>In 2018, just 5% of companies said they'd invested less in partnerships than in 2017. (<a href=\"https://blog.partnerize.com/partner-affiliate-marketing-research-the-state-and-future-of-partnerships-survey-1-4/\">Partnerize, 2018</a>)</li> \n <li>More than half of respondents in a 2018 partnership survey said partnerships were driving more customers and sales in that year than in 2017. (<a href=\"https://blog.partnerize.com/partner-affiliate-marketing-research-the-state-and-future-of-partnerships-survey-1-4/\">Partnerize, 2018</a>)</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Partnership and Co-Marketing Tactics</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>Brand partnerships that leverage digital channels see 4X the pipeline of non-digital partnerships. (<a href=\"http://go.impact.com/rs/280-XQP-994/images/PDFdownload-PC-AW-InvestinPartnerships.pdf\">Impact, 2019</a>)</li> \n <li>84% of vendors with brand partners offer money to those partners for co-marketing expenses. (<a href=\"https://www.partner-path.com/partner-program-benchmark-data\">PartnerPath, 2019</a>)</li> \n <li>30% of vendors will offer co-marketing reimbursement if their brand partner can prove ROI. (<a href=\"https://www.partner-path.com/partner-program-benchmark-data\">PartnerPath, 2019</a>)</li> \n <li>Roughly 11% of marketers say \"partnership posts\" are their brand's most engaging type of social media content. (<a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing\">HubSpot, 2020</a>)</li> \n <li>Many brands prioritize large partnerships, versus thousands of smaller partnerships. Roughly 34% of leading brands have 50 to 99 partners, while 67% of brands have less than 100. (<a href=\"https://blog.partnerize.com/partner-affiliate-marketing-research-the-state-and-future-of-partnerships-survey-1-4/\">Partnerize, 2018</a>)</li> \n <li>Only 2% of brands surveyed by Partnerize in 2018 partner with more than 1,000 brands. (<a href=\"https://blog.partnerize.com/partner-affiliate-marketing-research-the-state-and-future-of-partnerships-survey-1-4/\">Partnerize, 2018</a>)</li> \n <li>In 2018, 33% of CEOs said they planned to prioritize strategic partnerships, which could involve co-marketing partnerships, in 2019. (<a href=\"https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2018/05/ceo-outlook.html\">KPMG, 2018</a>)</li> \n <li>The top brand leader priorities include finding more partners (27%) and strengthening relationships with existing partners (23%). (<a href=\"https://blog.partnerize.com/partner-affiliate-marketing-research-the-state-and-future-of-partnerships-survey-1-4/\">Partnerize, 2018</a>)</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Co-Marketing and Brand Partnership Success Stories</h3> \n<ul> \n <li>The Yeezy shoe line, a collaboration between Adidas and Kanye West, enabled Adidas' net annual rose by 19.5% to $1.9 billion in 2019. (<a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-03-13/adidas-targets-slower-sales-in-2019-amid-prolonged-europe-slump\">Bloomberg, 2019</a>)</li> \n <li>Buffer and Social Chain's Brand 2019 Brand and Social Media Report resulted in 17,000 download page visits in just one week and more than 3,000 shares across social media. These results were higher than an average article shared on either of their sites. (<a href=\"https://quuu.co/blog/co-marketing-the-infallible-strategy-no-one-talks-about/\">Quuu, 2019</a>)</li> \n <li>When Estée Lauder and a top U.S. retailer created joint Google Ads that promoted the retailer and the brand's fragrance products, the average ad click share rose by 70%. (<a href=\"https://www.google.com/retail/solutions/shopping-campaigns-with-partners/\">Google, 2020</a>)</li> \n <li>In 2018, Coors Light teamed up with National Geographic to launch a series of video ads taking place in Iceland. The campaign reached 10.5 million people and resulted in a 6.8 percent lift in brand favorability. (<a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/business/success/coors-light\">Facebook, 2018</a>)</li> \n <li>In a recent case study, a gaming app company partnered with another brand in a cross-promotional campaign that was coordinated by Aarki -- a mobile marketing agency. The gaming app received a 32% rise in downloads shortly after remarketing ads to the partnering brand's contact list on social media. (<a href=\"https://www.aarki.com/blog/case-study-the-impact-of-cross-promotion\">Aarki, 2020</a>)</li> \n</ul> \n<h2>The Benefits of Co-Marketing</h2> \n<p>Co-marketing can provide a long list of benefits, especially if you want to pool your resources to create a large-scale marketing campaign. Along with the statistical benefits seen above, there are a number of other qualitative perks such as:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Audience exposure: </strong>Through co-marketing and cross-promotion, your content or brand information will be shared with your audiences as well as your brand partner's. This enables your brand to gain increased reach. For example, when local or online stores launch Google Ads showing that they carry Estée Lauder fragrances, fans of the perfume brand might visit or follow that store for the first time.</li> \n <li><strong>Increased trust and favorability: </strong>If a prospect trusts the brand you partner with, they might trust you when that brand promotes your name, logo, or content. For example, when <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-cobranding-partnerships\">Adidas teamed up with Kanye West</a> to create the Yeezy line, people might have bought a pair of Yeezys because they trusted Adidas' quality and West's sense of style.</li> \n <li><strong>Cost-effective content:</strong> When you <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/co-marketing-partner-tips\">team up with another brand</a>, you might be able to make an agreement where you split time or production costs, or you can trade one brand strength for another. For example, if you're a small brand partnering with a larger brand, you might be able to utilize the bigger brand's budget and gain more exposure on their channels. Meanwhile, the bigger brand might be able to leverage your niche social media audience..</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Now that you've learned about the benefits and stats related to co-marketing, get inspiration from <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-cobranding-partnerships\">these successful real-world examples of the tactic.</a> For more on how to find the right co-marketing partner, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/co-marketing-partner-tips\">check out this handy guide</a>.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fco-marketing-stats&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 23 Sep 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"00edf87b795a7509dc3c7cbba6972013","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"pbump@hubspot.com (Pamela Bump)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fco-marketing-stats&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn43@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-47-753_0815ccbd920f2e9b.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389708},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"What is Trading Up, and Why It Matters for Marketers","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/trading-up","description":"<p>To understand what the term \"trading up\" means, let's start with a scenario.</p> \n<p>You wake up early and jog to the Starbucks on the corner of your street. There, you wait in line to order a pumpkin-spiced latte, as you skim emails on your iPhone.</p> \n<p>Afterwards, you return home, put on your new Lululemon workout apparel, and hop on your Peloton for an at-home workout.</p> \n<p>In this scenario, you've \"traded up\" in a variety of consumer categories: including coffee, technology, clothing, and even workout gear.</p> \n<p>Why, for instance, did you feel the need to head to Starbucks and pay $6 for a drink, as opposed to making a quick pot of coffee in your Keurig? Alternatively, why not purchase workout apparel from Marshalls or Target?</p> \n<p>(No judgment on any of these decisions: I've made them, too.)</p> \n<p>Ultimately, trading up refers to a consumer's tendency to pay <em>more </em>for a higher-quality, more expensive product or service from a brand to which they've formed an emotional attachment, and feel a sense of loyalty.</p> \n<p>But trading up doesn't just refer to a consumer's behavior in the marketplace at-large: it also refers to a consumer's decision to upgrade their product for a newer model with additional features.</p> \n<p>As a marketer, it's critical you understand the concept \"trading up\" to discern how you might evoke brand loyalty in a crowded marketplace — or, how you might market a new version of your product to existing consumers.</p> \n<p>Here, let's explore what trading up means, as well as what it means specifically for marketers.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2><strong>What does trading up mean?</strong></h2> \n<h3><strong>Trading up in the industry at-large. </strong></h3> \n<p>There are two contexts in which you'll find the term \"trading up\" used: within a marketplace at-large, and within your company's own product suite.</p> \n<p>To start, let's explore what trading up means within an entire marketplace.</p> \n<p>In this context, trading up refers to a consumer's decision to purchase a more expensive product because of the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/branding\">brand</a><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/branding\"> value</a> they feel it delivers. This is why consumers will purchase a car for 10X the normal price if it's marked with BMW, but why they might not make the same decision for a car from a lesser-known brand.</p> \n<p>There are a few reasons why a consumer will trade up in the marketplace. For one, a consumer might trade up because the brand meets their aspirational vision of who they want to be. There is undoubtedly a different vision that comes to mind when a consumer thinks of Starbucks versus Dunkin' — in exchange for this vision, a consumer might be willing to pay more for a coffee.</p> \n<p>These top-of-the-line brands often feel \"premium\" and luxurious, incentivizing consumers to pay more than they would for another version of that product in the marketplace from a lesser-known or lower-quality brand.</p> \n<p>However, that isn't to say that consumers purchase products from certain companies entirely based on brand name alone. No matter how impressive Starbucks' brand image is, it doesn't do much good if the coffee is disgusting.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, you can't have one without the other. A brand like Starbucks, BMW, or Apple rises to the top of their industries because they provide high-quality, well-engineered products — not just because they have a good brand image to match.</p> \n<p>Additionally, these brands have built a good deal of trust with existing consumers, which leads to positive word-of-mouth marketing. Considering over <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/agency/how-online-word-of-mouth-marketing-is-changing\">90% of consumers</a> trust family and friends' suggestions more than advertising, this is important.</p> \n<p>For instance, nowadays, Apple doesn't need to appeal to consumers with constant commercials and billboards — instead, they can trust their loyal brand advocates to do the heavy-lifting (just consider the jokes you find on <a href=\"https://twitter.com/search?f=realtime&amp;q=%22green%20bubbles%22&amp;src=typd\">Twitter when you search \"green bubbles\"</a>, which signifies a non-Apple user).</p> \n<p>Suggestions from friends and family is the second powerful reason a consumer will trade up. Perhaps you've never considered purchasing a Peloton, until you heard your friends raving about the product.</p> \n<p>Friends will only suggest a product if it's truly high-quality and meets their needs above all other competitors in the marketplace.</p> \n<p>Which is why, ultimately, you need both a strong brand <em>and </em>a powerful product or service for consumers to feel they're trading up from the \"status quo product\" that exists in your industry.</p> \n<p>Next, let's explore what it means for a consumer to trade up at <em>your</em> company in particular.</p> \n<h3><strong>Trading up within a company's product suite. </strong></h3> \n<p>The second context for trading up is within a company, and is also known as upgrading.</p> \n<p>For instance, let's say you sell a starter version of your software, but you've just released a new professional version, with higher-quality features. If your consumers choose to upgrade to the new version of your product, they're \"trading up\".</p> \n<p>In many ways, this mirrors the first definition. You might think of your starter version as a used car, and your professional version as this year's latest model.</p> \n<p>To encourage consumers to trade up, you'll want to demonstrate how the new features of your product are powerful and necessary — not just \"nice to haves\" but \"need to haves\".</p> \n<p>Take a look at <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/cross-selling\">Cross-Selling and Upselling: The Ultimate Guide</a> for more information on this.</p> \n<h2><strong>Trading Up in Marketing</strong></h2> \n<p>Now that we've explored what trading up means for a consumer, let's explore what it means as a marketer.</p> \n<p>Understanding the reasons a consumer might trade up can help you leverage your brand and products to incentivize consumers to feel they're trading up when they purchase <em>your </em>products or services.</p> \n<p>How? Through good brand recognition (and a high-quality product, of course).</p> \n<p>While I used some major brands in my examples, you don't need to be a large corporation for consumers to feel they're trading up. For instance, consider my new favorite coffee shop, the <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/bittersweetboston/\">Bittersweet Shoppe</a>, on Newbury Street. The cozy cafe is filled with sunflowers and offers fantastic customer service — now, when I go there, I feel like I'm trading up from Starbucks. Ultimately, I like the <em>experience</em> of entering their coffee shop, which is what a good brand image is all about.</p> \n<p>If you work for a small business, there are plenty of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/branding\">strategies you might implement to create a strong brand</a>, including building a brand strategy, prioritizing consistency, and using a strong mission or vision statement to guide all your decisions.</p> \n<p>Additionally, encouraging consumers to trade up, or upgrade, from <em>within</em> your product suite involves strong messaging, sales and marketing alignment, and a true understanding of what your consumers need and how your newer version can meet those challenges, particularly as consumers out-grow your first product.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, people don't trade up from brands and products they love. Ensure you're meeting your consumers needs, both through your brand <em>and</em> your products, and they'll tell their friends and family. Soon enough, you'll be the brand people trade up for.</p> \n<p>Just consider this: I'm going on six years of owning an iPhone, with no interest in pivoting. Now <em>that's</em> the power of a good brand, and a strong product.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ftrading-up&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 07 Oct 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"4e5636b149a6c37e92a160486e50bb98","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Caroline Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ftrading-up&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn54@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-51-521_f0686dd2b9fd0371.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389701},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"What's Sprite to Coca Cola? An Exploration of Brand Portfolios","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/brand-portfolio","description":"<p>Do you know how you have siblings, cousins, aunts, and uncles? Well, brands kind of do too — only their fellow brands probably don't get way too aggressive about the conspiracy theories they believe in while everyone's just trying to enjoy Thanksgiving dinner like <em>somebody's</em> Uncle Gary does every year.</p>  \n<p>While brands don't go through<em> that </em>kind of situation that totally doesn't apply to me, they're still generally related — falling under umbrellas set by larger, overarching firms. And if we're running with the whole family analogy, the family trees those umbrellas set are known as brand portfolios.</p> \n<p>Here, we'll get a more thorough understanding of brand portfolios, see the different kinds of brands that can compose one, and explore some prominent brand portfolio examples.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Firms generally create, expand, and maintain brand portfolios to gain footholds in multiple markets and appeal to a wider variety of prospects. This trend has a presence in virtually every industry. For the sake of example, let's imagine a firm that runs a single fast-food chain.</p> \n<p>That flagship brand serves typical fast-food fare at bargain prices. That chain is doing well, but executives at the firm are noticing a significant shift in consumer preferences. Now, a solid segment of the chain's market is starting to err towards healthier options.</p> \n<p>The flagship brand's identity has been firmly established as a value-oriented albeit not-so-healthy franchise — so much so that making its menu healthier might alienate the majority of its customers who <em>aren't</em> interested in health-food.</p> \n<p>In this case, the firm could explore the possibility of creating a new restaurant — one with an emphasis on healthy options. If it decides to take that route, it would add another brand to its brand portfolio.</p> \n<p>The brands contained within your average brand portfolio tend to fall into four main roles: flanker brands, cash cow brands, low-end entry-level brands, and high-end prestige brands. Each category serves a purpose, and in many cases, a firm will create and maintain brands that fulfill different roles to complement one another.</p> \n<h3>1. Flanker Brand</h3> \n<p>A flanker brand is a brand a company releases in a product category in which it already has an existing brand. The hope is that the new brand helps increase the company's market share within that product category and serves the needs of prospects the original brand might not cover.</p> \n<p>For instance, alcoholic beverage company Molson Coors leverages a flanker brand strategy in its approach to the low-calorie beer market. The company has released multiple brands — including Miller Lite, Coors Light, and Keystone Light — that all occupy a similar niche.</p> \n<p>Still, the brands are distinct enough to appeal to different consumers and suit different situations. Even though they're technically competing, flanker brands <em>complement</em> more than they <em>cannibalize</em>. They're designed to help a company flesh out its market presence and crowd out competitors.</p> \n<h3>2. Cash Cow Brand</h3> \n<p>A cash cow brand is one that has reached a certain level of maturity with respect to its market presence and ability to make money. These brands can generate enough profit to essentially sustain themselves — keeping themselves afloat after businesses recoup their initial investments from them.</p> \n<p>It's much less expensive to sit back and let these brands continue to bring in cash than to launch any sort of new product to replace them. As a result, they're rarely removed from the market.</p> \n<h3>3. Low-End Entry-Level Brand</h3> \n<p>A low-end entry-level brand is one that's added to a brand portfolio to be offered at a lower price than the other products or services that portfolio covers. The principle behind low-end entry-level brands has to do with hooking customers.</p> \n<p>The idea is that consumers will buy the low-end entry-level brand initially — effectively introducing them to that brand's broader portfolio. Once a customer has engaged with and been impressed by the company behind the low-end entry-level brand, they'll be inclined to explore the broader suite of products in its portfolio.</p> \n<h3>4. High-End Prestige Brand</h3> \n<p>High-end prestige brands are ones designed to create the impression of premium quality and luxury. The hope is that some of the esteem the brand creates will trickle down onto the other brands within the company's broader portfolio.</p> \n<p>These kinds of brands are tailored to lead consumers to think, <em>\"If this company can create a product of its caliber, maybe its other ones are high quality in their own right.\"</em></p> \n<p>1. <a href=\"https://www.coca-colacompany.com/brands\">Coca Cola</a></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Whats%20Sprite%20to%20Coca%20Cola%3F%20An%20Exploration%20of%20Brand%20Portfolios-1.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.coca-colacompany.com/brands\" style=\"font-style: italic; text-decoration: none;\">Image Source: Coca Cola</a></p> \n<p>Coca Cola's brand portfolio is about as eclectic, far-reaching as they come — certainly when it comes to the food and beverage industry. Its suite of brands includes drinks and edible products that cover a massive range of purposes, prices, qualities, and regional markets.</p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://www.nestle.com/\">Nestle</a></h3> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Whats%20Sprite%20to%20Coca%20Cola%3F%20An%20Exploration%20of%20Brand%20Portfolios.jpeg\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://www.nestle.com/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source: Nestle</a></p> \n<p>Nestle is the largest food and beverage company in the world, and the graphic above barely scrapes the surface of its scale. Its brand portfolio is eclectic and contains brands that suit a massive variety of categories and needs.</p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://www.ge.com/\">General Electric</a></h3> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Whats%20Sprite%20to%20Coca%20Cola%3F%20An%20Exploration%20of%20Brand%20Portfolios-2.jpeg\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.ge.com/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source: GE</a></p> \n<p>GE's brand portfolio is monolithic, meaning all the brands that fall under its broader portfolio are similarly branded. They all feature fundamentally similar names and sport the same logo.</p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://www.jnj.com/\">Johnson and Johnson</a></h3> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Whats%20Sprite%20to%20Coca%20Cola%3F%20An%20Exploration%20of%20Brand%20Portfolios-1.jpeg\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"https://www.jnj.com/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source: Johnson and Johnson</a></p> \n<p>Johnson and Johnson's brand portfolio covers a variety of markets that fit under the broader healthcare industry umbrella.</p> \n<p>Major brands generally don't exist in a vacuum. Almost all of them are a part of a broader brand portfolio, so virtually every brand has a firm, company, or conglomerate at the top of its lineage.</p> \n<p>That's important to bear in mind when taking actions like trying to be ethical with your dollar. Any brand you use starts somewhere. If you can navigate that product's portfolio back to a company whose values and actions don't sit well with you, you'll know to avoid it.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbrand-portfolio&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 06 Oct 2020 12:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Whats%20Sprite%20to%20Coca%20Cola%3F%20An%20Exploration%20of%20Brand%20Portfolios-1.png","linkMd5":"a81edb721fc60b35458886c1227bc302","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn99@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-31-850_e01f07d85d683ef6.webp","destWidth":1280,"destHeight":1280,"sourceBytes":954858,"destBytes":954858,"author":"jfuchs@hubspot.com (Jay Fuchs)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Whats%20Sprite%20to%20Coca%20Cola%3F%20An%20Exploration%20of%20Brand%20Portfolios-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn99@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-31-850_e01f07d85d683ef6.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Whats%20Sprite%20to%20Coca%20Cola%3F%20An%20Exploration%20of%20Brand%20Portfolios.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn16@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-51-618_1c09bc760f79e0be.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Whats%20Sprite%20to%20Coca%20Cola%3F%20An%20Exploration%20of%20Brand%20Portfolios-2.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn83@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-45-860_1ceb8af3f51a74a7.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Whats%20Sprite%20to%20Coca%20Cola%3F%20An%20Exploration%20of%20Brand%20Portfolios-1.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn45@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-47-192_e7c308517bdeb1ee.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbrand-portfolio&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn40@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-49-550_27f282a710dde349.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389708},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"The Ultimate Guide to Google Ads [Examples]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-adwords-ppc","description":"<p>If you’re considering spending any amount of money on ads to reach your target audience, you’d better spend it in the right place.</p> \n<p>That is, somewhere with over <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/topics/1001/google/\">259 million</a> unique visitors and <a href=\"http://www.internetlivestats.com/google-search-statistics/\">4.8 billion</a> daily interactions.</p> \n<p>Somewhere like ... <strong>Google.</strong></p> \n<p>Google Ads was launched just two years after what has become the <a href=\"https://www.alexa.com/topsites\">most popular website</a> in the world: Google.com. The advertising platform came on the scene in October 2000 as <strong>Google Adwords</strong>, but after some rebranding in 2018, it was renamed <strong>Google Ads</strong>.</p> \n<p>Given Google’s expansive reach, chances are you’ve seen (and probably clicked on) a Google ad … and so have your potential customers.</p> \n<p>In this guide you'll discover how to begin advertising on Google. We’ll cover features specific to the platform and teach you how to optimize your campaigns to achieve the best results with your ads.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>It's no secret that, these days, the stronger and more focused your paid campaigns are, the more clicks you generate — leading to a greater probability of obtaining new customers.</p> \n<p>This is why Google Ads has become increasingly popular among businesses across all industries.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>What is Google Ads?</h2> \n<p><a href=\"https://ads.google.com/home/\">Google Ads</a> is a paid advertising platform that falls under a marketing channel known as <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ppc\">pay-per-click (PPC)</a>, where you (the advertiser) pays per click or per impression (CPM) on an ad.</p> \n<p>Google Ads is an effective way to drive qualified traffic, or good-fit customers, to your business while they're searching for products and services like the ones you offer. With Google Ads, you can boost your website traffic, receive more phone calls, and increase your in-store visits.</p> \n<p>Google Ads allows you to create and share well-timed ads (via both mobile and desktop) among your target audience. This means your business will show up on the search engine results page (SERP) at the moment your ideal customers are looking for products and services like yours via Google Search or Google Maps. This way, you reach your target audience when it makes sense for them to come across your ad.</p> \n<p><strong>Note</strong>: Ads from the platform can span across other channels too, including YouTube, Blogger, and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-display-network\">Google Display Network</a>.</p> \n<p>Over time, Google Ads will also help you analyze and improve those ads to reach <em>more</em> people so your business can hit all of your paid campaign goals<i>.</i></p> \n<p><i><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/ads?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase\"><em>Discover how HubSpot can help you better manage your Google ads.</em></a></i></p> \n<p>Additionally, no matter the size of your business or your available resources, you can tailor your ads to suit your budget. The Google Ads tool gives you the opportunity to stay within your monthly cap and even pause or stop your ad spending at any point in time.</p> \n<p>Now, onto another important question: Is Google Ads <em>really</em> effective? To answer this, let’s consider a few statistics:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Google Ads have a click-through rate of nearly 8%.</li> \n <li>Display ads yield 180 million impressions each month.</li> \n <li>For users who are ready to buy, paid ads on Google get 65% of the clicks.</li> \n <li>43% of customers buy something they’ve seen on a YouTube ad.</li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h3>Why advertise on Google?</h3> \n<p>Google is the most used search engine, receiving over <a href=\"http://www.internetlivestats.com/google-search-statistics/\">5 billion search queries</a> a day. Not to mention, the Google Ads platform has been around for nearly two decades, giving it some seniority in the area of paid advertising.</p> \n<p>Google is a resource used by people around the world to ask questions that are answered with a combination of paid advertisements and organic results.</p> \n<p>And, according to <a href=\"https://static.googleusercontent.com/media/economicimpact.google.com/en//static/reports/2016/ei-report-2016.pdf\">Google</a>, advertisers make $8 for every $1 they spend on Google Ads. So, there are a few reasons why you’d want to consider advertising on Google.</p> \n<p>Need another reason? Your competitors are using Google Ads (and they might even be bidding on your branded terms). <a href=\"https://idatalabs.com/tech/products/adwords\">Hundreds of thousands</a> of companies use Google Ads to promote their businesses, which means that <strong>even if you’re ranking organically for a search term, your results are being pushed down the page, beneath your competitors</strong>.</p> \n<p>If you’re using PPC to advertise your product or services, Google Ads should be a part of your paid strategy — there’s no way around it (except maybe <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/facebook-marketing/facebook-lead-ads\">Facebook Ads</a>, but that’s another article).</p> \n<p></p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Google Ads Best Practices</h2> \n<p>If you’ve tried unsuccessfully to advertise on Google, don’t give up. There are many reasons why your Google Ads could be underperforming. Let’s cover some common Google Ads best practices.</p> \n<h3>1. Avoid broad keyword terms.</h3> \n<p>You really need to nail it when it comes to your keywords, which is why testing and tweaking should be a part of your strategy. If your keywords are too broad, Google will be placing your ad in front of the wrong audience which means fewer clicks and a higher ad spend.</p> \n<p>Review what’s working (i.e. which keywords are generating clicks) and adjust them to best match your ads with your target audience. You likely won’t get the mix right the first time, but you should keep adding, removing, and tweaking keywords until you do.</p> \n<p><strong>Tip</strong><strong>: </strong>Review the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-adwords-ppc#keyword-strategy\">keyword strategies that we cover below</a>.</p> \n<h3>2. Don't run irrelevant ads.</h3> \n<p>If your ad doesn’t match the searcher’s intent, you won’t get enough clicks to justify your ad spend. Your headline and ad copy need to match the keywords you’re bidding on, <em>and</em> the solution your ad is marketing needs to solve whatever pain point that searcher is experiencing.</p> \n<p>It’s a combination that will yield the results you’re looking for, and it may just be a few tweaks away. You have the option to create multiple ads per campaign — use this feature to split test which ads work best. Or, better yet, use Google’s <a href=\"https://support.google.com/google-ads/answer/7684791?hl=en\">Responsive Search Ads</a> feature.</p> \n<p><strong>Tip: </strong>Read our <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-adwords-ppc#ad-copy\">best practices for ad copy</a>.</p> \n<h3>3. Improve your Quality Score (QS).</h3> \n<p>Your Quality Score (QS) is how Google determines how your ad should rank. The higher your rank, the better your placements. If your quality score is low, you’ll have fewer eyeballs on your ad and fewer chances to convert. Google will tell you your Quality Score, but improving it is up to you.</p> \n<p><strong>Tip:</strong> Keep reading to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-adwords-ppc#quality-score\">learn how to improve your QS</a>.<em><br /></em></p> \n<h3>4. Optimize your ad landing page.</h3> \n<p>Your efforts shouldn’t stop with your ad — the user experience <em>after</em> a click is equally important.</p> \n<p>What does your user see once they click your ad? Is your landing page optimized for conversions, meaning does it use the same keywords? Does the page solve your user’s pain point or answer their question? Your user should experience a seamless transition through to the conversion.</p> \n<p><strong>Tip: </strong>Review <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/landing-page-best-practices\">landing page best practices</a> and implement them to increase your conversion rate.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p></p> \n<p>These common terms will help you set up, manage, and optimize your Google Ads. Some of these are specific to Google Ads, while others are related to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ppc\">PPC</a> in general. Either way, you’ll need to know these to run an effective ad campaign.</p> \n<h3>1. AdRank</h3> \n<p>Your AdRank determines your ad placement. The higher the value, the better you’ll rank, the more eyes will fall on your ad, and the higher the probability that users will click your ad. Your AdRank is determined by your maximum bid multiplied by your Quality Score.</p> \n<h3>2. Bidding</h3> \n<p>Google Ads is based on a bidding system, where you as the advertiser selects a maximum bid amount you’re willing to pay for a click on your ad. The higher your bid, the better your placement. You have three options for bidding: CPC, CPM, or CPE.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>CPC</strong>, or cost-per-click, is the amount you pay for each click on your ad.</li> \n <li><strong>CPM</strong>, or cost per mille, is the amount you pay for one thousand ad impressions, that is when your ad is shown to a thousand people.</li> \n <li><strong>CPE</strong>, or cost per engagement, is the amount you pay when someone takes a predetermined action with your ad.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>And, yes, we’ll review <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-adwords-ppc#bidding-strategy\">bidding strategies below</a>.</p> \n<h3>3. Campaign Type</h3> \n<p>Before you begin a paid campaign on Google Ads, you’ll select between one of three campaign types: search, display, or video.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Search ads</strong> are text ads that are displayed among search results on a Google results page.</li> \n <li><strong>Display ads</strong> are typically image-based and are shown on web pages within the Google Display Network.</li> \n <li><strong>Video ads</strong> are between six and 15 seconds and appear on YouTube.</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>4. Click-Through Rate (CTR)</h3> \n<p>Your CTR is the number of clicks you get on your ad as a proportion of the number of views your ad gets. A higher CTR indicates a quality ad that matches search intent and targets relevant keywords.</p> \n<h3>5. Conversion Rate (CVR)</h3> \n<p>CVR is a measure of form submissions as a proportion of total visits to your landing page. Simplistically speaking, a high CVR means that your landing page presents a seamless user experience that matches the promise of the ad.</p> \n<h3>6. Display Network</h3> \n<p>Google ads can be displayed on either search results pages or a web page within <a href=\"https://support.google.com/google-ads/answer/2404190?hl=en\">Google’s Display Network (GDN)</a>. GDN is a network of websites that allow space on their webpages for Google Ads — these ads can be text-based or image ads and are displayed alongside content relevant to your target keywords. The most popular Display Ad options are <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-shopping\">Google Shopping</a> and app campaigns.</p> \n<h3>7. Extensions</h3> \n<p>Ad Extensions allow you to supplement your ad with additional information at no additional cost. These extensions fall under one of five categories: Sitelink, Call, Location, Offer, or App; <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-adwords-ppc#ad-extensions\">we’ll cover each of these ad extensions below</a>.</p> \n<h3>8. Keywords</h3> \n<p>When a Google user types a query into the search field, Google returns a range of results that match the searcher’s intent. Keywords are words or phrases that align with what a searcher wants and will satisfy their query. You select keywords based on which queries you want to display your ad alongside. For example, a searcher that types “how to clean gum off shoes” will see results for advertisers that targeted keywords like “gum on shoes” and “clean shoes.”</p> \n<strong>Negative keywords</strong> are a list of keyword terms that you do \n<em>not</em> want to rank for. Google will pull you from the bid on these keywords. Typically, these are semi-related to your intended search terms but fall outside of the realm of what you offer or want to rank for. \n<br> <h3>9. PPC</h3> <p>Pay-per-click, or PPC, is a type of advertising where the advertiser pays per click on an ad. PPC is not specific to Google Ads, but it is the most common type of paid campaign. It’s important to understand the ins and outs of PPC before launching your first Google Ads campaign.</p> <h3>10. Quality Score (QS)</h3> <p>Your Quality Score measures the quality of your ad by your click-through rate (CTR), the relevance of your keywords, the quality of your landing page, and your past performance on the SERP. QS is a determining factor in your AdRank.</p> <p><em><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/google-adwords-ppc?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase\">Click to get our free guide on how to use Google Ads.</a></em><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/google-adwords-ppc\"></a></p> <a></a> <h2>How does Google Ads work?</h2> <p>Google Ads displays your ad to potential leads or customers who are interested in your product or service. Advertisers bid on search terms, or keywords, and the winners of that bid are placed at the top of search results pages, on YouTube videos, or on relevant websites, depending on the type of ad campaign selected.</p> <p>Many factors impact your ability to create effective and high-performing Google Ads. Let’s cover them below, plus some Google Ads examples.</p> <a></a> <h3>AdRank and Quality Score</h3> <p>AdRank determines the placement of your ads, and Quality Score is one of the two factors (the other being bid amount) that determines your AdRank. Remember, your Quality Score is based on the quality and relevance of your ad, and Google measures that by how many people click on your ad when it’s displayed — i.e. your CTR. You CTR depends on the how well your ad matches searcher intent, which you can deduce from three areas:</p> \n <ol> \n  <li>The relevance of your keywords</li> \n  <li>If your ad copy and CTA deliver what the searcher expects based on their search</li> \n  <li>The user experience of your landing page</li> \n </ol> <p>Your QS is where you should focus most of your attention when you first set up your Google Ad campaign — even before you increase your bid amount. The higher your QS, the lower your acquisition costs will be and the better placement you’ll get.</p> <h3>Location</h3> <p>When you first set up your Google Ad, you’ll select a geographical area where your ad will be shown. If you have a storefront, this should be in a reasonable radius around your physical location. If you have an ecommerce store and a physical product, your location should be set in the places where you ship. If you provide a service or product that is accessible worldwide, then the sky's the limit.</p> <p>Your location settings will play a role in placement. For instance, if you own a yoga studio in San Francisco, someone in New York that enters “yoga studio” will not see your result, no matter your AdRank. That’s because Google’s main objective is to display the most relevant results to searchers, even when you’re paying.</p> <a></a> <h3>Keywords</h3> <p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-do-keyword-research-ht\">Keyword research</a> is just as important for paid ads as it is for organic search. Your keywords need to match searcher intent as much as possible. That’s because Google matches your ad with search queries based on the keywords you selected.</p> <p>Each ad group that you create within your campaign will target a small set of keywords (one to five keywords is optimal) and Google will display your ad based on those selections.</p> <h4>Match Types</h4> <p>Match Types give you a little wiggle room when it comes to your keyword selections — they tell Google whether you want to match a search query exactly or if your ad should be shown to anyone with a search query that’s semi-related. There are four match types to choose from:</p> \n <ul> \n  <li><strong>Broad Match</strong> is the default setting that uses any word within your keyword phrase in any order. For example, “goat yoga in Oakland” will match “goat yoga” or “yoga Oakland.”</li> \n  <li><strong>Modified Broad Match</strong> allows you to lock in certain words within a keyword phrase by denoting them with a “+” sign. Your matches will include that locked-in word at the very least. For example, “+goats yoga in Oakland” could yield “goats,” “goats like food,” or “goats and yoga.”</li> \n  <li><strong>Phrase Match</strong> will match with queries that include your keyword phrase in the exact order but may include additional words before or after it. For example, “goat yoga” can yield “spotted goat yoga” or “goat yoga with puppies.”</li> \n  <li><strong>Exact Match</strong> maintains your keyword phrase as it is written in the exact order. For example, “goat yoga” will not show up if someone types “goats yoga” or “goat yoga class.”</li> \n </ul> <p>If you’re just starting out and don’t know exactly how your persona will be searching, move from a broad match to a more narrow approach so you can test which queries yield the best results. However, since your ad will be ranking for many queries (some unrelated) you should keep a close eye on your ads and modify them as you can gain new information.</p> <a></a> <h3>Headline and Description</h3> <p>Your ad copy can be the difference between a click on your ad and a click on your competitor’s ad. It’s important that your ad copy matches the searcher’s intent, is aligned with your target keywords, and addresses the personas pain point with a clear solution.</p> <p>To illustrate what we mean, let’s review an example.</p> <p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/baby%20swim%20lessons%20-%20Google%20Search%202019-03-02%2011-17-04.png?width=1500&amp;name=baby%20swim%20lessons%20-%20Google%20Search%202019-03-02%2011-17-04.png\" alt=\"google ads copy and headline\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> <p>A search for “baby swim lessons” yielded this result. The copy is concise and uses the limited space wisely to convey their message and connect with their target audience.</p> <p>The Swim Revolution knew to put the keyword in their headline so we instantly know that this ad matches what we’re looking for. The description tells us why this is the best option for swim lessons because it addresses the concerns of their persona — a parent looking to enroll their baby in a swim class.</p> <p>They use words like “skills,” “fun,” “confidence,” and “comfort in the water” to ease our nerves about putting a baby in a pool and to prove to us that we will get what we want out of this class — an infant that can swim.</p> <p>This kind of ad copy will get you clicks, but conversions will result from carrying this level of intention into your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/landing-page-best-practices\">landing page copy</a>.</p> <a></a> <h3>Ad Extensions</h3> <p>If you’re running Google Ads, you should be using Ad Extensions for two reasons: they’re free, and they give users additional information and another reason to interact with your ad. These extensions fall within one of these five categories:</p> \n <ul> \n  <li><strong>Sitelink Extensions</strong> extend your add — helping you stand out — and provide additional links to your site that offer users more enticing reasons to click.<br><br><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-02-28%20at%202.26.34%20PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-02-28%20at%202.26.34%20PM.png\" alt=\"google ads sitelink extensions\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></br></br></li> \n  <li><strong>Call Extensions</strong> allow you to incorporate your phone number in your ad so users have an additional (and instant) way to reach out to you. If you have a customer service team that is ready to engage and convert your audience, then include your phone number.<br><br><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-02-28%20at%202.29.00%20PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-02-28%20at%202.29.00%20PM.png\" alt=\"google ads call extensions\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></br></br></li> \n  <li><strong>Location Extensions</strong> include your location and phone number within your ad so Google can offer searchers a map to easily find you. This option is great for businesses with a storefront and it works well for the search query “...near me.”<br><br><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-02-28%20at%202.30.27%20PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-02-28%20at%202.30.27%20PM.png\" alt=\"google ads location extensions\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></br></br></li> \n  <li><strong>Offer Extensions</strong> work if you’re running a current promotion. It can entice users to click your ad over others if they see that your options are discounted compared to your competitors.<br><br><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-02-28%20at%202.33.13%20PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-02-28%20at%202.33.13%20PM.png\" alt=\"google ads offer extensions\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></br></br></li> \n  <li><strong>App Extensions</strong> provide a link to an app download for mobile users. This reduces the friction from having to perform a new search to find and download the app in an AppStore.<br><br><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/IMG_2202.PNG%202019-03-02%2011-41-54-2.png?width=500&amp;name=IMG_2202.PNG%202019-03-02%2011-41-54-2.png\" alt=\"google ads app extensions\" width=\"500\" style=\"width: 500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></br></br></li> \n </ul> <h3>Google Ads Retargeting</h3> <p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/retargeting-ideas\">Retargeting</a> (or remarketing) in Google Ads is a way to advertise to users who have previously interacted with you online but have not yet converted. Tracking cookies will follow users around the web and target these users with your ads. Remarketing is effective since prospects need to see your marketing at least seven times before they become a customer.</p> <a></a> <p><span style=\"color: #33475b;\"></span></p> <p>You can select from one of five campaign types on Google Ads. Let’s cover the optimal uses for each and why you might choose one over the other.</p> <h3>1. Search Ad Campaigns</h3> <p>Search ads are text ads that are displayed on Google results pages. As an example, a search for “pocket squares” returns sponsored results:</p> <p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-09-17%20at%201.42.25%20PM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-09-17%20at%201.42.25%20PM.png\" alt=\"types of google ads search ads campaigns\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> <p>The benefit of search ads is that you’re displaying your ad in the place where most searchers look for information first — on Google. And Google shows your ad in the same format as other results (except for denoting it as an “Ad”) so users are accustomed to seeing and clicking on results.</p> <h4><strong>Responsive Search Ads</strong></h4> <p><a href=\"https://support.google.com/google-ads/answer/7684791?hl=en\">Responsive search ads</a> allow you to enter multiple versions of headlines and ad copy (15 and four variations, respectively) for Google to select the best performers to display to users. With traditional ads, create one static version of your ad, using the same headline and description each time.</p> <p>Responsive ads allow for a dynamic ad that is auto-tested until you arrive at the version that is best suited for your target audience — for Google, that means until you get the most clicks.</p> <h3>2. Display Ad Campaigns</h3> <p>Google has a network of websites in various industries and with an array of audiences that opt in to display Google Ads, known as the <a href=\"https://support.google.com/google-ads/answer/2404190?hl=en-GB\">Google Display Network</a>. The benefit to the website owner is that they’re paid per click or impression on the ads. The benefit to advertisers is that they can get their content in front of audiences that are aligned with their personas.</p> <p>These are typically image ads that draw users attention away from the content on the webpage:</p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-02-27%20at%207.30.46%20PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-02-27%20at%207.30.46%20PM.png\" alt=\"google ads display ad\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://alittlebitoflacquer.blogspot.com/\" style=\"font-size: 13px;\"><em>Source</em></a></p> <h3>3. Video Ad Campaigns</h3> <p>Video ads are displayed before or after (and sometimes in the middle of) <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-video-advertising-guide\">YouTube videos</a>. Remember, YouTube is a search engine, too. The right keywords will place you in front of a video, disrupting the user’s behavior just enough to grab their attention.</p> <p>Here's a video advertisement that pops up in the middle of another video on how to tie a tie:</p> <p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-09-15%20at%204.19.59%20PM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-09-15%20at%204.19.59%20PM.png\" alt=\"google ads video ads youtube\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> <p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-video-advertising-guide\"><em>Source</em></a></p> <h3>4. App Ad Campaigns</h3> <p><a href=\"https://ads.google.com/home/campaigns/app-ads/\">Google App Campaigns</a> promote your mobile application through an ad displayed on Google Search Network, YouTube, Google Play, Google Display Network, and more. You can run ads that encourage your audience to install your app or, if they already use it, to take a certain action within your app.</p> <p>Unlike other ad types, you don't design an App ad campaign. Instead, provide Google with your app's information and audience, and place a bid. Google does the rest to get your app in front of the right eyes:</p> <p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-09-17%20at%201.38.58%20PM-1.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-09-17%20at%201.38.58%20PM-1.png\" alt=\"types of google ads app ads campaigns\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://marketingland.com/search-ads-in-google-play-store-go-live-globally-136919\"><em><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\">Source</span></em></a></p> <h3>5. Shopping Ad Campaigns</h3> <p>Another type of Google Ad is Google Shopping Ad Campaigns. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-shopping\">Shopping campaigns</a>, like these other types of ads, are displayed on SERPs and include detailed product information such as price and product imagery. You can <a href=\"https://support.google.com/merchants/answer/2660968?hl=en\">run a Shopping campaign</a> through Google Merchant Center, where you input specific product information that Google pulls from to create your shopping ads.</p> <p>Instead of marketing your brand as a whole, Shopping Ads allow you to promote specific products and product lines. That's why, when you search for a particular product on Google, you'll see ads for different brands pop up along the top and/or side. This is what I see when I search \"running shoes.\" The ads at the top are Google Search ads, but the specific products advertised on the side are Shopping ads optimized for the keyword \"running shoes\":</p> <p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-09-17%20at%201.49.19%20PM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-09-17%20at%201.49.19%20PM.png\" alt=\"types of google ads google shopping ads\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> <a></a> <h2>How to Use and Create Google Ads</h2> <p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33283/a-simple-guide-for-setting-up-your-first-google-adwords-campaign.aspx\">Setting up your paid campaigns</a> on Google is relatively easy (and quick), mostly because the platform takes you through the setup and provides helpful hints along the way. Once you visit the <a href=\"https://ads.google.com/\">Google Ads site</a> and click “Start Now,” you’ll be taken through a series of steps to get your ads up and running. If you have your ad copy and/or images created, set up should take you no more than 10 minutes.</p> <p>What may be less obvious are all the additional things you need to do to make sure your ads are optimally set up and easily trackable. Let’s cover these together. These are the steps you’ll take once your ads are submitted for review.</p> <h3>1. Link Google Analytics.</h3> <p>You likely have <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-install-google-analytics-tracking-code-website-ht\">Google Analytics set up on your website</a> so you can track traffic, conversions, goals, and any unique metrics. You also need to <a href=\"https://support.google.com/google-ads/answer/6209127?hl=en\">link your Analytics account to Google Ads</a>. Linking these accounts will make tracking, analyzing, and reporting between channels and campaigns much easier because you can view these events in one place.</p> <p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-09-17%20at%201.55.29%20PM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-09-17%20at%201.55.29%20PM.png\" alt=\"google ads link google analytics\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> <h3>2. Add UTM codes.</h3> <p>Urchin Tracking Module (UTM) codes are used by Google to track any activity associated with a specific link. You’ve probably seen them before — it’s the part of a URL that follows a question mark (“?”). UTM codes will tell you which offer or ad led to a conversion so you can track the most effective parts of your campaign. UTM codes make it easier to optimize your Google Ads since you know exactly what’s working.</p> <p>The trick, though, is to <a href=\"https://adespresso.com/guides/google-ads-beginners/account-setup/\">add your UTM codes at the campaign level</a> when you set up your Google Ads so you don’t have to do so manually for each ad URL. Otherwise, you can add them manually with <a href=\"https://ga-dev-tools.appspot.com/campaign-url-builder/\">Google’s UTM builder</a>.</p> <p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-09-17%20at%201.56.02%20PM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-09-17%20at%201.56.02%20PM.png\" alt=\"google ads set up utm codes google campaign url builder\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> <h3>3. Set up conversion tracking.</h3> <p>Conversion tracking tells you exactly how many customers or leads you’ve acquired from your ad campaigns. It’s not mandatory to set up but, without it, you’ll be guessing the ROI of your ads. <a href=\"https://support.google.com/google-ads/answer/1722054?hl=en\">Conversion tracking</a> allows you to track sales (or other activities) on your website, app installs, or calls from your ads.</p> <p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-09-17%20at%201.56.55%20PM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-09-17%20at%201.56.55%20PM.png\" alt=\"google ads conversion tracking\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> <p><em><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/template-managing-and-organizing-google-adwords-campaigns?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase\">Manage and organize your ads with our free Google Ads Kit and Templates</a>.</em></p> <h3>4. Integrate your Google Ads with your CRM.</h3> <p>There is something to be said about keeping all of your data in one place where you can track, analyze, and report on it. You already use your CRM to track contact data and lead flows. <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/integrations/google-ads\">Integrating Google Ads with your CRM</a> gives you the ability to track which ad campaigns are working for your audience so you can continue marketing to them with offers that are relevant.</p> <p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-09-17%20at%201.57.54%20PM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-09-17%20at%201.57.54%20PM.png\" alt=\"google ads integration hubspot crm\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> <p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/advertising/google-ads\"><em>Source</em></a></p> <a></a> <h2>Google Ads Bidding Strategies</h2> <p>Once you’ve set up your ad campaigns and have tracking in place, it’s time to start bidding. Remember, your ability to rank in Google Ads depends on how you bid. While your bid amount will depend on your budget and goals, there are a few strategies and bid settings you should be aware of when launching your paid campaign.</p> <h3>Automated vs. Manual Bidding</h3> <p>You have two options when it comes to bidding on your keywords — automated and manual. Here’s how they work:</p> \n <ul> \n  <li><strong>Automated Bidding</strong> puts Google in the driver’s seat and allows the platform to adjust your bid based on your competitors. You can still set a maximum budget, and Google will work within a range to give you the best chance at winning the bid within those constraints.</li> \n  <li><strong>Manual Bidding</strong> let’s you set the bid amounts for your ad groups and keywords, giving you the chance to reduce spending on low-performing ads.</li> \n </ul> <h3>Bidding on Branded Search Terms</h3> <p>Branded terms are those with your company or unique product name in them, like “HubSpot CRM.” There is much debate on whether to bid on your branded terms or not. On one side of the debate, bidding on terms that will likely yield organic results could be seen as a waste of money.</p> <p>On the other side, bidding on these terms gives you domain over these search results pages and helps you convert prospects that are further along the flywheel. For instance, if I’ve been doing research on live chat tools and am heavily considering <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/crm/live-chat\">HubSpot’s Live Chat</a>, then a simple search for “HubSpot live chat software” will yield exactly the result I’m looking for without the effort of scrolling.</p> <p>The other argument in favor of bidding on your branded terms is that competitors may bid on them if you don’t, thereby taking up valuable real estate that should belong to you.</p> <h3>Cost Per Acquisition (CPA)</h3> <p>If the idea of spending money to convert prospects into leads makes you uneasy, then you can set a CPA instead and only pay when a user converts into a customer. While this bidding strategy could cost more, you can take comfort in knowing that you only pay when you acquire a paying customer. This strategy makes it easy to track and justify your ad spend.</p> <h2>Additional Resources to Optimize Your Google Ads</h2> <p>Your ad copy and headline is not the only component that will make your paid campaign successful. Getting a user to click is only the beginning … they should arrive on a landing page that’s optimized for conversion and then be taken to a <em>Thank You</em> page that tells them what to do next.</p> <p>If you want your Google Ads to produce qualified leads and customers, then check out these additional resources and use them as guidelines as you set up your Google Ads campaign.</p> \n <ul> \n  <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/landing-page-best-practices\">Landing Page Best Practices</a> will teach you how to set up a landing page that’s prime for conversions so you don’t waste those precious clicks.</li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/30650/the-anatomy-of-conversion-optimized-thank-you-pages.aspx\">Optimized “Thank You” Pages</a> shows you what to do with your new lead post-conversion, how to keep them on your site, and ways to maintain their attention.</li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/enhanced-campaigns-how-to-create-mobile-ads-in-adwords\">Tips for Mobile Google Ads</a> teaches you the key differences between desktop and mobile ads and how to optimize both.</li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-ads-cost\">Optimizing Google Ads Costs</a> will show you how we, at HubSpot, maximize our Google Ads spend to get the best ROI.</li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/build-the-best-google-adwords-campaign\">Quality Google Ads Examples That Convert</a> shares examples of Google advertising campaigns that got it right.</li> \n </ul> <h2>Start Your Campaign</h2> <p>Given its reach and authority, Google Ads should be a part of your paid strategy. Use the tips we covered to get started, and remember to refine and iterate as you go.</p> <p>There’s no such thing as a Google Ads campaign that doesn’t work — there are only ones that need a bit more work. Using the strategy and information provided above, you have what you need to create a successful Google Ad campaign that drives clicks and converts leads.</p> <p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in November 2015 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> <img
