\">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 02 Oct 2020 21:30:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"6c79aa21a6496537c5be3ee05ce9ebf3","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Caroline Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/7%20Tips%20for%20Running%20Engaging%20Instagram%20Giveaways,%20Plus%20Examples%20and%20Ideas-1.png?width=600&name=7%20Tips%20for%20Running%20Engaging%20Instagram%20Giveaways,%20Plus%20Examples%20and%20Ideas-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn23@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-50-833_640954db7425000c.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/7%20Tips%20for%20Running%20Engaging%20Instagram%20Giveaways,%20Plus%20Examples%20and%20Ideas-4.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn31@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-49-353_a5fa02976204b895.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/7%20Tips%20for%20Running%20Engaging%20Instagram%20Giveaways,%20Plus%20Examples%20and%20Ideas.png?width=600&name=7%20Tips%20for%20Running%20Engaging%20Instagram%20Giveaways,%20Plus%20Examples%20and%20Ideas.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn97@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-45-859_e81eb4b162103f33.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/7%20Tips%20for%20Running%20Engaging%20Instagram%20Giveaways,%20Plus%20Examples%20and%20Ideas-6.png?width=600&name=7%20Tips%20for%20Running%20Engaging%20Instagram%20Giveaways,%20Plus%20Examples%20and%20Ideas-6.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn65@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-51-980_d7a49a4107b74c7f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/7%20Tips%20for%20Running%20Engaging%20Instagram%20Giveaways,%20Plus%20Examples%20and%20Ideas-3.png?width=600&name=7%20Tips%20for%20Running%20Engaging%20Instagram%20Giveaways,%20Plus%20Examples%20and%20Ideas-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn47@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-48-794_3e0a89740585939a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/7%20Tips%20for%20Running%20Engaging%20Instagram%20Giveaways,%20Plus%20Examples%20and%20Ideas-5.png?width=600&name=7%20Tips%20for%20Running%20Engaging%20Instagram%20Giveaways,%20Plus%20Examples%20and%20Ideas-5.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn39@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-52-526_ba4cb8198680a098.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/7%20Tips%20for%20Running%20Engaging%20Instagram%20Giveaways,%20Plus%20Examples%20and%20Ideas-2.png?width=600&name=7%20Tips%20for%20Running%20Engaging%20Instagram%20Giveaways,%20Plus%20Examples%20and%20Ideas-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn43@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-48-078_485daeaa81e12df3.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Finstagram-giveaway&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn4@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-45-749_e5dbf3d705b43ba1.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389701},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"Why Overworking Is Bad For Your Health (and Your Career)","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/overwork-bad-health","description":"<p>There's no doubt that technology has simplified the way we carry out our day-to-day routines.&nbsp;Computers help us do&nbsp;things faster, emails and text messages<span>&nbsp;let us always be in touch, and&nbsp;</span>the internet makes it easy to&nbsp;find the answer to any question with&nbsp;<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/1264/12-Quick-Tips-To-Search-Google-Like-An-Expert.aspx\">just a quick Google search</a>.</p> \n<p>While being&nbsp;constantly plugged in&nbsp;can make us feel safe, connected, and in-the-know -- both at work and at home -- it also means we never <em>really</em>&nbsp;clock out.</p> \n<p><span class=\"content-post__body\">It's one thing to pull a long day every once in a while to finish a project or deal with a crisis, but it's another to routinely stay late at the office or work into the night. That's chronic overwork -- and it can have extremely negative impacts on your health, happiness, and overall quality of life.</span></p> \n<p>But w<span>orking overtime has become the norm for most people. And, now that multiple offices have embraced remote work, the lines between the end of the work day and the start of personal time can get even blurrier.</span></p> \n<p><span> It's&nbsp;</span>one of those things everyone knows is bad for us, but no one really listens. Trouble is, failure to prioritize a healthy balance isn't just bad for the employees -- it's actually bad for employers, too.</p> \n<p>There are numerous research studies out there showing how overwork -- and its resulting stress -- can lead to many health problems. But, it also impacts your brand's bigger business too. Read on to learn exactly why it's bad for health <em>and&nbsp;</em>our performance at work.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span><span>Why Overworking is&nbsp;Bad For Your Health</span></span></span></span></h2> \n<h3>1. It prevents sleep.</h3> \n<p><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span><span><span><span><span><a href=\"https://hbr.org/2009/10/dont-overwork-your-brain\">S</a>tudy after study shows that working too much or too late in the day can negatively impact your sleep -- w<span>hether it's the resulting stress, the staring at the computer screen, or just not having enough time to unwind before&nbsp;</span><span>hitting the hay. </span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></p> \n<p><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span><span><span><span><span><span>Avoiding sleep can cause us to build up \"sleep debt</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>.\" Essentially, it feels like your energy is overdrawn for days at a time until you get a proper eight hours of sleep.</p> \n<p>Chronic sleep debt <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/science-of-sleep\">raises the risk</a> of obesity, heart disease, stroke, and diabetes. In the short-term, lack of sleep <a href=\"https://www.webmd.com/sleep-disorders/sleep-requirements\">can have significant effects</a> on the hippocampus, an area of the brain involved in memory creation and consolidation.</p> \n<p><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span><span><span><span>Think you're one of those \"lucky people\" who can get by fine with only five or six hours of sleep? You probably aren't. While <a href=\"https://www.nih.gov/news-events/nih-research-matters/gene-identified-people-who-need-little-sleep\">researchers have found gene</a>s in people that enable them to be well rested after less than eight hours of sleep, they also say incidence&nbsp;of either <a href=\"https://www.nih.gov/news-events/nih-research-matters/gene-identified-people-who-need-little-sleep\">is incredibly rare</a>.</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></p> \n<h3><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span><span><span><span>2. Overworking gets in the way of good habits.</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></h3> \n<p><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span><span><span><span><span>Working too much can take a toll on the body and brain in two ways -- by boosting stress and by getting in the way of exercise, healthy eating, and other good habits.</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></p> \n<p>For example, when you’re overtired, you rely more on caffeine to get you through the day, you tend to make unhealthy food choices and working out becomes a thing of the past.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://health.clevelandclinic.org/how-stress-can-make-you-eat-more-or-not-at-all/\">Cleveland Clinic reports</a> that stress due to overworking or lack of sleep can cause you to overreat or make poor diet choices. But how does this happen?</p> \n<p>First, overworking and lack of sleep slows activity in the areas of our brains responsible for ranking different foods based on what we want and need.</p> \n<p>Second, little sleep also causes an increase in the brain's amygdala, which is responsible for controlling the salience of food. Over time, poor food choices can lead to weight gain and even obesity.</p> \n<h3><span class=\"content-post__body\">3. Overworking is bad for your heart.</span></h3> \n<p><a href=\"http://www.ucl.ac.uk/news/news-articles/1005/10051205#sthash.ljtjvuTF.dpuf\">A&nbsp;long-running study of more than 10,000 civil servants in London found</a> that white-collar workers&nbsp;who worked three or more hours longer than a normal, seven-hour day had a 60% higher risk of heart-related problems than&nbsp;white-collar workers who didn't work overtime. Examples of heart-related problems included&nbsp;death due to heart disease, non-fatal heart attacks, and angina, a condition caused by low blood supply to the heart.</p> \n<p><span><a href=\"http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22952309\">A follow-up study of over 22,000 participants found</a> that people who worked long hours were </span>40% more likely to suffer from coronary heart disease<span> than those who worked standard hours.</span></p> \n<p>And even after that, <a href=\"https://www.webmd.com/balance/stress-management/news/20180716/working-yourself-to-death-long-hours-bring-risks\">reports from health sites like WebMD</a> still tell stories of people who developed heart conditions through overworking.</p> \n<p>What about overworking might be causing heart disease, specifically?</p> \n<p>The link between overworking and heart disease might have something to do with your personality. In fact, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/a-b-personality-types\">the \"Type A vs. Type B\" personality test </a>was&nbsp;<span>originally aimed to determine&nbsp;how likely it was that a person would develop coronary heart disease. Considering Type A folks tend to be more&nbsp;</span>competitive, tense, time-oriented, and stressed out -- which is often intensified by overworking -- their personality type is often associated with a higher risk.</p> \n<h3><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span><span><span><span><span><span>4. It leads to bad habits.</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></h3> \n<p><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span><span><span><span><span><span>Aside from health risks, research done in the last decade has shown how overworking links to bad habits that are also unhealthy.</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></p> \n<p>Even back in 2015, the Finish Institute of Occupational Health published <a href=\"https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn26793-long-hours-make-people-more-likely-to-drink-heavily#.VSLlF5N4r6c\">the largest ever study</a> of the correlation between working patterns and alcohol consumption. In the study, a group of researchers put together a dataset of over 330,000 workers across 14 different countries.</p> \n<p>They found that&nbsp;48 hours of work per week was the magic number: When people worked more than 48 hours per week, they were more likely to engage in \"increased risky alcohol use.\" Risky alcohol use was defined as more than 14 drinks per week for women and more than 21 drinks per week for men.</p> \n<p>Aside from alcohol consumption, <a href=\"https://www.webmd.com/balance/stress-management/news/20180716/working-yourself-to-death-long-hours-bring-risks\">researchers have also found</a> that long hours link to bad smoking habits.</p> \n<p>And a 2018 paper from Welltory added to the list of bad habits by showing that overworking can also lead to <a href=\"https://drive.google.com/file/d/1hNEZpNrVhtH0ITpRxQLHQHYqT-bf5JRD/view\">more social media consumption</a>, which can danger your level of stress recover when you're not working.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3><span class=\"content-post__body\">5. It causes higher risks for low-income workers.</span></h3> \n<p>Way back in 2015, a group of researchers investigated the role of long working hours as a risk factor for type 2 diabetes. <a href=\"http://www.thelancet.com/journals/landia/article/PIIS2213-8587%2814%2970178-0/abstract\">They found that the link between longer working hours and type 2 diabetes is apparent in individuals in the low socioeconomic status groups. This was true regardless of age, sex, obesity, and physical activity, and remained even when they excluded shift workers from the analysis. Shortly after, another study showed an association between long hours and type 2 </a><a href=\"http://www.thelancet.com/journals/landia/article/PIIS2213-8587%2814%2970178-0/abstract\">diabetes</a><span> in low-income workers.</span></p> \n<p>Overall, these findings show how strong of a relationship a person's mental state can have on physical health.</p> \n<h2>Why Overworking is Bad for Business</h2> \n<p>If better health and happiness isn't enough of an incentive to do something about chronic overwork, it turns out overworking can have a legitimately negative impact on a business' bottom line. Sarah Green Carmichael of <em>Harvard Business Review</em> <a href=\"https://hbr.org/2015/08/the-research-is-clear-long-hours-backfire-for-people-and-for-companies\">calls the story of overwork</a> \"the story of diminishing returns\": keep overworking, and you'll keep making avoidable mistakes and getting lost in the weeds -- all while not actually producing more.</p> \n<h3>6. More input doesn't necessarily mean more output.</h3> \n<p>Do longer work hours equate to&nbsp;more work getting done?&nbsp;From time to time, yes -- but not when \"overtime\" becomes \"all the time.\"</p> \n<p><a href=\"http://www.hcgexperts.com/scheduled-overtime-effect-on-construction-projects.php\">Research by the Business Roundtable found</a> employees saw short-term gains when they pushed their workweek to 60 or 70 hours for a few weeks at a time if, for example, they needed to meet a critical production deadline. But increasing the number of hours worked in the office from 40 to 60 hours doesn't result in more output: \"In fact, the numbers may typically be something closer to 25–30% more work in 50% more time,\" <a href=\"http://www.salon.com/2012/03/14/bring_back_the_40_hour_work_week/\">writes Sara Robinson for&nbsp;</a><em><a href=\"http://www.salon.com/2012/03/14/bring_back_the_40_hour_work_week/\">Salon</a>.</em></p> \n<p>Why? Robinson&nbsp;explains that most people do their best work between hours two and six of working in a given day. By the end of an eight-hour day, their best work tends to be behind them -- and by hour nine, fatigue begins to set in and productivity levels drop. They won't be able to deliver to their full potential -- especially if they aren't invigorated by something like a rare, critical deadline -- and they'll end the day completely exhausted.</p> \n<p>Interestingly, <a href=\"http://pubsonline.informs.org/doi/abs/10.1287/orsc.2015.0975\">one study out of Boston University's Questrom School of Business found</a> that managers actually couldn't tell the difference between employees who actually worked 80 hours per week and those who just pretended to. What's more, managers tended to punish employees who were transparent about working less -- but there was no evidence that those employees actually accomplished less, nor were there any signs that the overworking employees accomplished more.</p> \n<h3>7. You're more likely to make mistakes.</h3> \n<p>Speaking of exhaustion, <a href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6617405/\">researchers have found</a> that overwork -- and the resulting stress and exhaustion -- can make it far more difficult to do everything that a modern office requires, including interpersonal communication, making judgment calls, reading people, or <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/emotional-intelligence-tips\">managing one's own emotional reactions</a>. Aside from small office slip ups, research from NCBI even shows that overworking can lead to <a href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6617405/\">physical injuries in the workplace</a>.</p> \n<h3>8. You lose sight of the bigger picture.</h3> \n<p>Have you ever worked on a project so long that you began to obsess over it and forget about everything else related to your role or personal life? Many marketers have been there.</p> \n<p>The breaks we take to recharge, eat meals, or spend time with the people we love help us step back from our work and stay mindful of how our work contributes to our goals.</p> \n<h3>9. Overworking hinders creativity.</h3> \n<p>As marketers, we're sought after for our creative and colorful ideas, messaging, and content. But, this type of work takes a lot of time, energy, and open-mindedness.</p> \n<p>Unfortunately, <a href=\"https://www.thecut.com/2018/11/losing-sleep-creativity.html\">lack of sleep, stress, and other issues</a> caused by overworking can drain your energy, motivation, and, ultimately, your level of creativity.</p> \n<p>If you want to stay fresh and creative, it's important to limit your work hours, get a good night's sleep, and take time off when you feel like your mind is being drained of creative thoughts.</p> \n<p>When you do take time off, be sure to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-stay-creative-under-pressure\">keep a notepad or a phone recording </a>app nearby. Sometimes, creative ideas can strike when you're most relaxed -- and you'll want to take them down somewhere.</p> \n<h3>10. It makes multitasking harder.</h3> \n<p>As we mentioned above, overworking raises the risk of making silly mistakes. This risk gets even higher when you're working on multiple projects all at once.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Multitasking is one of the commodities of a modern marketing role. Each day, we might send out an email, update social media, write a long-form blog post, attend multiple video meetings, and monitor the analytics of what we're doing.</p> \n<p>When you're tired, low on energy, and not primed to pay attention to detail, it will be harder to complete all of your tasks correctly -- let alone one of them.&nbsp;</p> \n<h2>Who's to Blame?</h2> \n<p>Chronically overworking isn't fun.&nbsp;It doesn't feel<em>good;</em>to&nbsp;realize you have to work through yet another family dinner or relaxing weekend.</p> \n<p>So why do people do it? Is it because our bosses told us to?&nbsp;Or because we want to make more money? Or do we have some deep-seated psychological need? In <a href=\"https://hbr.org/2015/08/the-research-is-clear-long-hours-backfire-for-people-and-for-companies\">her article for</a><em><a href=\"https://hbr.org/2015/08/the-research-is-clear-long-hours-backfire-for-people-and-for-companies\"> Harvard Business Review</a>,</em> Carmichael asks, \"who's to blame?\"</p> \n<h3>Over-ambitious managers?</h3> \n<p>In many cultures,&nbsp;bosses want and expect employees to put in long days, make themselves available on email 24/7,&nbsp;and work nights, weekends, and during vacation without protest. In this version, writes Carmichael, we overwork because we're told to.</p> \n<p>This is&nbsp;<span>especially evident in the three countries in which employees </span><a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/she-the-people/wp/2014/02/21/5-things-you-get-from-working-too-hard/\">work the longest hours</a><span> of all advanced countries in the world:&nbsp;<span>America, South Korea, and Japan.</span></span></p> \n<h3><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span><span>... Or ourselves?</span></span></span></span></h3> \n<p>Some of us overwork even when our managers don't want us too, And, truthfully, most of us can't put all the blame on others.</p> \n<p>More often than not, working long hours is a way for us to prove something to ourselves. Maybe working late makes us feel ambitious or important. Maybe it's because we think it's the only way to get a promotion, make more money, or avoid falling behind. Maybe we straight up feel guilty when we get up and leave at 5 P.M.&nbsp;<a href=\"http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2014/07/15/330191097/when-work-becomes-a-haven-from-stress-at-home\">Several studies have even shown</a> some of us consider w<span>ork a safe haven -- a place in which we feel confident and in control as compared with stresses&nbsp;outside the office.</span></p> \n<p>And who could blame us? More and more, working beyond normal business hours has become something people brag about. In some cases, it becomes an addiction.</p> \n<p><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span>\"We live in a competitive society,\" <a href=\"http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970203358704577237603853394654\">writes Laura Vanderkam for </a><em><a href=\"http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970203358704577237603853394654\">The Wall Street Journal,</a>&nbsp;</em>\"and so by lamenting our overwork and sleep deprivation -- even if that requires workweek inflation and claiming our worst nights are typical -- we show that we are dedicated to our jobs and our families.\"</span></span></p> \n<h2>Know When It's Time to Log Off</h2> Sometimes, working long hours can feel rewarding -- even invigorating. Other times, especially when we make a habit out of it, it can make us feel stressed, mad, lonely, and generally unhealthy. \n<p>The key is paying attention to how it makes you feel. If it's interfering with your mental, physical, or emotional help, it may be time to&nbsp;reprioritize.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's Note: This blog post was originally published in June 2016, but was updated for comprehensiveness and freshness in October 2020.</em></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Foverwork-bad-health&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 07 Oct 2020 21:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"f722274a025082f99067d2b59346de87","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"lkolowich@hubspot.com (Lindsay Kolowich Cox)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Foverwork-bad-health&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn81@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-48-414_9e5905fb38002ccf.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389706},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"Why Consumers Sign Up for Webinars [New Data]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/why-consumers-sign-up-for-webinars","description":"<p>In 2020, brands are <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/run-successful-virtual-conference\">leveraging virtual events</a> more than ever.</p>  \n<p>And, although some marketers once believed that \"<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/are-webinars-dead-how-to-make-a-webinar\">webinars were dead</a>,” many are now rethinking that statement as they find themselves scheduling and promoting this exact type of event.</p> \n<p>Webinars, or online events often modeled like a class or seminar, often include a lesson, slide deck, interactive elements such as polls, and, occasionally, time for audience members to virtually ask questions.</p> \n<p>Because of their educational format, webinars can offer a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/are-webinars-dead-how-to-make-a-webinar\">number of great perks to brands</a>.</p> \n<p>First, you can build a sense of credibility by hosting a webinar on a topic your company has expertise in. Second, webinars can enable your fans to interact with you digitally.</p> \n<p>Lastly, and most importantly, webinar signups can <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/are-webinars-dead-how-to-make-a-webinar\">lead to a bigger contact list, more prospects, or purchasing conversions</a>.</p> \n<p>But webinars <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/are-webinars-dead-how-to-make-a-webinar\">aren't always easy to plan and execute</a>.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Because webinars require viewers to sign up and remember to tune in, it takes <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-promote-a-virtual-event\">clever marketing</a> to ensure that a large audience actually attends. Additionally, with most brands going virtual in 2020, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-promote-a-virtual-event\">a number of competitors in your space</a> might very well be planning a similar webinar that your audiences might be more drawn to.</p> \n<p>Luckily, by researching your target audience, and learning more about what drives attendees to sign up for webinars, you can create and promote an event that effectively pulls in and delights your audiences.</p> \n<p>So, where do you start?</p> \n<p>To help you research the best webinar tactics for your brand, I surveyed 400 consumers about their webinar preferences and what motivates them to attend these virtual events. In this blog post, I'll highlight a few key findings that you can keep in mind as you develop and promote your webinar content.</p> \n<h2>What Consumers Say About Webinars in 2020</h2> \n<h3>People want webinars that help them explore their passions.</h3> \n<p>When choosing which webinars to sign up for, are people drawn mostly to events that help them elevate their career, or are they attending them for more recreational purposes?</p> \n<p>To learn more about consumers' motivations for attending a webinar, I asked 400 consumers, \"Which webinars are you most likely to attend in 2020?\", 27% chose, \"Webinars that teach me more about a passion or hobby;\" while 24% chose, \"Webinars that entertain me.\"</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Why%20Consumers%20Sign%20Up%20for%20Webinars%20%5BNew%20Data%5D.png?width=600&amp;name=Why%20Consumers%20Sign%20Up%20for%20Webinars%20%5BNew%20Data%5D.png\" alt=\"which webinar would you sign up for?\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"font-size: 10px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"http://luc.id/\" style=\"font-style: italic; font-weight: normal;\">Data Source</a></p> \n<p>If you have a webinar strategy or series that aims to help people boost their careers or work tactics, don't panic. Nearly one-fifth of the group (18%) said they wanted to attend webinars that helped them learn more about their career or industry, while 22% said \"All of the above.\" These results indicate that consumers will definitely still sign up for a webinar that tackles career, work, or industry-related topics.</p> \n<p>Additionally, you should also keep in mind that this survey was delivered to a small general consumer pool of all ages and career levels. Had this been given primarily to executives or B2B business reps, the results might have leaned towards industry-related content.</p> \n<p>Regardless of what industry you're in, or the size of this survey pool, marketers should keep the data above in mind when creating and promoting a webinar. Because people are naturally curious and want to learn, your webinar promotions should intrigue them by clearly stating what they'll learn, noting any experts that might be featured, and highlighting how attendees will be able to use the knowledge they'll gain from the event.</p> \n<h3>Webinar viewers sign up to learn something -- but prefer certain teaching styles over others.</h3> \n<p>Just like any in-person class, each professor -- or webinar host -- might have a slightly different teaching style.</p> \n<p>While some hosts might come in with a great slide deck presentation, others might bring in an expert and have the audience ask them questions. Or, they might bring in a few experts and host a panel discussion where the audience just listens rather than asking questions.</p> \n<p>There are many ways to format an informative webinar, but which teaching style actually intrigues people enough to get them to sign up?</p> \n<p>When I asked, \"Which webinar format sounds most engaging to you?\", 30% of participants said, \"A presentation that teaches me how to do something specific.\" Meanwhile, 20% said \"All of the above.\"</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Why%20Consumers%20Sign%20Up%20for%20Webinars%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-2.png?width=600&amp;name=Why%20Consumers%20Sign%20Up%20for%20Webinars%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-2.png\" alt=\"Which webinar format is most engaging?\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"font-size: 10px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"http://luc.id/\" style=\"font-weight: normal; font-style: italic;\">Data Source</a></p> \n<p>The results above hint that a simple how-to webinar with fewer frills could still engage audiences if you're feeling low on bandwidth and creativity. However, if you have the time to coordinate a webinar that feels more like a live Q&amp;A, this could also be a great formatting option. 39% of people said they were drawn to one of the webinar formats that included a Q&amp;A.</p> \n<p>Although a more basic presentation or lecture styled webinar will still catch the attention of potential viewers, content marketers should still make sure their presentations educate audiences on something specific -- like a strategy -- rather than discussing an incredibly broad or very vague topic -- like an entire industry. Only 12% of respondents say they're driven to webinars that will feature a presenter discussing a broad topic.</p> \n<p>Odds are, a person attending a webinar already knows the basics of their hobby, industry, or passion. But, they want to learn more or become an expert at something related to it. For example, as a content marketer, I might not attend a webinar with a broad topic of \"Marketing,\" but I might attend webinars like, \"Advanced Blogging Tips from Managing Editors,\" or \"The Basics of SEO in Marketing.\"</p> \n<p>As a marketer or webinar creator, you'll need to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/buyer-persona-research\">build a buyer persona</a> for your target audience to determine the best expertise level to create valuable content around. If your audience is filled with beginners in a topic, you might want to create more granular webinars that discuss basic tasks or tactics. If your audience is made up of topic experts, your webinars might need to be more advanced.</p> \n<h3>Interactive Content: The Key to an Engaging Webinar?</h3> \n<p>In the modern classroom, teachers will often zest up a number of different class outlines by adding opportunities for students to interact or test their knowledge. These could include polling the class by asking them to raise their hands, pop quizzes, or allowing them to ask questions.</p> \n<p>When it comes to online events, a number of tools and video software enable marketers to make their webinars more interactive and engaging. And, based on our research, it seems like consumers enjoy interactive webinars.</p> \n<p>When asked, \"Which element would you most like to see in a webinar?\", \"A host or presenter that takes questions from the audience,\" received 22% of the votes, followed by \"No preference as long as the webinar feels interactive,\" with 19% of the votes. Another 20% say they'd like to see polls or quizzes.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Why%20Consumers%20Sign%20Up%20for%20Webinars%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-1.png?width=600&amp;name=Why%20Consumers%20Sign%20Up%20for%20Webinars%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-1.png\" alt=\"Which element would you like to see in a webinar?\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"font-size: 10px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"http://luc.id/\" style=\"font-weight: normal; font-style: italic;\">Data Source</a></p> \n<p>If you're a marketer who regularly creates webinars, it might be worth it to consider where you can make your programming more interactive.</p> \n<p>For example, if you're hosting an expert, consider leaving time for the audience to ask questions in the webinar tool's chat area. Or, if you're discussing a strategy that's common in your field, poll your audience to see if they've used the tactic.</p> \n<p>Although polls or Q&amp;A might seem like a super basic webinar element, they might make your audiences listen more actively and enjoy the content they're consuming more. This ultimately could lead to them engaging more with your brand, signing up for future webinars, or converting to a customer.</p> \n<p>If you're marketing a webinar that has interactive content in it, be sure to promote that aspect. For example, in your messaging, emails, and follow-up emails, directly tell your audiences they'll be able to actively participate in quizzes, polls, or a Q&amp;A during your event.</p> \n<p>In a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-promote-a-virtual-event\">competitive webinar pool</a>, anything you can do to make your webinar seem more active and engaging than others that are more basic could help boost signups and attendance during the actual event.</p> \n<h2>Creating and Promoting a Successful Webinar</h2> \n<p>While creating a unique and engaging webinar will be one crucial step in your virtual event strategy, the proper promotional tactics will also be vital.</p> \n<p>Once you've created a webinar plan that will inform audiences, allow them to interact with you, and fuel your contact list, be sure to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-promote-a-virtual-event\">promote all of the great things your online event will cover</a>.</p> \n<p>As you promote your webinar, don't forget to note aspects that will make your event stand out -- such as polls or Q&amp;As. This transparency will show audiences exactly what they can expect and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-promote-a-virtual-event\">differentiate you from competitors</a> with vague webinar promotions.</p> \n<p>To learn more about creating a truly compelling webinar, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/what-is-a-webinar\">check out this ultimate guide</a>. Want to learn how to promote your next online event? <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-promote-a-virtual-event\">Here are a few great tips</a> from HubSpot marketers.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwhy-consumers-sign-up-for-webinars&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 30 Sep 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"e858038abbf139c81cc5f060a312d382","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"pbump@hubspot.com (Pamela Bump)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Why%20Consumers%20Sign%20Up%20for%20Webinars%20%5BNew%20Data%5D.png?width=600&name=Why%20Consumers%20Sign%20Up%20for%20Webinars%20%5BNew%20Data%5D.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn33@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-50-959_7a9be954200de35e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Why%20Consumers%20Sign%20Up%20for%20Webinars%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-2.png?width=600&name=Why%20Consumers%20Sign%20Up%20for%20Webinars%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn77@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-52-763_0d272735c63fbe5a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Why%20Consumers%20Sign%20Up%20for%20Webinars%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-1.png?width=600&name=Why%20Consumers%20Sign%20Up%20for%20Webinars%20%5BNew%20Data%5D-1.png":null,"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fwhy-consumers-sign-up-for-webinars&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn84@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-49-006_90735056d2f9fd54.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389712},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"How to Make the Best of Facebook Ad Targeting, According to HubSpot's Paid Ad Specialist","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/facebook-advertising-targeting-options","description":"<p>With a potential <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/6128/the-ultimate-list-100-facebook-statistics-infographics.aspx\">advertising reach of 1.9 </a><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/6128/the-ultimate-list-100-facebook-statistics-infographics.aspx\">billion</a><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/6128/the-ultimate-list-100-facebook-statistics-infographics.aspx\"> </a><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/6128/the-ultimate-list-100-facebook-statistics-infographics.aspx\">users</a>, Facebook is undeniably one of the most powerful platforms to market your products or services.</p> \n<p>As an avid online shopper, I know the power of Facebook advertising firsthand. Consider, for instance, the ad I saw on my Facebook feed a few hours after completing a purchase on <a href=\"https://www.freepeople.com/\">Free People's</a> website:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Ad%20Targeting%20Blog-4.png?width=267&amp;name=Facebook%20Ad%20Targeting%20Blog-4.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"267\" style=\"width: 267px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>Despite my recent Free People purchase (and dwindling clothing budget … ) I couldn't help but click. I'd just been on their website, but I hadn't seen <em>these </em>clothes yet.</p> \n<p>Which leads me to my point: the power of targeted advertising.</p> \n<p>With over <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/6128/the-ultimate-list-100-facebook-statistics-infographics.aspx\">7 million advertisers on Facebook</a>, it can be difficult for brands to stand out on Facebook amidst the masses.</p> \n<p>Here, we'll dive into the various Facebook ad targeting options you might consider to get the highest ROI on your campaigns — plus, Facebook advertising tips from HubSpot's Paid Ads specialist, Nicole Ondracek.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2><strong>Facebook Ad Targeting Options</strong></h2> \n<p>It's important to note, you'll find all these ad targeting options within your <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/ads/manager/accounts/\">Facebook Ads Manager</a>. Once you begin creating a new ad campaign, you'll have the option to \"Create New Audience\" or \"Use Saved Audience\".</p> \n<p>If you opt to create a new audience, you'll see a field for \"Custom Audiences\" at the top (in which you can add a custom or lookalike audience, both of which are described below), a section for demographics (including Location, Age, Gender, and Languages), and sections for more detailed targeting or connections.</p> \n<h3>1. Demographic</h3> \n<p>Demographic Facebook ad targeting options include the opportunity to segment your audience(s) based on age, location, language, work, education, and more. If you sell a product or service that pertains primarily to a certain demographic, this is a good ad targeting option for you.</p> \n<p>For instance, maybe your audience is primarily millennial females, people who work in the medical industry, or anyone who lives in Spain — all of these factors can help you hyper-target to ensure you're reaching the prospects who are most willing to buy your product or service based on an ad they see on Facebook.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Ad%20Targeting%20Blog.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Ad%20Targeting%20Blog-1.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<h3>2. Interests</h3> \n<p>Consider how much you're able to learn about someone from their Facebook activity.</p> \n<p>For instance, in the last six months I've Liked pages of various restaurants in Boston, MA; I've watched yoga videos via Facebook Live; and I've shopped for clothing on Facebook Marketplace.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>All of these activities suggest the types of hobbies I'm interested in, and, tangentially, what types of products or services I'd be interested in purchasing.</p> \n<p>Perhaps you sell a product or service that doesn't pertain to an audience's demographic as much as it pertains to an audiences' <em>interests</em>.</p> \n<p>A good example of this? Workout gear. Sure, you can <em>guess</em> that your audience is primarily 20 to 30-year-old women, for instance, but a more powerful opportunity for targeting would simply be to target anyone who's Liked fitness pages, or engaged with fitness videos, over the last couple months.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Ad%20Targeting%20Blog-Sep-16-2020-03-33-05-33-PM.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<h3>3. Behavior</h3> \n<p>There are plenty of user behaviors you'd want to keep track of before sending a Facebook ad their way — for instance, consider my example earlier, in which I'd shopped on Free People's website before receiving a Free People ad on Facebook.</p> \n<p>Additionally, it's often most effective to target prospects who've already shown interest in your brand. For instance, you might find your Facebook ads perform better with audiences who've already read some of your blog posts or followed you on social media.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, \"behavior\" can help you target audiences who've consumed certain types of content, visited certain websites, used certain browsers or devices, or even donated to certain charities.</p> \n<p>This is a particularly good targeting option for ecommerce re-engagement ads, in which you display ads to users who've added items to their check-out cart on your website. Alternatively, you might consider serving ads to users who've visited a certain landing page on your website.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Ad%20Targeting%20Blog-2.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<h3>4. Connections</h3> \n<p>If you have a specific page, app, or event listed on Facebook that attracts visitors to whom you'd like to serve ads, you're in luck. With \"Connections\", you can do exactly that.</p> \n<p>For instance, let's say you recently held a networking event and added 300+ users to the event-specific Facebook page — after-the-fact, you might consider sending specific ads towards those users, who are now more aware of your brand and likely interested in your offerings.</p> \n<p>Additionally, you can expand your ad's potential by sending the ad to <em>friends </em>of people who've attended your event, as well.</p> \n<h3>5. Custom Audiences</h3> \n<p>If you already have a good list of leads in your database and want to reach them on Facebook, you could simply create a Custom Audience to attract and convert those leads.</p> \n<p>A Custom Audience enables you to provide specific information you've gathered about your leads, such as a phone number or email, and then target those leads with ads.</p> \n<p>This is a good targeting option if your goal is to up-sell to existing customers. For instance, perhaps you have a database of customers who currently use your product, but you've recently released new features in a Professional version.</p> \n<p>One of the best opportunities to attract and convert existing customers is to use Custom Audiences to serve your Professional-product Facebook ads to those customers already in your database.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Ad%20Targeting%20Blog-Sep-16-2020-03-33-05-74-PM.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>6. Lookalike Audiences</h3> \n<p>Lookalike Audiences is a fantastic opportunity to perform cold outreach towards prospects who look similar to your existing prospects and customers. As the name implies, Lookalike Audiences allows you to target ads towards users who match similar characteristics to people who've shown interest in your brand.</p> \n<p>To further understand what it means for an audience to \"look\" like your existing database, consider the following example: let's say you upload your email subscriber list to Facebook as a custom audience.</p> \n<p>Facebook then identifies the following consistent features about your list: users are primarily in their mid-to-late thirties, they live in the United States, they work in banking, <em>and </em>they've shown an interest in travel.</p> \n<p>Facebook could then find users on Facebook who match all of these qualifications, since users with those criteria seem most interested in what your brand has to offer.</p> \n<p>Similar to Custom Audiences, you'll need to upload a custom audience for Lookalike Audiences to work — for instance, perhaps you upload a list of email subscribers, event attendees, or website visitors.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Ad%20Targeting%20Blog-Sep-16-2020-03-33-05-97-PM.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<h2><strong>Facebook Ad Targeting Tips</strong></h2> \n<h3>1. Repurpose your highest-performing content as a Facebook ad.</h3> \n<p>If you have a few high-performing pieces of content that already attract <em>and </em>convert leads, why not put some paid ad spend behind it?</p> \n<p>We've seen success with this strategy at HubSpot. For instance, each quarter I send a list of top-performing and high-converting content to the paid ad team, and they reformat it into an advertisement for Facebook.</p> \n<p>Ondracek adds, \"This can apply to different goals throughout a customer's lifecycle. For example, if our goal is to drive more brand awareness to our site, we'll test a blog post that generates a large amount of site traffic. On the other hand, if our goal is more focused on generating leads and submissions, we'll instead test a high-converting content offer, since we care more about conversions than traffic.\"</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>Ondracek told me, \"It's all about finding the right content that matches up to your campaign objective.\"</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>Of course, not <em>every</em> piece of content that performs well organically will perform well as a social ad, which is why you want to be highly selective and pay attention to metrics like social media views when choosing posts.</p> \n<p>But, nonetheless, choosing these high-performers is a good starting point and ensures you're providing new audiences with content that already delights your existing audience.</p> \n<h3>2. Retarget ads to prospects most likely to convert.</h3> \n<p>With Facebook advertising, you're able to target prospects who've already shown interest in your content, which could be more effective than cold-targeting Facebook users who haven't shown any interest in your brand.</p> \n<p>With retargeting, you can send ads towards prospects who've already watched a product demo, interacted with a blog post, or downloaded an ebook — which are all signs they're intrigued by your brand and could be interested in learning more.</p> \n<p>For instance, let's say you work in the ecommerce industry and sell athletic apparel. You might consider creating a gated video on fitness tips from top health experts. Once you've collected an email list of users who've downloaded that video, you can target a follow-up \"Top Workout Routines\" Facebook to those same video viewers.</p> \n<p>Ondracek says, \"Retargeting is a really powerful approach, and we've found it works best when used to go after an audience similar to the seed list. For example, we've seen success retargeting visitors who have previously visited our pricing page with direct response product ads since they're already in that consideration stage and more likely to buy.</p> \n<p>She adds, \"On the flip side, when we tried retargeting awareness video ad viewers with these types of down funnel ads, we saw worse performance since these two audiences have completely different behaviors.\"</p> \n<p>Of course, it's vital to note, you'll want to retarget ads that align well with your products or services. If people have shown interest in content that isn't high-converting and doesn't align with your product, you likely don't want to retarget those viewers, since there's no evidence they'll turn into qualified leads.</p> \n<h3>3. Leverage existing fans of your business.</h3> \n<p>Similar to the tip above, it's often more worthwhile to target users who've demonstrated their appreciation for your brand by liking your Facebook's business Page. Consider how you might convert those users by retargeting ads towards them.</p> \n<p>For instance, Facebook Ads expert Jon Loomer found his ads <a href=\"https://www.jonloomer.com/2013/08/21/facebook-ads-roi/\">ROI increased dramatically when he targeted fans</a>, rather than non-fans. In fact, his fan-targeted ads returned 129 conversions and resulted in <a href=\"https://www.jonloomer.com/2013/08/21/facebook-ads-roi/\">$9,481.50 in revenue — 45.9X ROI</a>. When he targeted non-fans, he didn't convert at all.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Ad%20Targeting%20Blog-3.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Ad%20Targeting%20Blog-Sep-16-2020-03-33-05-46-PM.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 11px;\"><a href=\"https://www.jonloomer.com/2013/08/21/facebook-ads-roi/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>Ultimately, it's much less obtrusive to target ads towards people who <em>want</em> to see content from your brand and have demonstrated an interest in your company. Save time and money by targeting your brand's fans first.</p> \n<p>Additionally, Ondracek told me, \"You can also get creative and try layering on some criteria here. For example, you could try targeting fans of your page who haven’t purchased a product to try and influence some buying power. Or on the other hand, you could try targeting fans who have previously purchased a product if you sell something that can be purchased multiple times —like clothing in the FreePeople ad.\"</p> \n<h3>4. Take advantage of custom audiences to up-sell and build loyalty with existing customers.</h3> \n<p>Targeting Facebook ads isn't just effective for attracting new prospects to your business — it's also a good strategy for retaining and up-selling your existing customers.</p> \n<p>And, considering it's <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/cross-selling\">5-25X more expensive to acquire a new customer</a> than it is to retain an existing one, it makes sense to leverage the customers in your database already rather than only sending ads to brand-new prospects.</p> \n<p>To up-sell via Facebook ads, think about your existing customers who might benefit from an additional feature, product, or service that you can offer them. For instance, perhaps you've just released new features on a Pro version of your product. More than likely, users of your free or beginner product would be interested in learning about those features, particularly if they're enjoying your product and considering an upgrade.</p> \n<p>Alternatively, maybe you simply want to target helpful content towards existing customers to increase brand loyalty. You might consider creating a Custom Audience list of customers who've read your social media blog posts, for instance, and then serve ads on your upcoming social media webinar to that audience.</p> \n<h3>5. Create lookalikes of top-performing audiences to keep improving upon what works best.</h3> \n<p>Ondracek suggests that, once you find an audience that works well following the tips above, you can always create a lookalike of the same audience.</p> \n<p>She says, \"If, for example, you find targeting people who like your page works best, you can create a Lookalike of this same audience to test. This new audience allows you to expand your reach to new prospects and might even perform better.\"<br><br>Additionally, Ondracek told me, \"At HubSpot, we tend to see the most positive results and improvements when testing with Lookalike Audiences. As digital platforms become more and more automated, you'll find yourself having to put more faith into the algorithms.\"</p> \n<p>\"And what's pretty cool is that these algorithms tend to work! When you upload a list of customers to Facebook and create a lookalike from them, Facebook's algorithm is going to do its best to target your ads to people most similar to your existing customers.\"&nbsp;<br><br>Ondracek adds that you'll want to make sure you have some conversion tracking setup on your campaigns, so that Facebook will be able to tell who's actually converting and optimize to find more people similar to those users.</p> \n<p>Of course, if you don't have enough data or conversions for the system to optimize, it's going to be harder for this approach to work — which is why you'll want to aim to run an audience test for at least two weeks, so there's enough data to work with.<br><br>Additionally, Ondracek says, \"What's also great about Lookalikes is that if you find a Lookalike audience performing well, you can increase the size of it to test if a larger audience performs better or worse than a smaller one. In the Facebook interface, you have the option to test between 1-10% Lookalike audiences. The smaller the size, the more similar the audience is supposed to be to your seed list.\"</p> \n<h3>6. Keep an eye out for frequency.</h3> \n<p>Finally, when targeting your ads, you'll want to keep an eye on the frequency metric to make sure someone isn’t seeing your ad too often.</p> \n<p>Ondracek advises, \"If the frequency is too high, you risk hurting your brand perception. We can all name that one brand we see <em>way</em> too many ads for. On the other hand, it can be beneficial for someone to see your ad more than once to increase your brand awareness. You'll have to play around with a sweet spot that works best for your company, but aiming for a frequency of 3-4 can be a good place to start.\"<br><br>Ondracek adds, \"If you do start to see the frequency increase, there are a few ways to solve for this. First, you can create a larger-sized lookalike audience as mentioned above, which will expand your reach. Second, you can create new custom audiences to add to your campaign. And, finally, you can add in interest or behavioral targeting since those are large pools of audiences to begin with.\"</p> \n<p>\"Additionally, you can swap out with new creative so the same audience is at least seeing some new fresher content.\"</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>\"One of the most exciting parts of paid advertising is being able to continuously test and find what works best. There are so many different options and ways to target, so if you find an audience not working, don’t be afraid to try a new one.\"</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>Undoubtedly, there are endless opportunities for increasing customer lifetime value by retargeting Facebook ads in an effort to demonstrate your brand's empathy and commitment to helping customers with all their various needs.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ffacebook-advertising-targeting-options&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\"
