\">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 30 Sep 2020 15:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"9adc663abde854a63457c33d212d8b90","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Caroline Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Ad%20Targeting%20Blog-4.png?width=267&name=Facebook%20Ad%20Targeting%20Blog-4.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn20@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-45-850_ebadffd8a2f28962.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Ad%20Targeting%20Blog.png":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Ad%20Targeting%20Blog-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn4@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-47-781_57248bae1f678d0a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Ad%20Targeting%20Blog-Sep-16-2020-03-33-05-33-PM.png":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Ad%20Targeting%20Blog-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn11@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-46-635_83957621306b714f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Ad%20Targeting%20Blog-Sep-16-2020-03-33-05-74-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn25@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-49-374_691c4654fb27a072.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Ad%20Targeting%20Blog-Sep-16-2020-03-33-05-97-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn98@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-52-944_0a3b2c9a59c1529f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Ad%20Targeting%20Blog-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn35@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-45-794_3a9561b3602483e6.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/Facebook%20Ad%20Targeting%20Blog-Sep-16-2020-03-33-05-46-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn58@2020_6/2020/10/09/03-33-48-083_3e50c7f4f3502ad7.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ffacebook-advertising-targeting-options&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn85@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-48-523_ca13b76cf55112dd.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389703},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"7 Tips for Hosting a Virtual Brainstorm, According to HubSpot Marketing Managers","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/virtual-brainstorm-tips","description":"<p>At HubSpot, we love brainstorms</p>  \n<p>Getting your team together in one room to come up with ideas not only allows you to identify creative content or strategies that you might not have thought of, but it also can improve feelings of <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/psychological-safety-according-to-edmondson\">psychological safety</a> as people who might not be high-level managers are invited and encouraged to offer their input.</p> \n<p>Brainstorming is one of the most productive team-building activities we use at HubSpot. But, recently, when we had to leave our physical offices and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/remote-work-tips\">embrace remote work</a>, many managers wondered how they’d recreate the same in-person communication, productivity, and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/psychological-safety-according-to-edmondson\">sense of psychological safety</a> virtually.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Luckily, many of our managers were able to adapt quickly, leading a number of successful virtual brainstorms in 2020.</p> \n<p>To help managers build solid idea-generation techniques -- even from home -- here are a few steps HubSpot employees on the blog, acquisition team, and DI&amp;B team take when coordinating remote brainstorms.</p> \n<h2>How to Run a Virtual Brainstorm</h2> \n<h3>1. Give your team a headstart.</h3> \n<p>If your teammates already know the goal of the brainstorm, the prompts they'll be given, and their idea generation instructions, they'll come ready and eager to immediately make suggestions.</p> \n<p>Before the brainstorm, consider sending a detailed email or a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/creative-brief\">creative brief</a> about what you'd like to achieve during the session.</p> \n<p>\"I’ve found that giving members of your brainstorm a chance to prepare in advance results in higher quality ideas presented in the brainstorm,\" says Emmy Jonassen, Sr. Director of Marketing at HubSpot. \"A creative brief will also help you make the best use of your time, so you'll focus on the act of brainstorming rather than discussing the assignment.\"</p> \n<h3>2. Designate a facilitator before the brainstorm.</h3> \n<p>When you're attending a brainstorm in person, it's easier to determine who's talking, who's being asked questions, and who's running the meeting simply by body language and other social cues.</p> \n<p>When you're on a video call, some cues can be harder to notice. You might not know who should be answering a question, who you should ask questions to, and who is trying to keep the meeting on schedule. That's why it's helpful to clearly designate a host or facilitator.</p> \n<p>\"The trick to having a great brainstorm is getting everyone involved,\" Jonassen explains. \"A facilitator can help create an environment where everyone feels comfortable chiming in. They can also help keep the conversation going through awkward silences, keep the group on track, and bring people into the conversation who tend to be more reserved.\"</p> \n<p>Once you've planned your brainstorm and designated yourself or someone else as a facilitator, be sure to note this information in the brainstorm's <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/creative-brief\">creative brief</a>, calendar invite, or at the beginning of the session. If you choose to use breakout rooms -- which we'll discuss in step four -- consider having a facilitator for each of them.</p> \n<h3>3. Take virtual notes.</h3> \n<p>During in-person brainstorms, it's easy to look down and type on your computer while still talking and engaging with others. But, on a video call, you might want to stare less at your notes and more at your camera so it doesn't look like you're losing interest. And, if you must take notes, you might worry about missing something as you toggle between screens. Because of these issues, notes can get pretty muffled.</p> \n<p>That's why Alexandra Garnier, a French automation marketing manager, says brainstorm coordinators should, \"Either use a virtual whiteboard, a shared online notes document, or (if needed) a designated note-taker.\"</p> \n<p>By creating joint notes or designating a note-taker, everyone can have a shared source of information to look back on and can focus on the discussions at hand, When selecting a note-taker, it's best to pick a fast typer or an attendee who isn't tasked with coming up with ideas, such as a co-coordinator. This will allow them to focus on the notes without heavily missing out on a great team activity.</p> \n<h3>4. Embrace virual breakout rooms.</h3> \n<p>During a large in-person brainstorm, you might be asked to break into small groups, go to another room, and come back with a few ideas to offer from your group. Luckily, many video call tools have been able to mimic this experience with breakout room features.</p> \n<p>\"It’s harder to get everyone to participate if you have more than five or six people involved,\" Jonassen says. \"If I have a big group, I’ll typically use this feature to break people into smaller groups and brainstorm for a set period of time. After that time has ended, I’ll have everyone rejoin the larger group to share their ideas.\"</p> \n<p>Garnier similarly added, \"If you do a brainstorm with a larger group, it's better to then do breakout rooms. Some people tend to shy away when there are many participants.\" This can be especially true in a virtual setting, where people might feel uncomfortable speaking up.</p> \n<p>If you're using Zoom for your meetings and interested in breakout rooms, here's a great tutorial for how to activate them on your next call.</p> \n<div class=\"hs-embed-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; width: 100%; height: auto; padding: 0; max-width: 480px; max-height: 270px; min-width: 256px; display: block; margin: auto;\">\n <div class=\"hs-embed-content-wrapper\">\n  <div style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.25%; margin: 0px;\">\n   <iframe width=\"480\" height=\"270\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/jbPpdyn16sY?feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen style=\"position: absolute; top: 0px; left: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\"></iframe>\n  </div>\n </div>\n</div> \n<h3>5. Use digital noises and other signals to transition between activities.</h3> \n<p>Some brainstorms might involve a combination of individual and group activities. However, when the ideas are flowing in one task, it can be naturally hard to stop and jump into a new portion of the session. According to Margot Lieblich, a Sr. UX Researcher who coordinates monthly brainstorms and ideation sessions, it's even harder to manage time in a virtual meeting.</p> \n<p>“Oftentimes in brainstorms, you are on a tight schedule and need to make quick transitions to the next activity. This can be especially hard in a remote setting, when you can’t always visually signal to get everyone’s attention at once,\" Lieblich says.</p> \n<p>\"Use an audible timer to clearly mark the end of an activity. You can even get creative with the sound,\" Lieblich advises. \"I’ve used the Oscars' theme music, and one of my coworkers uses the sound of a duck quacking.\"</p> \n<p>\"After hearing the timer once, the group will quickly learn to wrap up and start transitioning to the next activity when they hear the sound again,” Lieblich explains.</p> \n<h3>6. Include both group and individual brainstorm activities.</h3> \n<p>Some people work better by themselves while others work much better in groups. In a virtual brainstorm, this can become more apparent when those who don't respond to group activities zone out, and those who don't like to give individual pitches will wait until the end hoping they run out of time. By doing two activities, you ensure that everyone can ideate in their own confort zone.</p> \n<p>\"I like to start out with an individual activity so people have a few minutes to explore their own approaches to the problem space without influencing each other,\" Lieblich says. \"After running an individual activity, I incorporate a group activity so people can inspire each other and come up with even richer, more interesting ideas.”</p> \n<h3>7. Remember, you don't always need to schedule a video call.</h3> \n<p>While you might think all remote brainstorms must happen on video calls, this isn't always true. Yes, many of them certainly will. But, if you're asking teammates to come to a brainstorm prepared with something quick -- like a blog post pitch or a one-off email idea, you might be able to cut a time-consuming video call out of your brainstorming process entirely.</p> \n<p>Recently, when the blog team was drawing out our quarterly content strategy, we wanted to ask our writers to come up with ideas for blog posts. But, because each writer has an incredibly busy schedule, asking them to come to a very long brainstorm meeting where each person would offer five to 10 post suggestions didn't make logistical sense.</p> \n<p>So instead, I coordinated a virtual brainstorm that took place completely over Google Sheets. To kick off the brainstorm, I sent my team an email and an Idea Generation Spreadsheet with instructions on what content needs we'd have for the next quarter, how many post ideas to insert on the spreadsheet, and a deadline for submitting post suggestions.</p> \n<p>From there, writers had two weeks to offer ideas for at least five blog posts. Here's a quick look at the spreadsheet with an example post I gave writers to guide them through the elements of giving a post suggestion:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/7%20Tips%20for%20Hosting%20a%20Virtual%20Brainstorm,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketing%20Managers.png?width=600&amp;name=7%20Tips%20for%20Hosting%20a%20Virtual%20Brainstorm,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketing%20Managers.png\" alt=\"HubSpot Blog hosts a virtual brainstorm in a Google Sheet\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>After the deadline, our editors went in and used the spreadsheet's comment features to give feedback that writers could keep in mind for the next virtual brainstorm. Since this brainstorm, most of the blog posts suggested were added to our content calendar.</p> \n<h2>Planning Your Virtual Brainstorm</h2> \n<p>Many of the tips above relate to boosting one critical aspect of brainstorms: participation.</p> \n<p>As you plan your next content or campaign brainstorm, ask yourself how you can make the brainstorm engaging for everyone.</p> \n<p>By making it easier for your team to engage with others, give their thoughts, or suggest ideas in a brainstorm, you'll get more participation and -- ultimately -- more winning ideas from teammates that might not offer them otherwise.</p> \n<p>To learn about more brainstorming tactics, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/brainstorm-productive\">read this blog post</a>. If you're interested in how you can encourage psychological safety in other areas of your business, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/psychological-safety-according-to-edmondson\">check out these expert tips</a>.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fvirtual-brainstorm-tips&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 28 Sep 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"119e88e54cb866cd29b218bb43dbcc56","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"pbump@hubspot.com (Pamela Bump)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/7%20Tips%20for%20Hosting%20a%20Virtual%20Brainstorm,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketing%20Managers.png?width=600&name=7%20Tips%20for%20Hosting%20a%20Virtual%20Brainstorm,%20According%20to%20HubSpot%20Marketing%20Managers.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn36@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-46-204_ffd6a07264c1e674.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fvirtual-brainstorm-tips&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn62@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-48-303_eda1d08ae23bceae.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389706},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"What are Mini Apps & Why Marketers Should Care","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/mini-apps","description":"<p>With apps continuing to grow as a vital staple of everyday life, marketers continue to ask, \"Do I need to have an app for my business?\"</p>  \n<p>Luckily, unless your small business' product <em>is</em> an app -- or you have a skilled staff of developers, you probably don't need to spend tons of time and money building one just yet. Brainstorming, developing, launching, and promoting an app is a lot of work for a small company. In that same amount of time, you can launch a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/28776/the-ultimate-cheat-sheet-for-mastering-mobile-marketing.aspx\">mobile-optimized website or mobile email strateg</a>y that could earn you solid awareness and ROI.</p> \n<p>But, if you're a marketer at a digital startup, agency, or tech firm that thinks an app might be helpful for business, a more affordable development option could be on the horizon.</p> \n<p>In 2020, some tech companies are starting to invest in \"mini-apps.\" And, as these programs expand, there might be room for companies to test the waters with a more compact app experience.</p> \n<p>Mini-apps became a commodity on large-scale Chinese social media platforms <a href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2017/01/09/wechat-mini-programs/?guccounter=1&amp;guce_referrer=aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZ29vZ2xlLmNvbS8&amp;guce_referrer_sig=AQAAAM0j8haMgC_vAZ9AlTVy2WZJYhFLCjzbHx2IRrsoXUPYQoqv7L7J5CtTcLNr1h9_qomxre8Vm-610N0opOtTXHnImNdEunFeXYbCjJ6YY5kaq-fxGO1zEHQeLGBXBwk8pP24N_SWqVElgbZ8KKlBOi5dAIqeGqRVAsy45jSsn1eO\">as recently as 2017</a>. During this year, WeChat's founding company, Tencent, announced the launch of <a href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2017/01/09/wechat-mini-programs/?guccounter=1&amp;guce_referrer=aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZ29vZ2xlLmNvbS8&amp;guce_referrer_sig=AQAAAM0j8haMgC_vAZ9AlTVy2WZJYhFLCjzbHx2IRrsoXUPYQoqv7L7J5CtTcLNr1h9_qomxre8Vm-610N0opOtTXHnImNdEunFeXYbCjJ6YY5kaq-fxGO1zEHQeLGBXBwk8pP24N_SWqVElgbZ8KKlBOi5dAIqeGqRVAsy45jSsn1eO\">WeChat Mini Programs.</a></p> \n<p>After showing success on apps like WeChat, miniature app-like experiences recently caught the attention of Western tech firms like Apple and Snapchat. These companies have begun to build out and launch similar programs to WeChat.</p> \n<p>But what exactly do these apps look like, and how do they benefit the brands that launched them? Below, I'll highlight a few major mini-program platforms and give you a look at what these mobile experiences look like for brands.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2>Early Mini-App Platforms</h2> \n<h3>WeChat Mini Programs</h3> \n<p>A 2017 report from <a href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2017/01/09/wechat-mini-programs/?guccounter=1&amp;guce_referrer=aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZ29vZ2xlLmNvbS8&amp;guce_referrer_sig=AQAAAM0j8haMgC_vAZ9AlTVy2WZJYhFLCjzbHx2IRrsoXUPYQoqv7L7J5CtTcLNr1h9_qomxre8Vm-610N0opOtTXHnImNdEunFeXYbCjJ6YY5kaq-fxGO1zEHQeLGBXBwk8pP24N_SWqVElgbZ8KKlBOi5dAIqeGqRVAsy45jSsn1eO\">TechCrunch</a> described Mini-Programs as basic app experiences that could be accessed via WeChat. Although tech journalists describe these as mini-apps, Tencent could not label them as \"apps\" because they worried about <a href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2017/01/09/wechat-mini-programs/?guccounter=1&amp;guce_referrer=aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZ29vZ2xlLmNvbS8&amp;guce_referrer_sig=AQAAAM0j8haMgC_vAZ9AlTVy2WZJYhFLCjzbHx2IRrsoXUPYQoqv7L7J5CtTcLNr1h9_qomxre8Vm-610N0opOtTXHnImNdEunFeXYbCjJ6YY5kaq-fxGO1zEHQeLGBXBwk8pP24N_SWqVElgbZ8KKlBOi5dAIqeGqRVAsy45jSsn1eO\">infringing upon Apple and Google trademarks</a>.</p> \n<p>To give you a visual perspective of how Mini-Programs look on WeChat, here's a screenshot of what users see when accessing them. Although the text is in Chinese, the app's native language, you can tell the programs are all sponsored by other companies:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/What%20are%20Mini%20Apps%20%26%20Why%20Marketers%20Should%20Care-4.png?width=300&amp;name=What%20are%20Mini%20Apps%20%26%20Why%20Marketers%20Should%20Care-4.png\" alt=\"WeChat mini-app homescreen\" width=\"300\" style=\"width: 300px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 10px;\"><a href=\"https://walkthechat.com/wechat-mini-programs-simple-introduction/\" style=\"font-weight: normal; font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>When you tap on a Mini-Program, such as Tesla's, you'll stay on the WeChat app, but enter a new experience within it. With Tesla's basic program, you can find charging stations for your car, or schedule test drives:</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/What%20are%20Mini%20Apps%20%26%20Why%20Marketers%20Should%20Care-1.png?width=600&amp;name=What%20are%20Mini%20Apps%20%26%20Why%20Marketers%20Should%20Care-1.png\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"Tesla Mini-app on WeChat\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"font-size: 10px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://walkthechat.com/wechat-mini-programs-simple-introduction/\" style=\"font-weight: normal; font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>For users, a mini-program like Tesla's gives them the ability to connect with friends on WeChat, while learning about Tesla in the same session. Meanwhile, Tesla's content spreads awareness about its business to possible audiences or buyers who use WeChat.</p> \n<p>At this point, the WeChat Mini Program is only available for the app's original Chinese version, Weixin. However, if a marketer is trying to grow awareness on this platform, <a href=\"https://developers.weixin.qq.com/miniprogram/en/dev/#Apply-for-an-account\">they can apply for a Mini Program account</a>. Mini-program app creators will require a developer to create the experience. According to a <a href=\"https://walkthechat.com/wechat-mini-programs-simple-introduction/\">WALKTHECHAT</a> review of mini-programs, this aspect can be somewhat tricky:</p> \n<p>\"Mini-programs have to be developed in a specific 'language' (a JavaScript framework developed by Tencent). Developers have to write WXML, WXSS instead of traditional HTML and CSS, and leverage this framework for all their development,\" <a href=\"https://walkthechat.com/wechat-mini-programs-simple-introduction/\">the 2019 post noted</a>.</p> \n<h3>Snap Minis</h3> \n<p>Snap Minis, <a href=\"https://minis.snapchat.com/\">announced in 2020</a>, are miniature branded experiences within the Snapchat app. To access Snap Minis, a user opens a chat with a friend or group. Then they'll click on the spaceship icon, which reveals a number of searchable mini-programs. These include a number of different branded experiences from games, to scheduling tools, to meditation applets.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/What%20are%20Mini%20Apps%20%26%20Why%20Marketers%20Should%20Care.png?width=200&amp;name=What%20are%20Mini%20Apps%20%26%20Why%20Marketers%20Should%20Care.png\" width=\"200\" style=\"width: 200px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"Mini app experiences in the Snapchat mini program\">\n</div> \n<p>When users click on a miniature program, such as Headspace, they can interact with it in basic ways, such as playing daily meditations. You can also share in-app experiences, such as the meditations you listened to or a score on a gaming app, with your Snapchat contacts.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/What%20are%20Mini%20Apps%20%26%20Why%20Marketers%20Should%20Care-3.png?width=200&amp;name=What%20are%20Mini%20Apps%20%26%20Why%20Marketers%20Should%20Care-3.png\" alt=\"Headspace mini experience within Snapchat\" width=\"200\" style=\"width: 200px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p>While <a href=\"https://walkthechat.com/wechat-mini-programs-simple-introduction/\">Tesla's WeChat Mini-Program</a> spreads awareness of the car brand and its physical store locations, Snap's Minis take things a step further as they offer content that audiences can share with others, rather than just interacting with it. This is a great option for tech marketers or digital brands that want people in the Snapchat demographic to actively share branded content with others in their community.</p> \n<p>According to Snapchat, some development work is required before launching a Mini on its platform, but it is unclear if Snap or the partnering company will do most of the app development. Snap does note that Minis are <a href=\"https://minis.snapchat.com/\">easy-to-use </a><a href=\"https://minis.snapchat.com/\">build</a><a href=\"https://minis.snapchat.com/\"> with HTML5 code</a>.</p> \n<p>At this point, brands interested <a href=\"https://minis.snapchat.com/\">must apply for early access</a> to the Minis program. In the Snap application, businesses must include their contact information and explain what they'd like the Mini to be used for.</p> \n<h3>Apple App Clips</h3> \n<p>At this point, Apple Clips will still be inaccessible for brands that can't make their own Apple App Store app. However, they are still an interesting example of mini-apps that are worth noting, especially if your brand does have an app.</p> \n<p>Apple App Clips, which launched with <a href=\"https://developer.apple.com/app-clips/\">iPhone IOS 10.14 update in 2020</a>, are small features of a larger app that's currently available in the App Store. <a href=\"https://developer.apple.com/app-clips/\">Users can access App Clips</a> by scanning QR codes, walking near an App Clip business with an NFC tag, visiting the brand's website, or clicking on a specially designed link, but users can also find them when using other apps, such as Apple's Messenger or Maps apps.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/What%20are%20Mini%20Apps%20%26%20Why%20Marketers%20Should%20Care-2.png?width=600&amp;name=What%20are%20Mini%20Apps%20%26%20Why%20Marketers%20Should%20Care-2.png\" alt=\"Apple App clips mini app program\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"font-size: 10px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://developer.apple.com/app-clips/\" style=\"font-weight: normal; font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<p>When someone is discussing or searching for something related to a business that has an Apple App Clip, a call-to-action will pop up allowing a user to \"Open\" the Clip without downloading a full app. From there, a user can then take advantage of one of the app's basic features.</p> \n<p>For example, if two friends are talking about a restaurant chain that has an app via text message, an App Clip CTA might pop up encouraging them to open the restaurant's Clip to see a menu. When the user enters the Clip experience, they can do <a href=\"https://developer.apple.com/app-clips/\">a small task</a>, such as scanning the menu or making a reservation. Users can also click a CTA in the App Clip to download the full program from the App Store.</p> \n<p>While companies who can't easily create an app probably won't benefit from App Clips, digital startups and tech companies should keep on their radar. Along with literally allowing people to test out an app before they download it, <a href=\"https://developer.apple.com/app-clips/\">the App Clip CTA options</a> allow people to get notified about a brand's app when they walk near its store, are messaging friends about products the brand offers, or while searching local businesses on Maps. This enables app promotions to literally meet audiences where they are.</p> \n<h2>Mini-App Takeaways for Marketers</h2> \n<p>Although some mini-app programs, such as Apple and Snapchat's are more exclusive and less accessible to smaller brands right now, they could be a helpful marketing tool for more companies in the future. Here's what marketers should keep in mind as mini-app programs grow and expand.</p> \n<h3>1. Brands that embrace digital transformation will get better \"mini\" opportunities.</h3> \n<p>First of all, your brand will likely need to offer a digital tool or store that will improve another major app's experience. For example, Tesla's website already allowed you to look up car charging stations and schedule test drives, so turning this into a mini-app experience would be much easier for developers.</p> \n<p>Additionally, some of WeChat's audiences had an interest in technologies, cars, and Tesla's, which offered a business case for creating this experience. While audiences are zoning in on Tesla's offerings, they are still spending time on the WeChat app.</p> \n<p>Because you'll need a strong digital presence and online business capabilities, mini-apps might not be possible for many small businesses yet -- especially in the U.S. where they are just now being embraced. However, as the world becomes more connected to apps, this strategy could become more accessible to you later on.</p> \n<h3>2. Big apps will only host mutually beneficial mini-apps.</h3> \n<p>Think of mini-apps like a website integration or a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-cobranding-partnerships\">brand partnership project</a>. A major brand likely wouldn't have an integration with a competitor's tool or partner with a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-cobranding-partnerships\">business that doesn't target similar audiences</a>. In the mini-app space, the thinking might be similar.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, big app brands will opt to host mini-programs that spread awareness to businesses with similar audiences and offer digital experiences that keep users on their main app longer. This is likely why companies such as Snapchat and WeChat require brands to apply for their mini-programs, rather than just allowing them to buy space for a mini-app.</p> \n<h3>3. Brands will still need to do groundwork in creating mini-apps.</h3> \n<p>In some cases, you might not need your own in-house developer to have a mini-app. In WeChat's case, the company offers a mini-program where brands can apply and pay to have a mini-app experience made and launched for them.</p> \n<p>Despite the ease of working with some platforms, others like Apple will require you to already have developed an app. Meanwhile, <a href=\"https://minis.snapchat.com/\">Snapchat's site</a> is unclear (at time of publication) about what creating a Mini fully entails.</p> \n<h3>4. Not all brands will be able to access \"mini\" partnerships.</h3> \n<p>Despite the opportunities that might exist with mini-apps, marketers -- especially at small companies -- should still keep in mind that this might not be applicable to them or their strategy.</p> \n<p>As noted above, large platforms that offer mini-programs will selectively look for partners who can offer digital tools or experiences that improve each user's time on their main app. And, even though larger platforms might be more involved with producing a mini experience for smaller brands, these partners will still likely spend some time and money on ensuring that their program offers a glitchless experience.</p> \n<p>The good news? Although many companies can't launch a mini-app, just yet, they don't necessarily need to. If you never see this tactic fitting into your strategy, there are plenty of ways you can boost mobile or online awareness without any sort of app.</p> \n<p>If you'd like to harness on mobile marketing alternatives without an app, check out <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/28776/the-ultimate-cheat-sheet-for-mastering-mobile-marketing.aspx\">this Ultimate Guide</a>.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmini-apps&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\"
