\">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 22 Sep 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"e6cfa03457515bfd07f697737ae233df","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"pbump@hubspot.com (Pamela Bump)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/What%20are%20Mini%20Apps%20%26%20Why%20Marketers%20Should%20Care-4.png?width=300&name=What%20are%20Mini%20Apps%20%26%20Why%20Marketers%20Should%20Care-4.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn24@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-48-130_ef124f95ff29029f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/What%20are%20Mini%20Apps%20%26%20Why%20Marketers%20Should%20Care-1.png?width=600&name=What%20are%20Mini%20Apps%20%26%20Why%20Marketers%20Should%20Care-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn89@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-51-574_7cf9a95d04f9a19d.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/What%20are%20Mini%20Apps%20%26%20Why%20Marketers%20Should%20Care.png?width=200&name=What%20are%20Mini%20Apps%20%26%20Why%20Marketers%20Should%20Care.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn17@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-49-983_4b28317df44ce98d.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/What%20are%20Mini%20Apps%20%26%20Why%20Marketers%20Should%20Care-3.png?width=200&name=What%20are%20Mini%20Apps%20%26%20Why%20Marketers%20Should%20Care-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn15@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-47-958_fbbae99f53d1dff3.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/What%20are%20Mini%20Apps%20%26%20Why%20Marketers%20Should%20Care-2.png?width=600&name=What%20are%20Mini%20Apps%20%26%20Why%20Marketers%20Should%20Care-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn68@2020_4/2020/10/09/03-33-49-904_ae1fafce3b22bea0.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmini-apps&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn100@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-49-948_319f4c78eedec578.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389709},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"5 Myths About Video Marketing, Debunked","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/myths-about-video-marketing-debunked","description":"<p>By now, you've probably heard video marketing is a powerful tool for generating leads and capturing new customers.</p> \n<p>So why aren't you using it yet?</p>  \n<p>For many small to medium businesses, the reluctance to adopt video comes from a fear of the unknown. Video marketing feels expensive, cumbersome, and difficult to track. And these would be valid reasons … if any of them were still true in 2020.</p> \n<p>Video technology has come a long way in the past few years. We've gone from \"put it on YouTube and hope the millennials find it\" to <a href=\"https://www.vidyard.com/blog/choosing-a-video-platform-evaluate-for-marketing-and-sales/\">video enablement platforms</a> which empower small businesses to create, share, and analyze videos without the agencies, actors, or expense.</p> \n<p>In fact, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/state-of-video-marketing-new-data\">88%of video marketers reported that video gives them a positive ROI — a 5%increase on last years figure, and a world away from the lowly 33% who felt that way in 2015</a>.</p> \n<p>If you haven't seen what video can do for your company, it's time to stop putting it off.</p> \n<p>In this post, let's review the top video marketing myths.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2>5 Video Marketing Myths, Debunked</h2> \n<h3>1. Video is too expensive.</h3> \n<p>Sure, HBO's <i>Westworld</i> may have <a href=\"http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2016/10/westworld-has-a-giant-budget\">beaten The Game of Thrones' record</a> with a price tag of $10 million per episode, but you don't have to play their game. In fact, stay as far away from it as possible.</p> \n<p>Video doesn't have to be expensive. Today's buyers and consumers actually appreciate authenticity over production value.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p><a href=\"https://www.fastcompany.com/3002249/story-behind-stuff-consumers-growing-interest-real-products\">According to Fast Company</a>, consumers prefer lower quality but \"authentic\" goods and services over those of a higher quality but which seem \"inauthentic.\"</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>This craving for authenticity is why we're seeing such an explosion in micro-influencer marketing and user-generated content. With both of these marketing strategies, brands rely on their own buyers to create content, usually with little more than an iPhone.</p> \n<p>With your own video content, don't stress over having a low production budget if you have something valuable to say. For example, Vidyard produces <a href=\"https://www.vidyard.com/resources/?categories%5B%5D=chalk-talks&amp;types%5B%5D=videos&amp;search=\">Chalk Talks</a> where they ask experts within their company to chat about topics like outbound sales, analytics, and video strategy in front of a chalkboard. The videos have been shared thousands of times, and the cost? A few minutes of someone's time and a lot of colored chalk.</p> \n<h3>2. Video is cumbersome.</h3> \n<p>What many small business owners typically mean by this is \"I don't know where to begin.\" When they think of video, they imagine a time-consuming process of coming up with scripts and storyboards, procuring actors and equipment, and hiring someone in jockey pants to operate the clapperboard and shout, \"Action!\" Yet modern video marketing is worlds apart from Hollywood and requires a lot less effort.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>When it comes to camera equipment, the age-old aphorism still holds true: the best camera is the one that's with you.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>Today, most iPhone cameras rival all but the top-of-the-line DSLRs and video equipment and are a great substitute. You can easily capture videos of yourself, your office, events, and customers giving off-the-cuff testimonials when your sales and account teams pay them a visit.</p> \n<p>And when it comes to actors, don't worry that you can't afford <a href=\"http://www.imdb.com/name/nm2933757/\">Gal Gadot</a>: you don't need her. Your employees will do a far better job because they actually know your products, your customers, and the details of your industry. After the initial awkwardness of seeing themselves on camera fades, you'll have all the actors you need.</p> \n<p>And finally, not everything needs to be scripted. Writers are great and preparation has its place, but a lot of great content can be created with little or no forethought. Take entrepreneur and internet personality Gary Vaynerchuk, for example. He built a media empire from selfie videos recorded on his mobile phone. The below video of him giving advice to young entrepreneurs might be what the internet would call \"potato quality\" but it still gets the powerful point across.</p> \n<p>If you feel like you don't know where to start, <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/video-marketing\">HubSpot's Video Marketing course</a> can serve as a great guide to helping on your way.</p> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"position: relative; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: auto; border: none; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; min-width: 256px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; margin: 0px auto;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.07%; margin: 0;\">\n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe hs-fullwidth-embed\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/vxTXCpxn6DE\" width=\"560\" height=\"314\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n </div> \n</div> \n<h3>3. Our industry doesn't really use video.</h3> \n<p>What most brands hopefully mean by this one is \"our industry doesn't use video<i> yet</i>.\" Video is industry agnostic and the demand is being driven not by businesses, but the people who work within them. Remember, both B2B and B2C are really just B2H (business-to-human), and humans love video. One need only look at the numbers for a reminder:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing/content-marketing\">54% of people want to see more video content from marketers.</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing/content-marketing\">Overall, 83% of consumers worldwide prefer YouTube to watch video content.</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing/content-marketing\">Overall, 73% of consumers worldwide prefer seeing videos on social media that are \"entertaining.\"</a></li> \n <li style=\"text-align: left;\"><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing/content-marketing\">In 2019, video was the #1 form of media used in content strategy, overtaking blogs and infographics.</a></li> \n</ul> In fact, the industries with the greatest opportunities are those where video has classically been underused. Just look at the recent proliferation of online video in places like real estate, where agencies are suddenly embracing everything from drone flyovers to virtual reality walk-throughs. To see similarly outsized gains ask yourself, \n<em>\"What would the people who make up our customer base, business or otherwise, like to see?\"</em> \n<h3>4. Video is hard to track.</h3> \n<p>Videos can indeed be difficult to track, but only if you're using a bare bones video hosting platform like YouTube or your website's video feature. These platforms only show you total video views which is like measuring your website's success based solely from visits.</p> \n<p>What if 95 percent of your video's viewers dropped off in the first three seconds? You'd never know. A true <a href=\"https://www.vidyard.com/blog/choosing-a-video-platform-evaluate-for-marketing-and-sales/\">video enablement platform</a>, on the other hand, can give you insights into how people watch your videos, who they are, what they liked and didn't like, and what they did afterward.</p> \n<p>You see, video has some unique characteristics that make it highly trackable. Because it's linear and people watch it from end-to-end, video enablement platforms, like <a href=\"https://www.twentythree.net/\">TwentyThree</a> and <a href=\"https://wistia.com/\">Wistia</a>, can tell you what parts viewers watched, where they skipped, and where they revisited. From this, you can automatically infer an individual's interest in particular products or value propositions that appeared in the video.</p> \n<p>And, with CRM and marketing system integrations, you don't have to spend all your time on these analytics. You can trigger actions based on how your viewers watched the video. Did they only complete 25 percent of it? Better send them a different video. Did another viewer rewatch the part where the product is shown over and over? Better ping your sales team because you might have a qualified lead on your hands.</p> \n<h3>5. Video doesn't have enough uses.</h3> \n<p>Of all the excuses, this one invariably makes our editor cough and spit out her coffee in surprise. Video is perhaps the most dynamic and repurpose-able type of content that you have: It <a href=\"https://www.vidyard.com/blog/businesses-see-500-lift-in-email-conversion-personalized-video/\">increases open rates for email</a>, <a href=\"https://www.vidyard.com/blog/top-10-optimize-landing-page-with-video-to-convert-more-customers/\">boosts click through rates for landing pages</a>, encourages shares on social media, increases time on page for websites, and drives more leads than text alone. And, with a great video editing platform, you can optimize one video for all channels.</p> \n<p>A good video editing platform provides small to medium businesses with the tools they need to easily cut up, edit, and optimize one video into many formats for many channels. This scales easily because users can easily A/B test videos just as they would an email and can render dynamic content to personalize videos to viewers, such as inserting logos, names, or even swapping out different products. With the right tools, video has more uses than you'll know what to do with.</p> \n<p>Video is easier than you think.</p> \n<p>Once you have the epiphany that unscripted and low production value videos are both desirable and trackable, you'll also realize that it's useful for more than just marketing and sales.</p> \n<p>You can use video in your customer support to demonstrate how to use your product, in your internal communications to update your remote teams, and as a way for people within your company to communicate on a day-to-day basis.</p> \n<p>So, knowing that video isn't nearly as expensive, difficult, or untraceable as you previously thought, are you ready to stop putting it off?</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in August 2017 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p><em></em></p> \n<p><em></em></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmyths-about-video-marketing-debunked&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 28 Sep 2020 21:15:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"714e74b71c8c7e8286aa4abe2e247bb3","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"greg.kelly@vidyard.com (Greg Kelly)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fmyths-about-video-marketing-debunked&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn91@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-50-608_ccfd6663751aecb1.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389705},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"How to Automate Your Account-Based Marketing Strategy","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/account-based-marketing-automation","description":"<p>In today's day and age, marketing is all about personalization.</p> \n<p>It's about reaching the right people in the right place at the right time. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/account-based-marketing-guide\">Account-based marketing (ABM)</a> is no different and has been growing in popularity in recent years.</p>  \n<p>In fact, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/account-based-marketing-stats\">87% of account-based marketers say</a> ABM initiatives outperform other marketing investments.</p> \n<p>Plus, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/account-based-marketing-stats\">one in five accounts targeted through ABM </a>becomes considered a qualified sales opportunity.</p> \n<p>That's why ABM is an important tactic to implement if you sell high value B2B products or services to a finite number of companies who have a multi-person buying committee and require personalized content and engagement.</p> \n<p>As a marketer, that might seem like a daunting task, because you've probably felt the pain of tools that were hard to use, didn't integrate with your systems, or made collaboration among teams hard.</p> \n<p>That's why using marketing automation and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/account-based-marketing-software\">ABM software</a> to make the process seamless is a good idea.</p> \n<p>Below, let's review how to automate your account-based marketing strategy.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>1. Create your Ideal Customer Profile (ICP).</h3> \n<p>Before you can get started with ABM, you'll need to define your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/customers/ideal-customer-profiles-and-buyer-personas-are-they-different\">ideal customer profile</a>. This is similar to a buyer persona, except it's built around targeting entire organizations rather than individuals.</p> \n<p>You'll want to know what types of companies you want to target. For example, your ICP should include information on company size, revenue, industry, and location.</p> \n<p>With software, like <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/abm-software\">HubSpot's ABM software</a>, you can use ICP workflow templates to help you spot common traits that can be used to classify companies in your database by how well they match your ICP.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, automation should help you identify and organize your target accounts. Once you've created your ICP, you should be able to use this information in your ABM software to manage your audience.</p> \n<h3>2. Set up your target accounts.</h3> \n<p>Once you've created your ICP, you should be able to set up your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/how-to-choose-target-accounts-account-based-marketing\">target accounts</a> in your ABM software.</p> \n<p>Tagging \"Target accounts\" in your software will enable you to manage your audience from a Target Accounts dashboard. For example, with <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/abm-software\">HubSpot's ABM software</a>, you can tag accounts as target accounts and then rank them with the ICP Tier property. Your priority accounts will be marked Tier 1, while lower priority accounts will be marked Tier 3.</p> \n<p>Additionally, a great ABM software will use AI-powered target account recommendations to automate the process of researching companies that are a good fit.</p> \n<p>These types of tools will help you manage and then segment your lists so you can deliver personalized content to your target accounts.</p> \n<h3>3. Integrate your ABM, marketing automation software, and CRM.</h3> \n<p>Before you can build your ABM campaigns, you'll want to integrate your ABM software with your marketing automation software and your <a href=\"http://hubspot.com/crm\">CRM</a>.</p> \n<p>For example, with HubSpot, you can use many of the ABM software features if you have Marketing or Sales Pro.</p> \n<p>Integrating your marketing tools is important in the automation process. If your ABM software doesn't interact with your email marketing software or your ads tools, then you won't be able to automate the process.</p> \n<p>Additionally, if it doesn't interact with your CRM, it'll be impossible to know if leads become accounts and track the ROI of an account-based campaign.</p> \n<p>By integrating these tools, you'll have your ICP research, target accounts, content, and CRM all in one place.</p> \n<h3>4. Build your campaigns.</h3> \n<p>When you have your ABM software and marketing tools set up, it's time to create your campaigns.</p> \n<p>To start, you'll want to decide what channels you want to use and what actions will trigger an automated workflow.</p> \n<p>First, look at your target accounts and find out where they spend their time online. For example, you can build an ad campaign based on people's job title or company on LinkedIn and Facebook.</p> \n<p>Then, you'll want to think about your customer journey and set up automated workflows. For instance, you can have a task created for a sales rep when someone who works at one of your target accounts interacts with an email, your website, or blog content.</p> \n<h3>5. Personalize your content.</h3> \n<p>You probably got started with ABM so you could personalize your marketing campaigns. To do this, you'll want to create your content, and use your automation tools to segment your audience.</p> \n<p>For example, with <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/abm-software\">HubSpot's ABM software</a>, you can use company lists to create an ad audience or use company ad targeting for your LinkedIn ads.</p> \n<p>With your ICP set up, it should be easy to create your content based on your target audience. The content in your ABM campaigns will be similar to other marketing content, except that you're now targeting specific accounts and companies.</p> \n<p>Ultimately, your messaging should address specific pain points, and appeal to solving your target account's problems.</p> \n<h3>6. Tailor your engagement.</h3> \n<p>Another aspect of your ABM strategy will be collaborating with your sales team so they can tailor their engagement with target accounts.</p> \n<p>A great way to do this is through automation tools. That's why it's important for your CRM and ABM software to work together.</p> \n<p>For example, with <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/abm-software\">HubSpot's ABM software</a> and Sales Hub, you can automate your follow up emails and tasks based on prospect behavior.</p> \n<p>However, remember that even though you're focusing on automation right now, your sales outreach and content should still be personalized.</p> \n<h3>7. Set up a dashboard to assess ongoing efforts.</h3> \n<p>The last step to automating your ABM strategy is to track and measure your efforts. With your ABM software, you'll want to see information at-a-glance.</p> \n<p>For instance, on your dashboard, you might include information on your target accounts such as company score, open deals, total pipeline, and the number of decision makers identified.</p> \n<p>If your ABM software has company scoring available, you should use it. This is similar to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/lead-scoring-instructions\">lead scoring</a>, where you assign a score based on the properties in your software.</p> \n<p>Additionally, you should consider running <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-do-a-b-testing\">A/B tests</a> when you get started with ABM automation so you can see what messaging appeals to your ICP.</p> \n<p>While ABM does require thoughtful planning and coordination, using ABM software tools — ideally ones that integrate with your CRM and marketing automation tools — can help you automate and scale your strategy.</p> \n<p>For more information on HubSpot's offerings, read about our <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/abm-software\">ABM software</a>.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in May 2020 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<div>\n <a class=\"close\">&nbsp;</a>\n</div>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Faccount-based-marketing-automation&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 07 Oct 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"3f2c0c1d3b7020a34927b5204b2f2fc0","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Rebecca Riserbato","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Faccount-based-marketing-automation&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn32@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-52-519_b2eeefbd7333ce8e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389713},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"The Beginner’s Guide to Usability Testing [+ Sample Questions]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/usability-testing","description":"<p>My favorite part of the writing process is when my editor reviews my work. By the time I’ve submitted the first draft of most of my blog posts, I’ve invested so much time and effort into my piece that I’m <em>too</em> emotionally attached to it. I need to distance myself from it.</p> \n<p>My editor also has fresh editing eyes, so she can discover any overlooked errors and new creative opportunities to sharpen my piece. After I address her edits, my piece always looks more polished.</p>  \n<p>Asking other people to evaluate your work applies to almost every discipline, especially user experience and design. It's not smart to rely on yourself when evaluating your own product or website design. You're partial towards it, and that can skew your perception of reality. Learning directly from the people that your work is actually for -- your users -- is what enables you to craft the best user experience possible.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>UX and design professionals leverage usability testing to get user feedback on their product or website’s user experience all the time. So we interviewed some of HubSpot’s Senior UX Researchers and Designers to teach you what exactly usability testing is, its benefits, and how to effectively conduct your own study.</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>What is Usability Testing?</h2> \n <p>Usability testing is a method of evaluating a product or website’s user experience. By testing the usability of their product or website with a representative group of their users or customers, UX researchers can determine if their actual users can easily and intuitively use their product or website.</p> \n</div> \n<p>UX researchers will usually conduct usability studies on each iteration of their product from its early development to its release. This allows UX researchers to uncover any problems with their product's user experience, decide how to fix these problems, and ultimately determine if the product is usable enough.</p> \n<p>Identifying and fixing these early issues saves the company both time and money: developers don’t have to overhaul the code of a poorly designed product that’s already built, and the product team is more likely to release it on schedule.</p> \n<p>During a usability study, the moderator asks participants in their individual user session to complete a series of tasks while the rest of the team observes and takes notes. By watching their actual users navigate their product or website and listening to their praises and concerns about it, they can see when the participants can quickly and successfully complete tasks and where they’re enjoying the user experience, encountering problems, and experiencing confusion.</p> \n<p>After conducting their study, they’ll analyze the results and report any interesting insights to the project lead.</p> \n<h2>Benefits of Usability Testing</h2> \n<p>Usability testing has five major advantages over the other methods of examining a product's user experience, like a questionnaire:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Usability testing provides an unbiased, accurate, and direct examination of your product or website’s user experience. By testing its usability on a sample of actual users who are detached from the amount of emotional investment your team has put into creating and designing the product or website, their feedback can resolve most of your team’s internal debates.</li> \n <li>Usability testing is convenient. To conduct your study, all you have to do is find a quiet room and bring in portable recording equipment. If you don’t have recording equipment, someone on your team can just take notes.</li> \n <li>Usability testing can tell you what your users do on your site or product and why they take these actions.</li> \n <li>Usability testing lets you address your product’s or website’s issues before you spend a ton of money creating something that ends up having a poor design.</li> \n <li>For your business, intuitive design boosts customer usage and their results, driving demand for your product.</li> \n</ul> \n<h2>Examples of What Usability Testing Can Do</h2> \n<p>Usability testing sounds great in theory, but what value does it provide in practice? Here's what it can do to actually make a difference for your product (with examples):</p> \n<h3>1. Identify points of friction in the usability of your product.</h3> \n<p>As Brian Halligan said at INBOUND 2019, \"Dollars flow where friction is low.\" This just as true in UX as it is in sales or customer service. The more friction your product has, the more reason your users will have to find something that's easier to use.</p> \n<p>Usability testing can uncover points of friction from customer feedback.</p> \n<p>For example: <em>\"My process begins in Google Drive. I keep switching between windows and making multiple clicks just to copy and paste from Drive into this interface.\"</em></p> \n<p>Even though the product team may have had that task in mind when they created the tool, seeing it in action and hearing the user's frustration uncovered a use case that the tool didn't compensate for. It might lead the team to solve for this problem by creating an easy import feature or way to access Drive within the interface to reduce the number of clicks the user needs to make to accomplish their task.</p> \n<h3>2. Stress test across many environments and use cases.</h3> \n<p>Our products don't exist in a vacuum, and sometimes development environments are unable to compensate for all the variables. Getting the product out and tested by users can uncover bugs that you may not have noticed while testing internally.</p> \n<p>For example: <em>\"The check boxes disappear when I click on them.\"</em></p> \n<p>Let's say that the team investigates why this might be, and they discover that the user is on a browser that's not commonly used (or a browser version that's outdated).</p> \n<p>If the developers only tested across the browsers used in-house, they may have missed this bug, and it could have resulted in customer frustration.</p> \n<h3>3. Provide diverse perspectives from your user base.</h3> \n<p>While individuals in our customer bases have a lot in common (in particular, the things that led them to need and use our products), each individual is unique and brings a different perspective to the table. These perspectives are invaluable in uncovering issues that may not have occurred to your team.</p> \n<p>For example: <em>\"I can't find where I'm supposed to click.\" </em></p> \n<p>Upon further investigation, it's possible that this feedback came from a user who is color blind, leading your team to realize that the color choices did not create enough contrast for this user to navigate properly.</p> \n<p>Insights from diverse perspectives can lead to design, architectural, copy, and accessibility improvements.</p> \n<h3>4. Give you clear insights into your product's strengths and weaknesses.</h3> \n<p>You likely have competitors in your industry whose products are better than yours in some areas and worse than yours in others. These variations in the market lead to competitive differences and opportunities. User feedback can help you close the gap on critical issues and identify what positioning is working.</p> \n<p>For example: <em>\"This interface is so much easier to use and more attractive than [competitor product]. I just wish that I could also do [task] with it.\"</em></p> \n<p>Two scenarios are possible based on that feedback:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Your product can already accomplish the task the user wants. You just have to make it clear that the feature exists by improving copy or navigation.</li> \n <li>You have a really good opportunity to incorporate such a feature in future iterations of the product.</li> \n</ol> \n<h3>5. Inspire you with potential future additions or enhancements.</h3> \n<p>Speaking of future iterations, that comes to the next example of how usability testing can make a difference for your product: The feedback that you gather can inspire future improvements to your tool.</p> \n<p>It's not just about rooting out issues but also envisioning where you can go next that will make the most difference for your customers. And who best to ask but your prospective and current customers themselves?</p> \n<h2>The 9 Phases of a Usability Study</h2> \n<h3>1. Decide which part of your product or website you want to test.</h3> \n<p>Do you have any pressing questions about how your users will interact with certain parts of your design, like a particular interaction or workflow? Or are you wondering what users will do first when they land on your product page? Gather your thoughts about your product or website’s pros, cons, and areas of improvement, so you can create a solid hypothesis for your study.</p> \n<h3>2. Pick your study’s tasks.</h3> \n<p>Your participants' tasks should be your user’s most common goals when they interact with your product or website, like making a purchase.</p> \n<h3>3. Set a standard for success.</h3> \n<p>Once you know what to test and how to test it, make sure to set clear criteria to determine success for each task. For instance, when I was in a usability study for HubSpot’s Content Strategy tool, I had to add a blog post to a cluster and report exactly what I did. Setting a threshold of success and failure for each task lets you determine if your product's user experience is intuitive enough or not.</p> \n<h3>4. Write a study plan and script.</h3> \n<p>At the beginning of your script, you should include the purpose of the study, if you’ll be recording, some background on the product or website, questions to learn about the participants’ current knowledge of the product or website, and, finally, their tasks. To make your study consistent, unbiased, and scientific, moderators should follow the same script in each user session.</p> \n<h3>5. Delegate roles.</h3> \n<p>During your usability study, the moderator has to remain neutral, carefully guiding the participants through the tasks while strictly following the script. Whoever on your team is best at staying neutral, not giving into social pressure, and making participants feel comfortable while pushing them to complete the tasks should be your moderator</p> \n<p>Note-taking during the study&nbsp;is also just as important. If there’s no recorded data, you can’t extract any insights that’ll prove or disprove your hypothesis. Your team’s most attentive listener should be your note-taker during the study.</p> \n<h3>6. Find your participants</h3> \n<p>Screening and recruiting the right&nbsp;participants is the hardest part of usability testing. Most usability experts suggest <a href=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/blog/ux-usability-research-testing/\">you should only test five participants during each study</a>, but your participants should also closely resemble your actual user base. With such a small sample size, it’s hard to replicate your actual user base in your study.</p> \n<p>To recruit the ideal participants for your study, create the most detailed and specific persona as you possibly can and incentivize them to participate with a gift card or another monetary reward.</p> \n<p>Recruiting colleagues from other departments who would potentially use your product is also another option. But you don’t want any of your team members to know the participants because their personal relationship can create bias -- since they want to be nice to each other, the researcher might help a user complete a task or the user might not want to constructively criticize the researcher’s product design.</p> \n<h3>7. Conduct the study.</h3> \n<p>During the actual study, you should ask your participants to complete one task at a time, without your help or guidance. If the participant asks you how to do something, don’t say anything. You want to see how long it takes users to figure out your interface.</p> \n<p>Asking participants to “think out loud” is also an effective tactic -- you’ll know what’s going through a user’s head when they interact with your product or website.</p> \n<p>After they complete each task, ask for their feedback, like if they expected to see what they just saw, if they would’ve completed the task if it wasn’t a test, if they would recommend your product to a friend, and what they would change about it. This qualitative data can pinpoint more pros and cons of your design.</p> \n<h3>8. Analyze your data.</h3> \n<p>You’ll collect a ton of qualitative data after your study. Analyzing it will help you discover patterns of problems, gauge the severity of each usability issue, and provide design recommendations to the engineering team.</p> \n<p>When you analyze your data, make sure to pay attention to both the users’ performance and their feelings about the product. It’s not unusual for a participant to quickly and successfully achieve your goal but still feel negatively about the product experience.</p> \n<h3>9. Report your findings.</h3> \n<p>After extracting insights from your data, report the main takeaways and lay out the next steps for improving your product or website’s design and the enhancements you expect to see during the next round of testing.</p> \n<h2>The 3 Most Common Types of Usability Tests</h2> \n<h3>1. Hallway/Guerilla Usability Testing</h3> \n<p>This is where you set up your study somewhere with a lot of foot traffic. It allows you to ask randomly-selected people who have most likely never even heard of your product or website -- like passers-by -- to evaluate its user-experience.</p> \n<h3>2. Remote/Unmoderated Usability Testing</h3> \n<p>Remote/unmoderated usability testing has two main advantages: it uses third-party software to recruit target participants for your study, so you can spend less time recruiting and more time researching. It also allows your participants to interact with your interface by themselves and in their natural environment -- the software can record video and audio of your user completing tasks.</p> \n<p>Letting participants interact with your design in their natural environment with no one breathing down their neck can give you more realistic, objective feedback. When you’re in the same room as your participants, it can prompt them to put more effort into completing your tasks since they don’t want to seem incompetent around an expert. Your perceived expertise can also lead to them to please you instead of being honest when you ask for their opinion, skewing your user experience's reactions and feedback.</p> \n<h3>3. Moderated Usability Testing</h3> \n<p>Moderated usability testing also has two main advantages: interacting with participants in person or through a video a call lets you ask them to elaborate on their comments if you don’t understand them, which is impossible to do in an unmoderated usability study. You’ll also be able to help your users understand the task and keep them on track if your instructions don’t initially register with them.</p> \n<h2>Usability Testing Script &amp; Questions</h2> \n<p>Following one script or even a template of questions for every one of your usability studies wouldn't make any sense -- each study's subject matter is different. You'll need to tailor your questions to the things you want to learn, but most importantly, you'll need to know&nbsp;<em>how </em>to ask good questions.</p> \n<h3>1. When you [action], what's the first thing you do to [goal]?</h3> \n<p>Questions such as this one give insight into how users are inclined to interact with the tool and what their natural behavior is.</p> \n<p>Julie Fischer, one of HubSpot's Senior UX researchers, gives this advice:<em> \"Don't ask leading questions that insert your own bias or opinion into the participants' mind. They'll end up doing what you want them to do instead of what they would do by themselves.\"</em></p> \n<p>For example, <em>\"Find [x]\"</em> is a better than <em>\"Are you able to easily find [x]?\"</em> The latter inserts connotation that may affect how they use the product or answer the question.</p> \n<h3>2. How satisfied are you with the [attribute] of [feature]?</h3> \n<p>Avoid leading the participants by asking questions like <em>\"Is this feature too complicated?\"</em> Instead, gauge their satisfaction on a Likert scale that provides a number range from highly unsatisfied to highly satisfied. This will provide a less biased result than leading them to a negative answer they may not otherwise have had.</p> \n<h3>3. How do you use [feature]?</h3> \n<p>There may be multiple ways to achieve the same goal or utilize the same feature. This question will help uncover how users interact with a specific aspect of the product and what they find valuable.</p> \n<h3>4. What parts of [the product] do you use the most? Why?</h3> \n<p>This question is meant to help you understand the strengths of the product and what about it creates raving fans. This will indicate what you should absolutely keep and perhaps even lead to insights into what you can improve for other features.</p> \n<h3>5. What parts of [the product] do you use the least? Why?</h3> \n<p>This question is meant to uncover the weaknesses of the product or the friction in its use. That way, you can rectify any issues or plan future improvements to close the gap between user expectations and reality.</p> \n<h3>6. If you could change one thing about [feature] what would it be?</h3> \n<p>Because it's so similar to #5, you may get some of the same answers. However, you'd be surprised about the aspirational things that your users might say here.</p> \n<h3>7. What do you expect [action/feature] to do?</h3> \n<p>Here's another tip from Julie Fischer:</p> \n<p><em>\"When participants ask 'What will this do?' it's best to reply with the question 'What do you expect it do?' rather than telling them the answer.\" </em></p> \n<p>Doing this can uncover user expectation as well as clarity issues with the copy.</p> \n<h2>Your Work Could Always Use a Fresh Perspective</h2> \n<p>Letting another person review and possibly criticize your work takes courage -- no one wants a bruised ego. But most of the time, when you allow people to constructively criticize or even rip apart your article or product design, especially when your work is intended to help these people, your final result will be better than you could've ever imagined.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in August 2018 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fusability-testing&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 01 Oct 2020 11:30:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"0368000f507a8533c852cd2053f1bb60","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"cchi@hubspot.com (Clifford Chi)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fusability-testing&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn24@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-45-743_0fa459bd2fa98605.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389705},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"How to Craft Brand Messaging Your Target Audience Will Love","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/brand-communication-strategy","description":"<p>As a consumer — and a marketer — one of my favorite <a href=\"https://info.restaurantspacesevent.com/blog/taco-bell-reinvents-itself-into-a-full-fledged-lifestyle-brand\">brands to watch is Taco Bell</a>. In the last five years or so, Taco Bell has begun making strides in its brand messaging.</p>  \n<p>The brand has reinvented itself on social media, introducing a new, bold personality. With its food, packaging, marketing campaigns, events, philanthropic efforts, and interior design, Taco Bell reinvented itself into a full on lifestyle brand.</p> \n<p>Doing this — telling a compelling brand story through messaging — isn't easy.</p> \n<p>Marketers need to have an entire brand identity to communicate what their business does, what it's about, and why it's different. Oh, and it needs to resonate with people and strengthen your company's values and reputation.</p> \n<p>This is because, according to research from Bergische University, <a href=\"https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/mar.20805\">brands produce similar feelings as the ones we feel when we like someone</a>. So, we actually feel similarly about brands as we do about people.</p> \n<p>That's why marketers need to craft brand messaging that their audience can relate to.</p> \n<p>Below, let's review brand messaging — what it is and a framework to get started.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>It's how your consumers can have a relationship with your brand. Ultimately, it's the culmination of language, design, events, and philanthropic efforts that tell the story of who your brand is.</p> \n<p>So, how do you get started crafting brand messaging that your target audience will love?</p> \n<p>You need to know two things like the back of your hand: your target audience and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/sales/unique-selling-proposition\">unique value proposition</a>.</p> \n<p>Then, you can begin to write out a brand identity that'll help your company make all its marketing decisions. Would a brand that cares about \"X\" do this? Would a brand that's motivated by \"Y\" sell this?</p> \n<p>Your brand identity will inform your company's behavior because it'll tell you why your brand matters, what it stands for, and why it's different from other brands.</p> \n<p>A <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/agency/develop-brand-identity\">brand identity</a> that your audience relates to and has a personality — or talks to your audience like a friend — is how you'll continue to remain relevant to your consumers and create <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/service/customer-loyalty\">loyal customers</a>.</p> \n<h2>Brand Message Framework</h2> \n<p>With a full understanding of brand messaging and creating a brand identity, you might be wondering, <i>\"Now what? How do I get started?\"</i></p> \n<p>And it's a fair question. That's why we've created a brand message framework that you can use to begin crafting a brand message or identity.</p> \n<h3>1. Figure out who you are.</h3> \n<p>To get started, your brand message needs to answer these questions:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>How do you differentiate from your competitors?</li> \n <li>What is your unique value proposition?</li> \n <li>What kind of messaging will resonate with your target audience?</li> \n <li>Who is your target audience? What do they care about?</li> \n <li>Does your brand message tell a story?</li> \n <li>What are your company's goals? (No one is perfect and your target audience can't relate to a seemingly perfect brand).</li> \n <li>What are your company's values?</li> \n</ul> \n<p>While you're answering these questions and beginning to map out who your brand identity is and what your brand messaging will look like, remember that your brand message answers the question, <i>why?</i> Why does your audience care?</p> \n<h3>2. Know your audience.</h3> \n<p>Now that you have a better idea of what you offer and who you are, you need to understand who your audience is. If you haven't already, create <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/customers/ideal-customer-profiles-and-buyer-personas-are-they-different\">buyer personas</a> that represent who your customers are and their goals. This will help you find alignment between your brand and your consumers.</p> \n<h3>3. Start a document that explains your brand message.</h3> \n<p>After you've answered the questions above and written out your personas, begin compiling this information in a document that explains what your brand message is, your unique value proposition, and key themes that are core to your brand identity.</p> \n<p>Then, start to figure out how your brand identity relates to your buyer persona. What are the patterns and what do they have in common? This is how you'll make decisions on brand messaging. You'll see what your audience cares about that align with your values and can derive messaging opportunities.</p> \n<h3>4. Brainstorm messaging opportunities.</h3> \n<p>With a clear document that represents who you are and who your audience is, you can then begin to look for messaging opportunities. How can you relate your current campaigns to your brand message? How can you use content to convey your values?</p> \n<p>Once you have an idea, you can create a tagline that communicates who you are and your unique value proposition.</p> \n<p>At this point, you should have created a brand message and identity that'll inform your messaging. Now, we wanted to review a few tips for creating messaging that stays true to your brand:</p> \n<ol> \n <li><strong> Stay focused on the brand positioning: </strong>With all the content you write, ask yourself, <i>\"Is this true to our values?\"</i></li> \n <li><strong> Relate to your audience: </strong>When you create content, use your buyer personas and brand messaging document to ensure that you're talking about something that's relevant to your audience.</li> \n <li><strong> Don't be perfect: </strong>Similarly to the point above, people aren't perfect and brands shouldn't be either. Don't over promise and communicate that you're perfect, because you aren't and it'll come off disingenuous.</li> \n <li><strong> Communicate your message everywhere: </strong>In everything you write and all your marketing decisions, think about your brand message. Whether you're writing copy for your website, creating slogans for packaging, or marketing an event, your copy needs to communicate your brand message.</li> \n <li><strong> Be simple: </strong>Keep it simple. If your brand's personality or overall values are confusing or hard to discern, people won't relate to you. The last thing you want to do is create a brand message that your audience is confused by.</li> \n</ol> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://www.tacobell.com/\">Taco Bell</a></h3> \n<p>As mentioned above, Taco Bell has started to create a reputation for its strong, funny brand. If you tweet them, they will likely respond with a humorous comment.</p> \n<p>The goal is to be so relatable that customers love to interact and talk about Taco Bell. When people are talking about you and with you, they're more likely to be loyal customers.</p> \n<p>Below is an example of a tweet that represents Taco Bell's brand identity and messaging. They respond to tweets like a sarcastic, funny best friend would.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/taco-bell-example.jpg?width=600&amp;name=taco-bell-example.jpg\" alt=\"Taco Bell tweets a customer in a funny, sarcastic tone.\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 11px;\"><a href=\"https://twitter.com/tacobell/status/1201677471768203264\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://www.theskimm.com/\">TheSkimm</a></h3> \n<p>TheSkimm is a daily newsletter that aims to quickly inform young women of current events. The brand is known for having a bold, witty personality similar to that of its target audience — millennial women.</p> \n<p>The goal? To mirror its target audience. Act like the fun, irreverent best friend to help readers get started with their day.</p> \n<p>In the tweet below, theSkimm stays true to its <a href=\"https://www.brandchannel.com/2016/09/30/theskimm-093016/\">brand messaging and identity</a> by starting off with a sharp, witty comment on Congress.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/the-skimm-example.jpg?width=600&amp;name=the-skimm-example.jpg\" alt=\"The Skimm showcases its personality through brand messaging.\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 11px;\"><a href=\"https://twitter.com/theskimm/status/1205246833427177472\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://www.wearproclaim.com/\">Proclaim</a></h3> \n<p>Proclaim is a lingerie line that is \"expanding the definition of nude, one ethically made bra at a time.\" They tackle the lack of inclusivity in women's undergarments by creating products for all skin tones, and they do it with sustainable, Earth-friendly products. This value proposition is combined with their messaging, which celebrates diversity and nature.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/proclaim-brand-messaging.jpg?width=600&amp;name=proclaim-brand-messaging.jpg\" alt=\"proclaim's brand that celebrates diverse models and products in nature settings\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 11px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/wearproclaim/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://fabfitfun.com/\">FabFitFun</a></h3> \n<p>When I think of FabFitFun, I think of trendy products that are popular with self-care influencers. The brand has cultivated a following by partnering with influencers on Instagram who are trendy, fashionable, and take care of themselves.</p> \n<p>And this image of self-care and trendy products is carried out through its content as well. Below, the company tweeted its blog about trendy tech accessories. This type of content is right in line with the brand messaging consumers hear about on Instagram.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/fab-fit-fun-example.jpg?width=600&amp;name=fab-fit-fun-example.jpg\" alt=\"FabFitFun tweets blog aligning with personality and customer personas.\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 11px;\"><a href=\"https://twitter.com/FabFitFun/status/1204844753344331776\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"https://www.traderjoes.com/\">Trader Joe's</a></h3> \n<p>Trader Joe's is a grocery store that has created an almost cult-like following through its brand messaging. They are a fun, cheap, organic food store with a small-town, neighborhood feel. For example, they even put out an old-fashioned newsletter called the \"Fearless Flyer.\" This includes product roundups and recipes.</p> \n<p>The content Trader Joe's puts out reinforces its brand image as a small, neighborhood grocery store. With brand messaging that is consistent with its unique value proposition and personality, customers relate to the brand as if it were a person.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/trader-joes-example.jpg?width=444&amp;name=trader-joes-example.jpg\" alt=\"Trader Joes newsletter reveals brand identity.\" width=\"444\" style=\"width: 444px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 11px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.traderjoes.com/fearless-flyer\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h3>6. <a href=\"https://www.taylorswift.com/\">Taylor Swift</a></h3> \n<p>Besides the fact that Taylor Swift is one of my favorite singer/songwriters, I had to include her because her brand messaging is on point.</p> \n<p>From the time she was 16, Taylor Swift has used social media and brand messaging to connect with her fans. This is another example of someone who has created a cult-like following through brand messaging.</p> \n<p>Taylor Swift's brand is that she's like the girl next door, something her audience relates with. In the example below, someone on Tumblr posted a tweet on Swift's birthday, and Swift responded like … well, like the girl next door. A fun, outgoing best friend you can easily talk to on social media.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/taylor-swift-example.jpg?width=344&amp;name=taylor-swift-example.jpg\" alt=\"Taylor Swift uses Tumblr to reveal personality and brand identity.\" width=\"344\" style=\"width: 344px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"font-size: 11px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://taylorswift.tumblr.com/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source</a></p> \n<h3>7. <a href=\"https://hillaryweiss.com/\">Hillary Weiss</a></h3> \n<p>Large brands have more resources to invest into branding and awareness, so this list would not be complete without at least one personal brand (since I'm not sure that Taylor counts). Hillary Weiss is a great example to look to if you want an example of brand messaging that speaks directly to prospects. Her personality literally jumps off the page...</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hillary-weiss-brand-messaging.jpg?width=600&amp;name=hillary-weiss-brand-messaging.jpg\" alt=\"hillary weiss brand messaging: big ideas that stomp off the screen (along with photo of her coming out of a laptop screen)\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>... And it's her goal to make others' do the same with their brand positioning and copywriting. She comes right out and says it on her website:</p> \n<p>\"I'm Hillary Weiss, and I turn small businesses like yours into HUGE obsessions. Since 2011, I’ve helped thousands of personality-fueled brands define their Statement Piece — a.k.a. the big idea that makes them unmissable in their market, and radically relevant to their perfect people. Now it’s your turn. Let’s get loud (and rich) together.\"</p> \n<h3>8. <a href=\"https://www.loom.com/\">Loom</a></h3> \n<p>Good messaging often comes down to conveying value to your target audience and why you're doing what you're doing. Loom is a great example of this, and it helps that they have an amazing product.</p> \n<p>Their homepage says, \"Say it with video\" along with their tagline: \"The expressiveness of video with the convenience of messaging. Communicate more effectively wherever you work with Loom.\" The rest of their website backs up the assertion with facts to provide their point. For example, \"You talk up to 6 times faster than you type\" and \"Video conveys emotion and tone of voice that text simply can't.\"</p> \n<p>Even better, their brand messaging is further underscored in the testimonials of brand evangelists who truly believe in this value:</p> \n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\"> \n <p><a href=\"https://twitter.com/loom?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@loom</a> you’re changing lives over here. I know <a href=\"https://twitter.com/imcatnoone?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@imcatnoone</a> and <a href=\"https://twitter.com/ConnorPM?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@ConnorPM</a> feel similarly. <a href=\"https://t.co/a9qzt1shfm\">pic.twitter.com/a9qzt1shfm</a></p> — Alberto Orsini 🇵🇷 (@albertojorsini) \n <a href=\"https://twitter.com/albertojorsini/status/1299392126632046596?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">August 28, 2020</a>\n</blockquote>  \n<h3>9. <a href=\"https://www.dove.com/us/en/dove-self-esteem-project/our-mission.html#\">Dove</a></h3> \n<p>Branding goes so further than what you sell and why it's valuable. Dove recognizes this by making their brand about more than just having the best soap and care products. To them, their products mean enhancing the natural beauty of their customers and (more importantly) that beauty should be \"a source of confidence, not anxiety.\"</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/dove-brand-messaging.jpg?width=600&amp;name=dove-brand-messaging.jpg\" alt=\"dove's mission statement brand messaging\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>That's why Dove invests into realizing that mission with their Self-Esteem Project and taking a different approach with their advertising than simply discussing the features of their soap.</p> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; max-width: 623px; max-height: 350px; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.18%; margin: 0;\">\n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/XpaOjMXyJGk?autoplay=0&amp;fs=0&amp;iv_load_policy=3&amp;showinfo=0&amp;rel=0&amp;cc_load_policy=0&amp;start=0&amp;end=0\" width=\"623\" height=\"350\" frameborder=\"0\"></iframe>\n </div> \n</div> \n<h3>10. <a href=\"https://metierbrewing.com/\">Métier Brewing Company</a></h3> \n<p>Speaking of missions, Métier Brewing Company, founded in 2018, isn't just a brewery; it's an organization that's embedded in the community (and that means making the community better). According to their website, \"Great beer should be for everyone, and we don’t just mean the people drinking it. At MBC, we brew beer with everybody in mind: the suppliers who produce our ingredients, the brewers brewing, the staff who serve pints, and the broader community enjoying the beer.\"</p> \n<p>They embody this mission in all facets of their business from their beer hall and event space for hosting concerts and family gatherings to their support of The Major Taylor Project (an after-school bike education program to foster a sense of belong and empower youth, particularly those from underrepresented communities).</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/metier-brewing-company-brand-messaging.jpg?width=600&amp;name=metier-brewing-company-brand-messaging.jpg\" alt=\"metier brewing company's brand messaging: at metier brewing company our beers are outstanding, and our mission stands out\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Your personality and values should be evident and align with that of your audience. Your brand message is something that's strategically created to help you stand out and relate to your customers. For this reason, it can make a big difference in how you're perceived by prospects (and whether or not they want to do business with you), so start building your brand today.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>
