://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/how-to-verify-account-reese.jpg?width=450&name=how-to-verify-account-reese.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn77@2020_2/2020/10/09/03-33-51-260_e5737793246ada81.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Finstagram-features-tricks&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn92@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-45-934_f51532e82b0b432c.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389714},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"The Ultimate Guide to Account-Based Marketing (ABM)","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/account-based-marketing-guide","description":"<p>Imagine a world where you could <i>start</i> the sales process by selling directly to your best-fit, highest-value accounts. No wasted time working to market and sell to unqualified leads who aren’t the right fit for your business. Meaning, you could move straight into the phases of engaging and delighting your target accounts.</p> \n<p>Talk about efficiency, right?</p> \n<p>With <strong>account-based marketing</strong>, all of this is made possible. The process allows you to align your marketing and sales teams from the get-go to promote long-term business growth, delight customers, and boost revenue.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>This guide is here to help you make it happen. Let’s dive in.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p>Account-based marketing allows you to weed out less-valuable companies early on and ensure Marketing and Sales are in complete alignment — in return, your team can leap into the critical processes of engaging and delighting those accounts much faster.</p> \n<p>ABM helps your business work and communicate with high-value accounts as if they’re individual markets. By doing this — along with personalizing the buyer’s journey and tailoring all communications, content, and campaigns to those specific accounts — you'll see greater ROI and a boost in customer loyalty.</p> \n<p>Before we take a look at additional benefits of account-based marketing and specific tactics you can implement at your company, let’s review its relationship with another important strategy: <strong>inbound marketing</strong>.</p> \n<p>Often, these strategies are thought of as entirely different entities. However, they can be quite complementary.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Account-Based Marketing And Inbound Marketing</h2> \n<p>Batman and Robin. LeBron and D-Wade. Peanut butter and jelly. Arguably some of the strongest partnerships ever to exist 💪. These dynamic duos are forces to be reckoned with when they work <i>together</i>.</p> \n<p>Similarly, when paired, account-based marketing and inbound marketing have the power to make waves (the good ones) for your business.</p> \n<p>You might be wondering, “How exactly does this partnership work?”</p> \n<p>Well, we just reviewed the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/account-based-marketing-guide#what-is-account-based-marketing\">definition of account-based marketing</a> — as you learned, ABM is a highly-targeted strategy.</p> \n<p>Meanwhile, <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/inbound-marketing?_ga=2.118531978.2043081995.1586812054-1675356138.1572978608\">inbound marketing</a> is more foundational — the methodology and growth strategy allows you to attract customers through the creation of valuable content, SEO, and a delightful customer experience.</p> \n<p>Rather than interrupting your target audience and customers (as you would with outbound marketing), inbound marketing allows you to more organically provide your audience with the information they want when they want it. Inbound lays the foundation for a strong ABM strategy by allowing for highly-targeted and efficient resource allocation of high-value accounts.</p> \n<p>Here are a few more reasons to implement both <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/account-based-marketing-vs-inbound-marketing?_ga=2.118531978.2043081995.1586812054-1675356138.1572978608\">ABM and inbound marketing</a>:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Inbound marketing helps you attract target accounts and ABM then accelerates the <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/flywheel?_ga=2.118531978.2043081995.1586812054-1675356138.1572978608\">flywheel</a> so you can win and delight those target accounts with a remarkable customer experience (and as a result, you’ll <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/grow-better?_ga=2.194226990.2043081995.1586812054-1675356138.1572978608\">grow better)</a>.</li> \n <li>Inbound marketing lays the foundation for a strong ABM strategy — ABM builds off of inbound by allowing for targeted and efficient resource allocation of high-value accounts.</li> \n <li>With this combined approach, you attract a broader group of prospects than you would while using just one method and catch any opportunities the other strategy may have missed.</li> \n <li>Your content has a two-for-one value — you can create and use content that serves both an ABM and inbound strategy (e.g. create a personalized case study for a target account that you also share on your website).</li> \n <li>Software options, like <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/abm-software?_ga=2.165839805.2043081995.1586812054-1675356138.1572978608\">HubSpot’s account-based marketing software</a>, are available and make it easy to implement ABM and inbound strategies in a complementary way.</li> \n</ul> \n<p><strong>🧡</strong>TLDR: Combine ABM and inbound marketing to <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/grow-better?_ga=2.165839805.2043081995.1586812054-1675356138.1572978608\">grow better</a>.</p> \n<p>Next, we’ll take a look at some of the definable benefits of account-based marketing.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p></p> \n<p>There are a number of benefits associated with account-based marketing. We've compiled the following list of commonly-noted results that positively impact (all types of) businesses.</p> \n<h3>1. Keep Marketing and Sales aligned.</h3> \n<p>Cross-team collaboration and improved communication across any organization are beneficial to growth. In terms of account-based marketing, this transparency and alignment will ensure your marketing and sales teams are focused on the same goals, stick to the mutually-agreed-upon budget, and understand the specific roles of each internal stakeholder.</p> \n<p>This alignment helps ensure all communications, interactions, and content (and more) are consistent for the accounts you work with. Meaning, no matter how long an account works with your company, your team members can pick up where others left off at any point in time without question — this creates a seamless and delightful customer experience.</p> \n<p>🧡The easiest way to maintain internal account-based marketing alignment is with the help of software, like <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/abm-software?_ga=2.263906191.2043081995.1586812054-1675356138.1572978608\">HubSpot</a>, which makes connecting your marketing and sales teams exceptionally easy.<br><br /></br></p> \n<h3>2. Maximize your business’s relevance among high-value accounts.</h3> \n<p>Account-based marketing requires you to personalize everything (e.g. content, product information, communications, and campaigns) for each account you invest your resources in. Through this personalization and customization, your relevance among these accounts is maximized.</p> \n<p>That’s because your content and interactions are tailored in a way that shows them how your specific products, services, offerings, and team are what they <i>need</i> to solve their challenges and to grow better. Meaning, ABM allows you to angle your business in a way that makes it the most-relevant and ideal option for your target accounts.<br><br /></br></p> \n<h3>3. Deliver consistent customer experiences.</h3> \n<p>As mentioned, account-based marketing requires you to deliver consistent experiences for your accounts — this plays a major role in your success. A large part of the reason for this is because ABM is a long process that often lasts several months or years.</p> \n<p>So, for your ABM efforts to be remarkable, you must maintain a long-term sense of delight among your accounts. This is how you’ll make each account feel as though they’re your business’s market of <em>one</em> — and why would they ever want to stop doing business with you if that’s their experience?</p> \n<p>Delivering these long-term, consistent experiences may seem a bit daunting. Although this is understandable, the good news is that ABM is a process that naturally encourages you to do so.</p> \n<p>Think about it this way: We already discussed the way ABM requires Marketing and Sales to be aligned on all things related to each account (e.g. their goals, budget, unique needs, members of their team and buying committee).</p> \n<p>When there’s a universal understanding of these factors within your organization, Marketing and Sales (and anyone else involved) will be able to effectively and naturally deliver that feeling of consistency through everything they communicate and share with each account (e.g. personalized content, targeted campaigns, pricing and product information, and more).<br><br /></br></p> \n<h3>4. Measure your return on investment.</h3> \n<p>With account-based marketing, you can easily measure return on investment (ROI) for each account you invest your resources and time into. This is beneficial because you can confirm whether certain accounts you invested in were ideal for your business.</p> \n<p>Then, you can nurture and delight those accounts long term as well as identify and target similar accounts in the future. If your ROI proves your <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/account-based-marketing-guide#account-based-marketing-tactics\">ABM tactics</a> worked, use those results as a motivator to drive your strategy forward as well as one you can count on to continually improve your bottom line.<br><br /></br></p> \n<h3>5. Streamline the sales cycle.</h3> \n<p>Depending on your business, industry, and resources, the sales cycle typically looks something like this:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"background-color: #fce5cd;\"><strong>1) Prospect → 2) Connect → 3) Research → 4) Present → 5) Close → 6) Delight</strong></span></p> \n<p>With account-based marketing, this cycle is streamlined — by focusing your efforts on specific high-value target accounts, you save time and resources, and spend more time on the stages of the cycle that positively impact your bottom line:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong><span style=\"background-color: #fce5cd;\">1) Identify Target Accounts → 2) Present to Target Accounts → 3) Close Target Accounts → 4) Delight Accounts</span> </strong></p> \n<p>ABM streamlines your sales cycle by helping you stay efficient. Rather than experimenting with different tactics to prospect and qualify a large pool of leads, ABM ensures your target accounts are ideal for <i>your </i>business so you can quickly dive into building relationships.</p> \n<p>The sales cycle stage of <span style=\"font-style: italic;\">closing</span> is also streamlined through ABM. That’s because your <a href=\"https://blog.marketo.com/2017/11/key-successful-abm-marketing-sales-alignment.html\">chances of converting accounts and retaining them long term</a> increase thanks to marketing and sales alignment, consistent customer experiences, and personalization.<br><br /></br></p> \n<h3>6. Expand business through account relationships.</h3> \n<p>The saying \"quality over quantity” applies to account-based marketing. The process requires you to invest significant time and resources in engaging and delighting a group of carefully-chosen, high-value accounts, versus trying to quickly close deals with less-qualified leads who may not be the best fit for your company in the long run.</p> \n<p>By taking the time to build these trusting relationships with accounts, you’ll expand business by retaining those valuable customers longer. And considering it costs <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/happy-customers-marketing-opportunity?_ga=2.263906191.2043081995.1586812054-1675356138.1572978608\">more to obtain customers than retain them</a>, this will positively impact your bottom line.</p> \n<p>Additionally, as a result of personalized, thoughtful, and consistent customer experiences, accounts will become loyal to your business over time — and <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/happy-customers-marketing-opportunity?_ga=2.157844409.2043081995.1586812054-1675356138.1572978608\">loyal customers become your best marketers</a>, promoters, and brand advocates.</p> \n<p>In other words, your accounts will help you expand your business among <em>their</em> networks (e.g. partners, customers) through referrals, word-of-mouth marketing, testimonials, and more.</p> \n<p>Now let’s cover some account-based marketing tactics you can apply to your strategy to improve the likelihood of success.</p> \n<a></a> \n<br> <p>ABM tactics are the building blocks of your strategy — so, work through the following list to ensure your ABM efforts and investment are successful.</p> <h3>1. Secure organizational ABM alignment.</h3> <p>One of the most important account-based marketing tactics is arguably one of the most straightforward: Secure organizational ABM alignment.</p> <p>This means getting all internal stakeholders on board with the various factors related to your account-based marketing strategy. In doing so, it’ll be easier for your business to create consistent experiences for accounts and make sure your strategy is as efficient and streamlined as possible.</p> <p>For example, your VP of Marketing and VP of Sales should secure organizational alignment and spread awareness regarding:</p> \n <ul> \n  <li>Marketing and sales team members who are directly involved in the strategy</li> \n  <li>Account buying committee members and any other account stakeholders</li> \n  <li>Your business’s point-of-difference for each target account</li> \n  <li>ABM budget and resources</li> \n  <li>ABM goals and KPIs<br><br /></br></li> \n </ul> <h3>2. Build your ABM team.</h3> <p>Similar to the first tactic we reviewed above, VPs of Marketing and Sales will also likely be leaders in the discussion regarding how you’ll build your ABM team.</p> <p>They, along with managers on their respective teams, will need to identify a minimum of one marketer and one sales rep who will be completely dedicated to the accounts you work with.</p> <p>These people will create and publish content for accounts as well as work to manage and close business deals with each account’s buying committee. (As a rule of thumb, try to limit your team size to no more than ten sales reps and one marketer.)</p> <p>In addition to the marketer(s) and sales rep(s), don’t forget to identify any other internal key players — such as customer success reps — who should be aware of and aligned on your ABM strategy.<br><br /></br></p> <h3>3. Identify and pick your ideal set of target accounts.</h3> <p>Identify and pick your ideal set of high-value target accounts to invest your time and resources in.</p> <p>Here are some recommendations on how you can do this:</p> \n <ul> \n  <li>Set search alerts for your ideal customer profile on LinkedIn.</li> \n  <li>Create a workflow that filters incoming qualified leads based on specific criteria (e.g. company size, industry, etc.) and tags them as an ideal customer type in your <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/crm?_ga=2.157844409.2043081995.1586812054-1675356138.1572978608\">CRM</a>.</li> \n  <li>Ask, “If we could replicate one deal from last year, what would it be?” Then, use the characteristics of that deal (e.g. industry, company size, value) to help you identify other good-fit customers.</li> \n  <li>Pick target accounts based on a particular industry or geographical location.</li> \n  <li>Review major companies and leads who are using and engaging with your inbound content but don’t have a deal attached (yet!).</li> \n  <li>Identify the lighthouse accounts you could use for reference.</li> \n  <li>Stick to no more than 10 accounts per sales rep.<br><br /></br></li> \n </ul> <h3>4. Encourage Marketing and Sales to create account plans together.</h3> <p>Throughout this guide, you’ve probably picked up on the fact account-based marketing is a team effort. That’s why ensuring appropriate marketing and sales team members are involved in account planning is so important.</p> <p>Make sure Marketing and Sales ask the following questions while they work on account plans:</p> \n <ul> \n  <li>Who will we need to know at each account (e.g. buying committee members and account stakeholders)?</li> \n  <li>What content will we need to attract and engage account buying committee members (and any other stakeholders)?</li> \n  <li>Which channels will we use to share content with the right people at each account?</li> \n  <li>How will we (marketers and sales reps) provide the right type of support throughout each stage of the strategy and sales process — in other words, how will sales help at the outset and how will marketing support in the later stages?</li> \n </ul> <p><strong>🧡</strong>Store your account plans as pinned notes in your <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/crm?_ga=2.157844409.2043081995.1586812054-1675356138.1572978608\">HubSpot CRM</a>, Google Docs, <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/productivity/project-management/asana?_ga=2.157844409.2043081995.1586812054-1675356138.1572978608\">Asana</a> Boards, pinned messages in <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/sales/sales-enablement/slack?_ga=2.157844409.2043081995.1586812054-1675356138.1572978608\">Slack</a>, and more to allow for easy access and collaboration.</p> <p>Here are a few other tips Marketing and Sales can use to make your account plans successful:</p> \n <ul> \n  <li>Ensure Marketing and Sales align on your product or service’s value proposition and point-of-difference for every account.</li> \n  <li>Create personalized content — or update existing content — so it’s tailored to each unique account.</li> \n  <li>Customize your allocated resources and budget for each account.<br><br /></br></li> \n </ul> <h3>5. Attract contacts from high-quality accounts.</h3> <p>Next, you’ll want to attract the buying committee members and stakeholders of your target accounts. Depending on how long you’ve been in business and any previous ABM work you’ve done, you may or may not already have contacts for specific accounts.</p> <p>The key to successfully attracting high-quality accounts is to personalize content to those accounts — this will help you elevate brand awareness and maximize relevance among audience members.</p> <p>Here are some GDPR-compliant recommendations for attracting high-quality accounts:</p> \n <ul> \n  <li>Engage accounts on social media (e.g. determine which platforms they’re on, join the groups they’re in, contribute to conversations they're a part of, and share helpful and relevant content you’ve created).</li> \n  <li>Produce a podcast or video series and invite a leader from the account to be a special guest.</li> \n  <li>Sponsor a booth at a target account’s conference or event.</li> \n  <li>Send direct messages via social media and direct mail via email or post.</li> \n  <li>Communicate through LinkedIn InMail outreach (do this simply and <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/integrations/how-to-connect-hubspot-and-linkedin-sales-navigator?_ga=2.157844409.2043081995.1586812054-1675356138.1572978608\">without ever leaving HubSpot</a> with the <a href=\"https://ecosystem.hubspot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/social-media/linkedin?_ga=2.157844409.2043081995.1586812054-1675356138.1572978608\">LinkedIn integration</a>).</li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/landing-pages?_ga=2.157844409.2043081995.1586812054-1675356138.1572978608\">Build custom landing pages</a> tailored to the needs, questions, and concerns of accounts.</li> \n  <li>Offer gifts for engagement and interaction (e.g. prizes, swag, and discount codes).</li> \n  <li>Distribute content such as blog articles across channels that are relevant to each account (e.g. website, social media, and magazines).</li> \n  <li>Create <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/marketing-campaigns?_ga=2.157844409.2043081995.1586812054-1675356138.1572978608\">ad campaigns</a> and social ads to target different factors such as location, skill, and job title.</li> \n  <li>Ask current contacts, accounts, and customers for referrals.</li> \n  <li>Invite contacts to (physical or digital) events and ask attendees to invite their colleagues.<br><br /></br></li> \n </ul> <h3>6. Forge strong relationships with the account’s buying committee.</h3> <p>Once you’ve attracted high-value accounts, it’s time to forge strong relationships with their buying committees. This is something your team will likely work on over an extended period of time — in fact, it often takes months and even years to develop these bonds. Think of this tactic as one tied to delighting your accounts — you never stop the process of delight.</p> <p>Here are some thoughts on how you can forge strong, long-lasting relationships with an account’s buying committee.</p> \n <ul> \n  <li>Provide education around the value your business — and your product/ service — brings accounts through tailored interactions and engagement.</li> \n  <li>Create and share personalized content, such as case studies, to prove the ways you’ll exceed expectations and resolve the challenges of each account.</li> \n  <li>Communicate one-on-one when possible to make buying committee members feel like they’re your only priority.</li> \n  <li>Host events with and for account members (e.g. dinner) so they get to know your brand and team on a personal level.</li> \n  <li>Stick to organized, well-timed meetings.</li> \n  <li>Use <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/sales/sales-automation?_ga=2.157844409.2043081995.1586812054-1675356138.1572978608\">email sequencing</a> to enhance all communication, be professional, and maintain consistency.</li> \n </ul> \n <div class=\"docos-anchoreddocoview-content docos-docoview-replycontainer\"> \n  <div class=\"docos-anchoredreplyview docos-replyview-comment\"> \n   <div class=\"docos-collapsible-replyview\"> \n    <div class=\"docos-replyview-static\"> \n     <p>🧡<a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/abm-software\" style=\"font-style: normal;\">HubSpot's ABM Software <span style=\"font-style: italic;\">Target Accounts Home</span> and <span style=\"font-style: italic;\">Account Overview</span> features</a> will help you forge these strong relationships.&nbsp;</p> \n    </div> \n   </div> \n  </div> \n </div> <p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/case-study-templates?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase&amp;_ga=2.157844409.2043081995.1586812054-1675356138.1572978608\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Learn how to showcase your company's success using compelling case studies with a free case study creation kit.</a><br><br /></br></p> <h3>7. Measure and analyze your ABM results (and make necessary iterations).</h3> <p>While working through and upon completion of the tactics above, it’s crucial you monitor your success. By reviewing and analyzing your ABM results, you’ll identify any gaps or parts of your strategy that need to be changed. This will allow you to make your strategy more effective for your business, marketing and sales teams, and accounts.</p> <p>Here are some examples of common account-based marketing KPIs that provide insight into how you’re doing:</p> \n <ul> \n  <li>Deal creation</li> \n  <li>Account penetration (net new contacts added to an account)</li> \n  <li>Account engagement</li> \n  <li>Deal-to-close time</li> \n  <li>Net-new revenue</li> \n  <li>Percent of deals closed</li> \n </ul> <p>🧡For support with your analysis, enlist the help of <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/abm-software?_ga=2.157844409.2043081995.1586812054-1675356138.1572978608\">HubSpot's library of <span style=\"font-style: italic;\">12+ ABM reports</span> and <span style=\"font-style: italic;\">pre-built ABM reporting dashboard</span></a> to gain valuable insight into how to modify your ABM strategy for greater success.</p> <h2>Grow Better With Account-Based Marketing</h2> <p>Account-based marketing doesn’t have to be overwhelming. By working through the tactics we’ve listed above and implementing software — such as <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/abm-software?_ga=2.165732413.2043081995.1586812054-1675356138.1572978608\">HubSpot’s ABM software</a> — for your marketing and sales team to use <span style=\"font-style: italic;\">together</span>, you’ll identify valuable accounts more efficiently, reduce any friction impacting your flywheel, and grow better.</p> <p></p> <p></p> <img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Faccount-based-marketing-guide&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \" /></br>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 07 Oct 2020 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"d6df8b44d266db8fc86fcb4c0029b6fe","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"krbaker@hubspot.com (Kristen Baker)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Faccount-based-marketing-guide&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389713},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"3 High-Impact Marketing Strategies You're Probably Overlooking","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/high-impact-marketing-channels-list","description":"<p>Everyone wants to be #1 ... <em>especially</em> when it comes to marketing.</p> \n<p>Reaching the top of search engine results and creating content that becomes viral is a marketer's dream — but it's often not that simple.</p> \n<p>Creating good, high-quality marketing campaigns mean creating content that aligns with your marketing goals, target audience's interests, brand voice, and so much more.</p> \n<p>Plus, it needs to be effective without breaking the bank or surpassing the resourcing constraints your team might be up against.</p> \n<p>Additionally, building a strong online presence takes time and patience. Marketing campaigns can only be effective once you've invested in properly defining your value proposition, messaging, and brand authority.</p> \n<p>Fortunately, there are three high-impact marketing strategies you can implement to see maximum results. Here, we'll dive into three highly effective campaigns you might use for both quick wins, <em>and </em>impressive long-term results.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3><strong>1. It's More Than Just LinkedIn: Account-Based Marketing</strong></h3> \n<p>LinkedIn Ads are the leading tool for generating new leads in B2B and a great start to any ABM campaign.</p> \n<p>On LinkedIn you can <a href=\"https://www.penguinstrategies.com/blog/linkedin-ads-part-one-roi-and-targeting\"><span>target</span></a> by company, location, job title, and more, which can help you reach the right people at the right time. You can even set it up right from your <a href=\"https://knowledge.hubspot.com/ads/create-linkedin-lead-gen-ads-in-hubspot\"><span>Hubspot Account</span></a>!</p> \n<p>But you don't have to stop there. You need to build the journey <em>beyond</em> the ads. For instance, how will you nurture leads, who will nurture them, and when?</p> \n<p>To maximize engagement with your ABM campaign, <a href=\"https://www.penguinstrategies.com/blog/account-based-marketing-tactics-inbound-synergy\"><span>combine it with an inbound campaign</span></a>. Build an infrastructure of additional content and emails to nurture your new leads and keep them engaged. Be sure to constantly refresh your content to maintain relevance and new interest.</p> \n<p>Here's a five-step plan to build an effective ABM campaign with inbound tactics:</p> \n<ol> \n <li>Designate an owner of the campaign and ensure buy-in from all team members company-wide.</li> \n <li>Create a LinkedIn Lead Generation campaign focused on your ideal companies' industry with captivating ads.</li> \n <li>Create or update existing landing pages and content that speak directly to the targeted audience. Customize the messaging and design to really grab their attention and create a connection.</li> \n <li>Set up a workflow that will take the new leads and nurture them with the above content, as well as specialized landing pages (for advanced campaigns, set a nurture for each company or industry with customized content and messaging for each).</li> \n <li>Monitor the leads and their engagement so you can reach out with the right content at the right time.</li> \n</ol> \n<h3><strong>2. Two is Better than One: Partnerships</strong></h3> \n<p>An often untapped source for high-impact marketing is partner collaboration. Finding a partner with whom to create a piece of content is highly effective both in terms of engagement and costs.</p> \n<p>Partners will have a different perspective and can provide insights that you might not have considered. Plus, the backlinks is valuable from an SEO perspective. The assets you create with your partner can be shared with both of your brand's networks, expanding your exposure and enabling you to reach new audiences.</p> \n<p>Simple ways to create these partnerships include offering a guest blog post, inviting a speaker to join you on a webinar, or creating an infographic that showcases both companies' expertise.</p> \n<p>Make sure to choose your partners wisely. Your partner should have shared values, a strong following, and provide value to your target audience.</p> \n<p>For instance, in early 2020 our company planned on hosting a Hubspot User Group (HUG) at the Google Campus in Tel Aviv. Following the pandemic and subsequent social distancing, all plans were canceled and companies were forced to adapt at lightning speed. All of a sudden, physical meet-ups were out of the question.</p> \n<p>To solve for this, we decided to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/run-successful-virtual-conference\"><span>host a virtual event</span></a> in less than three weeks. Thanks to a dedicated staff and strong partnerships, some of the industry's top marketing leaders reached out to us about how they could take part in the event.</p> \n<p>These leaders' involvement brought on a snowball effect of leads from their networks interested in joining the event. Plus, although our HUGs are normally restricted to 300 registrants due to space limitations, we were able to accept over <a href=\"https://www.penguinstrategies.com/blog/how-to-generate-a-record-number-of-leads-from-a-virtual-event\"><span>1,200 registrants</span></a> to the virtual event.</p> \n<h3><strong>3. Actions Speak Louder than Words: Customer Evangelism</strong></h3> \n<p>Customer evangelism may be one of the most impactful tools for generating high-potential leads. You can create amazing campaigns, but nothing compares to a freely given recommendation by a satisfied client.</p> \n<p>The inbound flywheel is made up of three sections; Attract, Engage, and Delight. If you don't delight your customers, then your flywheel can't reach maximum speed.</p> \n<p>A customer evangelism program is not a linear campaign. You must delight your customers at all touchpoints, so when an opportunity arises they will gladly recommend you to their network.</p> \n<p>Moving beyond impeccable service and outstanding results, think of other creative ways to connect with clients and build your relationships. This can be anything from shout-outs on social media for wins, to sending new year wishes to show you are thinking of them. Ultimately, a little generosity can go a long way.</p> \n<p>Recently, one of our customers was on LinkedIn when he came across a post from a connection who hadn't heard of us. Because he was delighted with our services, our customer commented that the connection should check us out — one day later, he was speaking with a sales rep in the first step to becoming a new customer.</p> \n<p>You are already constantly in touch with your customers, and they have endless potential to bring in new business — don't let that go to waste.</p> \n<p>These strategies are only the first step in building a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/marketing-strategy\"><span>high-impact marketing strategy</span></a>. They must be combined with a full strategic plan aligned across your entire company, from marketing to sales to customer success and beyond.</p> \n<p>Each campaign is only one block inside a larger marketing plan that needs to cover all stages of the flywheel. No campaign can live on its own.</p> \n<p>Additionally, it's important to remember the importance of monitoring old campaigns to gather insights and ensure you're optimizing each future campaign for better results.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhigh-impact-marketing-channels-list&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 06 Oct 2020 15:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"89396010d2b34407ab7b7a5583911767","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Yoni Grysman","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhigh-impact-marketing-channels-list&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn59@2020_5/2020/10/09/03-33-48-913_f6d1ee10b7fcedbe.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389713},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"How to Create an Editorial Calendar in Google Calendar [Free Templates]","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/create-robust-editorial-calendar-ht","description":"<p>One of the most frequent questions we get from aspiring and current inbound marketers is, \"How do you manage all of that content?\"</p> \n<p>When we tell them we use an editorial calendar, the next question is often, \"Oh, how much does that cost?\"</p>  \n<p></p> \n<p>Nothing. Because, for the most part, we use Google Calendar.</p> \n<p>Surprised? There are a lot of great calendar tools out there you can choose from. (In fact, for those of you who are HubSpot customers, there's <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/customers/new-calendar\">a marketing calendar built right into HubSpot's software</a>.) But after trying a ton of other solutions, our team found that we really operated the best with just a simple Google Calendar. In fact, this has actually been the longest-running editorial calendar solution our team has ever seen.</p> \n<p>Here's how we set it up.</p> \n<h3>Follow Along With <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/editorial-calendar-templates?hubs_post-cta=body\">Free Editorial Calendar Templates</a></h3> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/editorial-calendar-templates?hubs_post-cta=image\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-10-23%20at%205.10.04%20PM.png?width=2296&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-10-23%20at%205.10.04%20PM.png\" alt=\"HubSpot's Blog Editorial Calendar - Free Template in Excel\" width=\"2296\" style=\"width: 2296px;\"></a><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/editorial-calendar-templates?hubs_post-cta=imagebottom\">Download the Template for Free</a></p> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/editorial-calendar-templates?_ga=2.241189250.1881622160.1600360775-2015275129.1600360775\">Download HubSpot's free editorial calendar templates.</a></h3> \n<p>First thing's first: Download the calendar templates, above (they're free.) By doing this, you'll have three editorial calendar templates on your computer to use at your leisure: one for Google Calendar, one for Excel, and one for Google Sheets. In this blog post, we'll be going over <strong>how to import the Excel template into Google Calendar</strong>.</p> \n<h3>2. Customize your template and prepare for import into Google Calendar.</h3> \n<p>By default, the publish dates on the templates you download will be stamped for the year 2016. Feel free to change them to the present year in the spreadsheet itself -- you can also drag them to the dates of your choosing after you upload the file into Google Calendar.</p> \n<p>Google Calendar makes it easy to load a calendar you might have pre-created in another program into Google. This includes Microsoft Excel. Here's how to import the Excel calendar template you downloaded in the previous step into Google Calendar:</p> \n<h3>3. Open Google Calendar.</h3> \n<p>Once you've downloaded (or, for that matter, created) a calendar that opens in Microsoft Excel, it's time to open Google Calendar. Just make sure you're already logged into the Gmail account you want this calendar to give access to.</p> \n<h3>4. Use the lefthand dropdown menu to create a new calendar.</h3> \n<p>Now it's time to set up your Google Calendar to accommodate the information in your Excel spreadsheet. First, go into your Google Calendar and click the plus sign to the right of \"Other Calendars,\" as shown in the screenshot below. In the dropdown menu that appears, select \"Create new calendar.\"</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/create-new-calendar.jpg?width=350&amp;name=create-new-calendar.jpg\" alt=\"Adding a New Calendar in Google Calendar\" width=\"350\" style=\"width: 350px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<h3>5. Fill out the details of your new calendar.</h3> \n<p>Fill out the fields that appear on the next screen. This includes a brief description of your calendar, as shown below, to give people proper context when you invite them into this calendar. When you're done filling in the details, click \"Create calendar.\"</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/create-calendar-google-calendar.png?width=378&amp;name=create-calendar-google-calendar.png\" width=\"378\" style=\"width: 378px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"Adding Details in Google Calendar to Create New Calendar\"></p> \n<h3>6. Import your XLS or CSV file from the same dropdown menu.</h3> \n<p>Using the same dropdown menu you used to create your editorial calendar, you'll now import the Excel file itself into Google Calendar. Click that plus sign and select \"Import.\"</p> \n<p>Click the upload box that reads \"Select file from your computer,\" and locate the file entitled \"Blog Editorial Calendar - Excel\" that was included in the ZIP file you downloaded in Step 1, above.</p> \n<h3>7. Select which calendar to add this file to.</h3> \n<p>In the second box below your imported file, click the \"Add to calendar\" dropdown. Be sure to choose the name of the calendar you just created from the dropdown menu, as shown below. Then, click \"Import.\"</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/import-file-google-calendar.png?width=420&amp;name=import-file-google-calendar.png\" alt=\"Import Excel Calendar in Google Calendar\" width=\"420\" style=\"width: 420px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<h3>8. Click Import.</h3> \n<p>Once you've uploaded your Excel file and selected the calendar you want to add this file to, click \"Import.\" You should see an Import calendar dialog box telling you that seven events were successfully imported. Click \"Close.\"</p> \n<p>Now, if you didn't change the dates of the first seven assignments in the original Excel document, you can now. Navigate to January 3, 2016, which is the start of your calendar. Be sure all of your other calendars are temporarily hidden by clicking the colored box to the left of the calendar name. On the week of January 3, 2016, you should just see one \"Blog TBD\" calendar event on each day from 10 a.m. to 11 a.m.</p> \n<p>Use the edit window of each assignment to change the publish date. For example, if you're satisfied with the 10 a.m. publish time, you can simply change the date from January X, 2016 to January X, 2019. Each assignment will then appear as event blocks in your 2019 monthly calendar view.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h3>9. Determine your publishing schedule.</h3> \n<p>Now that you have your calendar created, it's time to fill it in with assignments for the year. This is when you have to make some decisions about your blog's publishing schedule.</p> \n<p>While the Excel file you imported accounts for one blog post per day, this doesn't mean you need to publish seven days a week. Maybe you want to publish every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday. Or perhaps you plan on publishing on just Thursdays. Remember, the key to successful blogging is quality over quantity. Don't overcommit to a blogging schedule if the quality of your content will take a hit. (<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/blogging-frequency-benchmarks\">Read this blog post</a> for some great benchmark data on how often companies should blog.)</p> \n<p>If you decide to decrease the number of days you want to publish, click on the calendar event of that day and select \"Delete.\"</p> \n<p>Even if you wanted to publish multiple times a day, updating this calendar is as easy as adding an event. Select a slot on your calendar to add another \"Blog TBD\" event and copy the default description from another one of the events you imported.</p> \n<p>Next, it's time for some minor adjustments. Currently, the \"Blog TBD\" events are set for 10 a.m. Feel free to move these events to whichever time your blog publishes during the day.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>10. Set up recurring events.</h3> \n<p>Now that you have your publish dates and times set, you can make these recurring events on your calendar. If you have a regular publishing schedule, like every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday at 10:00 a.m., then put that in as a recurring \"slot\" on your calendar. It's okay if you don't have a piece of completed content -- or even a working title -- to put there yet. It's just a reminder that you want to publish <em>something </em>that day.</p> \n<p>To add your recurring slot, click on your first \"Blog TBD\" event and click the pencil icon to edit your event. This will take you to the details of the post, where you can create a custom recurring schedule for each assignment, as shown in the screenshot below.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/custom-repeat-schedule.jpg?width=430&amp;name=custom-repeat-schedule.jpg\" alt=\"Setting Custom Repeat Schedule in Google Calendar for Recurring Event\" width=\"430\" style=\"width: 430px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">You can set the post up as a recurring post so it automatically appears every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday at 10:00 a.m. (or whatever days and times you want).</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/custom-repeat-google-editorial-calendar.jpg?width=402&amp;name=custom-repeat-google-editorial-calendar.jpg\" alt=\"Setting Custom Recurrence in Google Calendar for Recurring Event\" width=\"402\" style=\"width: 402px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p>Once you've selected the recurring days, hit \"Done\" and \"Save,\" and you'll have an editorial calendar framework to work with.</p> \n<p>For now, keep the title of the event as \"Blog TBD,\" but feel free to customize the description with any extra details you want to be sure you include for each post. Wait to invite any guest, as we'll use this to assign posts to an author once you begin filling in your topics. With everything complete, click \"Save.\"</p> \n<p>If you don't have a recurring schedule like this, you might not be in need of an editorial calendar just yet -- but it is a good way to set goals for yourself. If you know you want to publish a certain number of posts each week, even if you don't hit every single slot, it's a good reminder for yourself and your team that this is something you should all be striving for.</p> \n<h3>11. Fill your publishing slots.</h3> \n<p>Now that you know all of the slots you <em>want </em>to fill, you gotta actually ... you know ... fill 'em. (If you don't have topic ideas yet, <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/blog-topic-generator\">check out this free topic idea generator</a>. It'll give you some good ideas for content to put in the calendar.)</p> \n<p>Let's say one of the posts you want to write is \"10 Surprising Facts About Tapirs,\" and one of the posts you've already written and want to publish later is \"Think You're Cut Out to Own a Tapir? Read This First.\" Cool! Just add 'em both to the calendar by clicking on \"Post - TBD\" on the correct date, choosing \"Edit Event,\" and then changing the \"Post - TBD\" text to the actual title of the post.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/change-name-of-post.png?width=390&amp;name=change-name-of-post.png\" alt=\"Changing Name of Post in Google Editorial Calendar\" title=\"change-name-of-post.png\" width=\"390\" style=\"width: 390px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>Now, let's say you don't actually want to write \"10 Surprising Facts About Tapirs,\" and you want your colleague to write it instead. To assign the post an author, you'll invite them to the event as a guest. To do this, click on the event, hit \"Edit Event,\" then invite that colleague to the post by typing his or her name or email address into the \"Add guests\" box, selecting \"Add\" when their name pops up, and hitting \"Save\" on the event once you're done.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/add-guests-editorial-google-calendar.jpg?width=690&amp;name=add-guests-editorial-google-calendar.jpg\" alt=\"Adding Guests in Google Calendar\" width=\"690\" style=\"width: 690px;\"></p> \n<p>Now, anyone can see who is responsible for writing the post that's going up in that time slot.</p> \n<p>You can take it a step further by adding details to the \"Description\" box of the event, as shown in the large box in the screenshot above. You might include a quick synopsis, the keywords you plan to target the post for, the target audience you're trying to reach, and the offer or CTA you will direct the reader to at the end of the post. Don't forget a due date for the draft.</p> \n<p>Before Google Calendar will let you save the event, you'll see a dialog box asking if you would like to change just this event or all of the events in the series. Select \"Only this event.\"</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/save-only-this-event.jpg?width=348&amp;name=save-only-this-event.jpg\" alt=\"Edit Recurring Event to Save Only This Event\" width=\"348\" style=\"width: 348px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p>Repeat these steps to assign each blog topic today and in the future.</p> \n<h3>12. Share your editorial calendar with others.</h3> \n<p>Now that you have your calendar set up, you can start to invite people to see it. I'd recommend you start with your immediate team and regular contributors -- as well as anyone who regularly asks you about publishing content on your company blog.</p> \n<p>To share this editorial calendar with people, simply find your editorial calendar under \"My Calendars,\" as shown below. Click the three dots next to the calendar name and then select \"Settings and sharing\" when it appears in the dropdown menu. You'll be taken to the same screen we saw when you first filled out the details of your editorial calendar in Step 2.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/sharing-settings-google-calendar.jpg?width=415&amp;name=sharing-settings-google-calendar.jpg\" alt=\"Sharing Settings in Google Calendar\" width=\"415\" style=\"width: 415px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">Then, you can add in the names of people with whom you'd like to share the calendar and set the right permission levels for each invitee.</p> \n<p>It's wise to keep those with the permission settings to manage changes and sharing to a minimum so there aren't too many cooks in the kitchen -- but I recommend you let everyone see all event details so it's clear exactly what content is going up in each slot.</p> \n<p>Under the \"Share with specific people\" heading, enter the email addresses of those on your content team and decide if they have viewing, editing, or admin privileges. Save your updated settings.</p> \n<h2>Why Using Google Calendar as an Editorial Calendar Works</h2> \n<p>I mentioned earlier that we tried a lot of different editorial calendar solutions, and this is the only one that's stuck for more than a couple months. I think one reason for that is because we use Gmail for our corporate email, which means everyone on our team is already in Gmail (and their calendar, specifically) all day. As a result, it isn't hard for people to form a habit of checking the editorial calendar, because it's not difficult for them to find it.</p> \n<p>Google Calendar also makes things really easy to move around and schedule because ... well ... it's already a calendar. It has all the functionality you need to schedule stuff out and let the people who need to know about it know. When we were using other solutions for this, we were trying to hack a calendaring function instead of just relying on one that already existed.</p> \n<p>Along those lines, adding people to view your calendar is simple, which makes it easy for multiple teams to collaborate, see what's being published, and figure out when they might be able to launch content and campaigns.</p> \n<p>Finally, this sets a precedent for other teams to coordinate with you in a really simple way. You can have a calendar for upcoming campaigns, offers, social media pushes, product launches -- you name it. And you can all share those calendars with one another for a single-screen view of everything that's going on so you can coordinate more easily.</p> \n<p>Are there other solutions of there for maintaining an editorial calendar? Of course. But if you're looking for a minimum viable product, and a free one at that, this ain't too shabby. It's kept our content team sane, agile, and transparent for quite some time -- and I think it could do the same for you.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in January 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p>  \n<img lendar.jpg?width=415&name=sharing-settings-google-calendar.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn36@2020_3/2020/10/09/03-33-47-027_8f051bff4fc66d83.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcreate-robust-editorial-calendar-ht&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn36@2020_1/2020/10/09/03-33-48-734_627e46108856bdbd.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602214389704},{"createdTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","updatedTime":"2020-10-09 11:33:09","title":"The Ultimate Guide to Content Marketing in 2020","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-marketing","description":"<p>Your customers, leads, and audience members want valuable content from your business. And that content needs to reach audience members in a way that feels natural and organic versus being disruptive.</p> \n<p>By honing in on effective content marketing, you can do just that — and as a result, increase conversions, improve brand awareness, boost revenue, establish yourself as an industry leader, and more.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>In this guide, we'll give you a birds-eye-view of content marketing, types of content marketing, content marketing examples, and how to get a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-marketing-plan\">strategy</a> going.</p> \n<p></p> \n<a></a> \n<h2>Content Marketing</h2> \n<p>Today, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/2989/inbound-marketing-vs-outbound-marketing.aspx\">outbound marketing</a> strategies (or anything that interrupts your audience members) aren’t as effective at resonating with and converting audience members as they once were.</p> \n<p>Today, your content needs to reach your audience in a way that feels natural (a.k.a. <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/inbound-marketing\">inbound</a>). A common way of doing this is by creating a narrative for your content — or telling a story. In doing so, your content will feel more authentic, engaging, and tailored to your audience.</p> \n<div class=\"hs-embed-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; width: 100%; height: auto; padding: 0px; max-width: 560px; max-height: 315px; min-width: 256px; display: block; margin: auto;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-embed-content-wrapper\"> \n  <div style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.25%; margin: 0px;\"> \n   <iframe style=\"position: absolute; top: 0px; left: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/0RoZHfg7uiE?feature=oembed\" width=\"480\" height=\"270\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe> \n  </div> \n </div> \n</div> \n<p>So, what defines content marketing anyway?</p> \n<a></a> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; font-weight: 400;\"></span></p> \n<h3>Why is content marketing important?</h3> \n<p>Content marketing can also help your business with the following:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Educate your leads and prospects about the products and services you offer</li> \n <li>Boost conversions</li> \n <li>Build relationships between your customers and business that result in increased loyalty</li> \n <li>Show your audience how your products and services solve their challenges</li> \n <li>Create a sense of community around your brand</li> \n</ul> Now let's look at the various types of content marketing. \n<br> <a></a> <h2>Types of Content Marketing</h2> <p>There are many types of content marketing that you may choose to incorporate in your strategy — here are some of the most common:</p> <h3>1. Social Media Content Marketing</h3> <p>With over <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/278414/number-of-worldwide-social-network-users/#:~:text=Social%20media%20usage%20is%20one,almost%204.41%20billion%20in%202025.&amp;text=Social%20network%20penetration%20is%20constantly,2020%20stood%20at%2049%20percent.\">3.6 billion global social media users</a>, it’s easy to understand why so many businesses invest in <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-marketing\">social media marketing</a>. There are a number of platforms (e.g. Facebook, Instagram, Pinterest, LinkedIn, Snapchat) to work with and several ways you can create and share content on each of them (e.g. photos, live videos, pre-recorded videos, stories).</p> <p><strong>Featured Resource: </strong><span style=\"color: #33475b;\"></span><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/social-media-content-calendar?hubs_post-cta=inline-text\">Social Media Content Calendar</a></p> <h3>2. Infographic Content Marketing</h3> <p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/create-infographics-with-free-powerpoint-templates\">Infographics</a> display content, information, and data in an easy-to-understand, graphic format. With a mix of simple wording, short statements, and clear images, infographics are a great way to effectively communicate your content. They work well if you’re trying to distill an educational and/ or complex topic down so all audience members can understand it.</p> <p><strong>Featured Resource:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/infographic-templates?hubs_post-cta=inline-text\">15 Free Infographic Templates</a></p> <h3>3. Blog Content Marketing</h3> <p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/34133/39-fantastic-inbound-marketing-blogs-you-ought-to-be-reading.aspx\">Blogs are a powerful type of inbound content</a> and allow for a lot of creativity in terms of their purpose and topic. With a blog, you can do things like promote other internal and external content and blog articles via links, add social share buttons, and incorporate product information.</p> <p><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Featured Resource:</span> <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/how-to-start-a-successful-blog\">Start a Successful Blog</a></p> <h3>4. Podcast Content Marketing</h3> <p>In a 2020 survey, it was found that <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/270365/audio-podcast-consumption-in-the-us/#:~:text=In%202020%2C%20a%20survey%20on,tripled%20over%20the%20past%20decade.\">37% of U.S. adults</a> listened to a podcast within the last month. For this reason, many businesses and media outlets have began creating and sharing their own podcasts.</p> <p>Podcasts allow for a lot of creativity as they can be about any topic of choice. Additionally, you determine other factors related to the podcast such as cadence of episodes, who's on the podcast, where you advertise the podcast, and how long episodes are.</p> <p><strong>Featured Resource: </strong><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/how-to-start-a-podcast?hubs_post-cta=inline-text\">How to Start a Podcast</a></p> <h3>5. Video Content Marketing</h3> <p>According to HubSpot research, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/news-trends/content-trends-global-preferences?_ga=2.54715939.966330271.1565107559-1493293515.1553017609\">over 50% of consumers</a> say they want to see videos from the brands they interact with. Additionally, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/video-marketing?_ga=2.54715939.966330271.1565107559-1493293515.1553017609\">video marketing </a>can boost conversions, improve ROI, and help you build relationships with audience members. You may choose to share your video content on social media platforms, landing pages, or on a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/34188/what-in-the-heck-is-co-marketing.aspx\">co-marketer's</a> website.</p> <p><strong>Featured Resource: </strong><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/beginners-guide-to-video-marketing?hubs_post-cta=inline-text\">The Ultimate Video Marketing Starter Pack</a></p> <h3>6. Paid Ad Content Marketing</h3> <p><span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; font-weight: 400;\"><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/ppc\">Paid ads</a> can help you reach a broad audience and allow you to position yourself in all of the places you want to be seen — paid ads are especially beneficial when paired with inbound marketing. </span>There are many places you can share paid ads including on social media, landing pages, banners, and sponsored content.</p> <p><strong>Featured Resource: </strong><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/google-ads-ppc-kit?hubs_post-cta=inline-text\">The Ultimate Google Ads PPC Kit</a></p> <p>Next, let's look at some content marketing examples that are associated with those types of content marketing we just reviewed.</p> <a></a> <h2>Content Marketing Examples</h2> <p>The following examples will give you a better understanding of how you can incorporate content in your greater marketing strategy.</p> <h3>1. Example of Social Media Content Marketing</h3> <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-08-02%20at%2010.54.21%20AM.png?width=1500&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-08-02%20at%2010.54.21%20AM.png\" alt=\"social media content marketing example\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> <p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><em><a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/lushcosmetics/?hl=en\">Source</a></em></p> <p>Lush Cosmetics’ Instagram account is on-brand and complements the <a href=\"https://www.lushusa.com/\">rest of their marketing content</a> — if the page didn’t say “Lush Cosmetics” anywhere on the profile, customers would likely still know the profile belongs to Lush.</p> <p>The Instagram page shares the Lush product line, displays different color and scent options for the products, and shows the various ways each product can be used. The profile feels and looks colorful and uniquely Lush, and depicts members of their wide customer base.</p> <h3>2. Example of Infographic Content Marketing</h3> \n <div> \n  <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Content%20Marketing%20in%202019.png?width=1500&amp;name=The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Content%20Marketing%20in%202019.png\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"infographic content marketing example\"> </img>\n </div> <p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><em><a href=\"https://www-03.ibm.com/press/us/en/photo/43780.wss\">Source</a></em></p> <p>IBM created an infographic when they launched their Cloud marketplace. Their infographic is on-brand, well-organized, and easy to read. It clearly explains what they’re doing with their Cloud marketplace and how customers can benefit from it. It also tells audience members how they can access the marketplace and get started using it.</p> <h3>3. Example of Blog Content Marketing</h3> \n <div> \n  <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Content%20Marketing%20in%202019-4.png?width=1500&amp;name=The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Content%20Marketing%20in%202019-4.png\" alt=\"blog content marketing example\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 1500px;\" width=\"1500\"> </img>\n </div> <p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><em><a href=\"https://blog.expedia.com.au/\">Source</a></em></p> <p>Expedia has a blog called “<a href=\"https://blog.expedia.com.au/\">[Out There Starts Here]</a>” that shares travel-related information including hotel recommendations, great places to visit, and travel-related activities you can take part in around the globe.</p> <p>Expedia regularly publishes their blog content to keep readers interested and engaged. It includes a wide range of topics related to any type of trip you could imagine. The blog is on-brand and all articles relate to the travel technology company’s goal and mission of gaining customers and boosting brand awareness. They do this by linking to their services and writing about customers who have already had positive experiences with the company.</p> <h3>4. Example of Podcast Content Marketing</h3> \n <div> \n  <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Content%20Marketing%20in%202019-2.png?width=1500&amp;name=The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Content%20Marketing%20in%202019-2.png\" alt=\"podcast-content-marketing-example\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 1500px;\" width=\"1500\"> </img>\n </div> <p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><em><a href=\"https://hbr.org/2018/01/podcast-ideacast\">Source</a></em></p> <p>Harvard Business Review (HBR) has a weekly podcast called <a href=\"https://hbr.org/2018/01/podcast-ideacast\">HBR IdeaCast</a> which features industry leaders in both business and management. You can either subscribe to consistently receive their hundreds of podcasts or pick and choose which ones you want to listen to.</p> <p>The podcast is on-brand and complements the rest of HBRs published content. It also serves as a great way for HBR to connect with their target audience, enhance brand awareness, and gain a following of audience members through a medium that differs from their typical work (e.g. podcast versus HBR article).</p> <h3>5. Example of Video Content Marketing</h3> \n <div> \n  <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Content%20Marketing%20in%202019-1.png\" alt=\"video-content-marketing-example\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"> </img>\n </div> <p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><em><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZUG9qYTJMsI\">Source</a></em></p> <p>Much of <a href=\"https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/290539\">Dollar Shave Club’s video content has gone viral</a>. Their marketing efforts are on-brand, humorous, and entertaining. In fact, one of their videos has over 26 million views on YouTube. By establishing a name for themselves via online video content, Dollar Shave Club has experienced impressive growth and brand recognition.</p> <h3>6. Example of Paid Ad Content Marketing</h3> \n <div> \n  <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Content%20Marketing%20in%202019-3.png?width=1500&amp;name=The%20Ultimate%20Guide%20to%20Content%20Marketing%20in%202019-3.png\" alt=\"paid-ad-content-marketing-example\" width=\"1500\" style=\"width: 1500px;\"> </img>\n </div> <p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><em><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/REVOLVE/?__tn__=kC-RH-R&amp;eid=ARAEBO9Zpcprsaor1LI7aown1n8iPeru7l_i8643ucnxvM-2Ov9Tn5oP9bTdOuYBpWNSEWm2bB78ZFmKO86A9fFZ8qDkPdNCIhljPMuYS5UOSg4L8S3mzwYOPEj_ZXlfnh0rnzJQaSrFCMPSuwS07Tn4EcjjClATqWFRPtgpuetras5RBg&amp;hc_ref=ARR91mOFt7E6wedtV4o9y8lE2o6gdsi7HjbRaG4z_rm_31SXy2DuV8bsisrLWK5AUjU&amp;fref=nf&amp;__xts__[0]=68.ARDCOh3LMfyV070Ab2Vrt8gUYMHGV57CjT_BKT7eh429ZY44yGCLh70MCf_hdeJK9seZBPfP6y2MEUcDLaO3N5hjj9HHUv4pURYCN2Slfxb0-G7n3Fe15zxzbfjOeaY88veRXRrMZ3Hg556o6olCPpOg1eY1oM1flZ5eMRxnreKtdvzIWPxwIj0YTpmN42BmtSoog0CAFCaF9DBbj1PVYsCLH4SDdIheX0OU613AnIbnTAGK5fIbxdlIXDUx-r27yUIlXCVEmk1C6aODKMdNsWKc1fE99y66o2sz&amp;ft[tn]=kC-R-RH-R-R&amp;ft[adid]=6126944372716&amp;ft[qid]=6721025332595228416&amp;ft[mf_story_key]=-2917377145067682603&amp;ft[ei]=AI%40AQKLTvYETF9H9MLYfxiJDp2n0D1giSyLA4IWzaueZxd6OFouUJPZ6N1M9C3XcFlLYTd14Lwe0i7cO0R1RcP9uDiL&amp;ft[top_level_post_id]=10157780362694311&amp;ft[src]=10&amp;ft[view_time]=1564860654&amp;ft[fbfeed_location]=1&amp;ft[insertion_position]=1&amp;__md__=1\">Source</a></em></p> <p><a href=\"http://www.revolve.com\">Revolve</a> — a clothing and accessories company — uses paid and sponsored ads on social media (like this one on Facebook) to reach their target audience while they browse their news feeds.</p> <p>The content ads feature some of their products as well as details about their free shipping and return policy to drive target audience members to their site (and, hopefully, convert them into paying customers).</p> <p>Lastly, let’s cover your <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/state-of-marketing/content-marketing\">content marketing strategy</a>. By implementing a strategy, your content marketing efforts will be impactful and effective in converting leads and reaching your target audience.</p> <a></a> <p></p> <h3>1. Set SMART goals.</h3> <p>The first part of your content marketing strategy is to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33898/how-to-set-smart-marketing-goals-for-2013-template.aspx?_ga=2.219868945.966330271.1565107559-1493293515.1553017609\">set SMART goals</a>. These should be specific to your business — they’ll likely complement your broader marketing and company goals.</p> <p>Here are some <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/how-to-determine-your-smart-marketing-goals\">SMART goal examples</a>:</p> \n <ul> \n  <li>Improve brand awareness</li> \n  <li>Boost revenue</li> \n  <li>Increase conversions</li> \n  <li>Improve brand loyalty</li> \n  <li>Increase customer engagement</li> \n  <li>Build rapport and trust among prospects and customers</li> \n  <li>Attract strategic partners</li> \n </ul> <h3>2. Determine your KPIs.</h3> <p>Next, set <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/choosing-kpis?_ga=2.219868945.966330271.1565107559-1493293515.1553017609\">key performance indicators (KPIs)</a> for your SMART goals. KPIs are quantifiable data points you can use to measure your actual performance against your goal.</p> \n <table style=\"border-collapse: collapse; width: 100%; height: 884px;\"> \n  <tbody> \n   <tr style=\"height: 65px;\"> \n    <td style=\"width: 50%; height: 65px;\">smart goal</td> \n    <td style=\"width: 50%; height: 65px;\">related kpi</td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr style=\"height: 149px;\"> \n    <td style=\"width: 50%; height: 149px;\">Brand awareness</td> \n    <td style=\"width: 50%; height: 149px;\">Site traffic, social media followers, subscription sign-ups, mentions (by customers and partners)</td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr style=\"height: 65px;\"> \n    <td style=\"width: 50%; height: 65px;\">Revenue</td> \n    <td style=\"width: 50%; height: 65px;\">Daily sales, site traffic</td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr style=\"height: 177px;\"> \n    <td style=\"width: 50%; height: 177px;\">Conversions</td> \n    <td style=\"width: 50%; height: 177px;\">Conversion rate, shopping cart abandonment rate, associated shipping rate trends, competitive price trends</td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr style=\"height: 121px;\"> \n    <td style=\"width: 50%; height: 121px;\">Brand loyalty</td> \n    <td style=\"width: 50%; height: 121px;\">Returning customers, promoters, product reviews, referrals</td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr style=\"height: 93px;\"> \n    <td style=\"width: 50%; height: 93px;\">Customer engagement</td> \n    <td style=\"width: 50%; height: 93px;\">Likes, shares, follows, mentions, backlinks</td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr style=\"height: 121px;\"> \n    <td style=\"width: 50%; height: 121px;\">Rapport and trust</td> \n    <td style=\"width: 50%; height: 121px;\">Returning customers, promoters, followers, mentions</td> \n   </tr> \n   <tr style=\"height: 93px;\"> \n    <td style=\"width: 50%; height: 93px;\">Strategic partners</td> \n    <td style=\"width: 50%; height: 93px;\">New partnerships, mentions, backlinks</td> \n   </tr> \n  </tbody> \n </table> <h3><br>3. Decide on the type of content.</br></h3> <p>Next, choose the type of content you’ll create. To do this, start by thinking about your target audience and buyer personas.</p> \n <div class=\"hs-embed-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; width: 100%; height: auto; padding: 0px; max-width: 560px; max-height: 315px; min-width: 256px; display: block; margin: auto;\"> \n  <div class=\"hs-embed-content-wrapper\"> \n   <div style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.25%; margin: 0px;\"> \n    <iframe width=\"480\" height=\"270\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/PfDwKjgL8tY?feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0px; left: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\"></iframe> \n   </div> \n  </div> \n </div> <p>Answer the following questions about your target audience to help you narrow down the right types of content for them:</p> \n <ul> \n  <li>What do they need from you?</li> \n  <li>What challenges are they looking to overcome?</li> \n  <li>Why do they need your product or service?</li> \n  <li>How can you help them succeed?</li> \n  <li>Where do they spend their time?</li> \n </ul> <p>Then, take a look back at the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-marketing#types-of-content-marketing\">various types of content we reviewed earlier</a> to decide which types of content you’ll create.</p> <h3>4. Choose your content channels.</h3> <p>Once you’ve decided on the type of content you’ll market with, it’s time to choose your specific content channels. Where will you share your content? Where will it live and be shared from?</p> <p>For some of the content types, the channel you need to work with will be obvious. For example, if you’re creating Facebook content, your channel will be the social platform itself.</p> <h3>5. Set a budget.</h3> <p>Now, set your budget. Think about the type of content you’re creating and which channels you’re marketing that content on.</p> <p>Then, ask yourself the following questions to determine your budget:</p> \n <ul> \n  <li>Do you need to purchase any software or technology to create the content (such as graphic design software like <a href=\"https://www.adobe.com/products/photoshop.html\">Adobe Photoshop</a>, a subscription to <a href=\"https://www.canva.com/\">Canva</a>, a camera to take high-quality photos and videos)?</li> \n  <li>Do you need to hire any content marketers or designers (such as artists, writers, editors, designers)?</li> \n  <li>Do you need to pay for ad space?</li> \n  <li>Do you need access to specific tools or resources to enhance or measure your specific type of content?</li> \n </ul> <p>Make note of how your responses impact your budget — whether that’s an increase or decrease in what you may have already estimated.</p> <h3>6. Create and distribute the content.</h3> <p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-distribution?_ga=2.242593546.966330271.1565107559-1493293515.1553017609\">Create and distribute your content</a> so your audience members can consume it — and possibly convert. To ensure you’re consistently producing content and sharing it among your prospects and customers, use a <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33415/the-social-media-publishing-schedule-every-marketer-needs-template.aspx?_ga=2.242593546.966330271.1565107559-1493293515.1553017609\">social media calendar</a> or an editorial content calendar. This will help your team stay on top of all of the content being created as well as allow you to schedule it ahead of time.</p> <p><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/editorial-calendar-templates?hubs_post-cta=pillar_allphrase&amp;_ga=2.257691011.966330271.1565107559-1493293515.1553017609\"><em>Use a free editorial calendar to schedule and optimize all of your marketing content to help you boost conversions.</em> </a></p> <h3>7. Analyze and measure results.</h3> <p>Lastly, analyze and measure your results so you can make any necessary changes to enhance your content marketing efforts and reach more audience members.</p> <p>Look at your SMART goals and KPIs to determine the success of your content marketing strategy. Did you achieve your goals and KPIs? Were you close to reaching them, or were you off in your estimations?</p> <p>Here are some tools to help you with your content marketing strategy analytics and results:</p> \n <ul> \n  <li>HubSpot <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/analytics?_ga=2.15920830.966330271.1565107559-1493293515.1553017609\">Marketing Analytics Software</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/social-inbox?_ga=2.15920830.966330271.1565107559-1493293515.1553017609\">HubSpot Social Media Management Software</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://mention.com/en/\">Mention</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://www.sharedcount.com/\">SharedCount</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/integrations/sprout-social?_ga=2.15920830.966330271.1565107559-1493293515.1553017609\">Sprout Social</a></li> \n  <li><a href=\"https://marketingplatform.google.com/about/analytics/\">Google Analytics</a></li> \n </ul> <h2>Engage Your Target Audience With Content Marketing</h2> <p>With effective content marketing, you can reach your target audience and increase conversions. There are several ways to market with content to boost revenue, grow your brand awareness and recognition, and build relationships with your prospects and customers.</p> <p>And don't forget to extract more value from every piece of content you create.</p> \n <div class=\"hs-embed-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; width: 100%; height: auto; padding: 0px; max-width: 560px; max-height: 315px; min-width: 256px; display: block; margin: auto;\"> \n  <div class=\"hs-embed-content-wrapper\"> \n   <div style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.25%; margin: 0px;\"> \n    <iframe width=\"480\" height=\"270\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/90yYcrhdYus?feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0px; left: 0px; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\"></iframe> \n   </div> \n  </div> \n </div> <p>To get started, determine which type of content works best for your business and audience, and develop a content marketing strategy to begin boosting your bottom line today.</p> <p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in August, 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> <p></p> <p></p> <img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcontent-marketing&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\"
